>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:62
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
61	               'categories': ['credential-access'],
62	               'description': 'Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in the process memory of '
63	                              'the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS). After a user logs on, the '
64	                              'system generates and stores a variety of credential materials in LSASS process memory. '
65	                              'These credential materials can be harvested by an administrative user or SYSTEM and '
66	                              'used to conduct [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) using [Use '
67	                              'Alternate Authentication Material](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550).\n'
68	                              '\n'
69	                              'As well as in-memory techniques, the LSASS process memory can be dumped from the target '
70	                              'host and analyzed on a local system.\n'
71	                              '\n'
72	                              'For example, on the target host use procdump:\n'
73	                              '\n'
74	                              '* <code>procdump -ma lsass.exe lsass_dump</code>\n'
75	                              '\n'
76	                              'Locally, mimikatz can be run using:\n'
77	                              '\n'
78	                              '* <code>sekurlsa::Minidump lsassdump.dmp</code>\n'
79	                              '* <code>sekurlsa::logonPasswords</code>\n'
80	                              '\n'
81	                              'Built-in Windows tools such as `comsvcs.dll` can also be used:\n'
82	                              '\n'
83	                              '* <code>rundll32.exe C:\\Windows\\System32\\comsvcs.dll MiniDump PID  lsass.dmp '
84	                              'full</code>(Citation: Volexity Exchange Marauder March 2021)(Citation: Symantec Attacks '
85	                              'Against Government Sector)\n'
86	                              '\n'
87	                              'Similar to [Image File Execution Options '
88	                              'Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012), the silent process exit '
89	                              'mechanism can be abused to create a memory dump of `lsass.exe` through Windows Error '
90	                              'Reporting (`WerFault.exe`).(Citation: Deep Instinct LSASS)\n'
91	                              '\n'
92	                              'Windows Security Support Provider (SSP) DLLs are loaded into LSASS process at system '
93	                              'start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext '
94	                              "passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or "
95	                              'smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: '
96	                              '<code>HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\Lsa\\Security Packages</code> and '
97	                              '<code>HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\Lsa\\OSConfig\\Security '
98	                              'Packages</code>. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which '
99	                              'will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows '
100	                              'API function is called.(Citation: Graeber 2014)\n'
101	                              '\n'
102	                              'The following SSPs can be used to access credentials:\n'
103	                              '\n'
104	                              '* Msv: Interactive logons, batch logons, and service logons are done through the MSV '
105	                              'authentication package.\n'
106	                              '* Wdigest: The Digest Authentication protocol is designed for use with Hypertext '
107	                              'Transfer Protocol (HTTP) and Simple Authentication Security Layer (SASL) '
108	                              'exchanges.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection)\n'
109	                              '* Kerberos: Preferred for mutual client-server domain authentication in Windows 2000 '
110	                              'and later.\n'
111	                              '* CredSSP:  Provides SSO and Network Level Authentication for Remote Desktop '
112	                              'Services.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection)\n',
113	               'name': 'LSASS Memory',
114	               'platforms': ['Windows']},
115	 'T1003.002': {'attack_id': 'T1003.002',
116	               'categories': ['credential-access'],
117	               'description': 'Adversaries may attempt to extract credential material from the Security Account '

121	                              'command. Enumerating the SAM database requires SYSTEM level access.\n'
122	                              '\n'

127	                              '* [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002)\n'
128	                              '* secretsdump.py\n'
129	                              '\n'
130	                              'Alternatively, the SAM can be extracted from the Registry with Reg:\n'
131	                              '\n'
132	                              '* <code>reg save HKLM\\sam sam</code>\n'
133	                              '* <code>reg save HKLM\\system system</code>\n'

183	                              'authentication to occur in the event a domain controller is unavailable.(Citation: '
184	                              'Microsoft - Cached Creds)\n'
185	                              '\n'
186	                              'On Windows Vista and newer, the hash format is DCC2 (Domain Cached Credentials version '
187	                              '2) hash, also known as MS-Cache v2 hash.(Citation: PassLib mscache) The number of '
188	                              'default cached credentials varies and can be altered per system. This hash does not '
189	                              'allow pass-the-hash style attacks, and instead requires [Password '
190	                              'Cracking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110/002) to recover the plaintext '
191	                              'password.(Citation: ired mscache)\n'
192	                              '\n'
193	                              'On Linux systems, Active Directory credentials can be accessed through caches '
194	                              'maintained by software like System Security Services Daemon (SSSD) or Quest '
195	                              'Authentication Services (formerly VAS). Cached credential hashes are typically located '
196	                              'at `/var/lib/sss/db/cache.[domain].ldb` for SSSD or '
197	                              '`/var/opt/quest/vas/authcache/vas_auth.vdb` for Quest. Adversaries can use utilities, '
198	                              'such as `tdbdump`, on these database files to dump the cached hashes and use [Password '
199	                              'Cracking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110/002) to obtain the plaintext '
200	                              'password.(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix) \n'
201	                              '\n'
202	                              'With SYSTEM or sudo access, the tools/utilities such as '

204	                              '[Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075), and secretsdump.py for Windows or '
205	                              'Linikatz for Linux can be used to extract the cached credentials.(Citation: Brining '
206	                              'MimiKatz to Unix)\n'
207	                              '\n'
208	                              'Note: Cached credentials for Windows Vista are derived using PBKDF2.(Citation: PassLib '
209	                              'mscache)',

432	                              'passwords, on compromised systems. Adversaries may use Wi-Fi information as part of '
433	                              '[Account Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1087), [Remote System '
434	                              'Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1018), and other discovery or '
435	                              '[Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0006) activity to support both '
436	                              'ongoing and future campaigns.\n'
437	                              '\n'
438	                              'Adversaries may collect various types of information about Wi-Fi networks from hosts. '
439	                              'For example, on Windows names and passwords of all Wi-Fi networks a device has '
440	                              'previously connected to may be available through `netsh wlan show profiles` to '
441	                              'enumerate Wi-Fi names and then `netsh wlan show profile “Wi-Fi name” key=clear` to show '
442	                              'a Wi-Fi network’s corresponding password.(Citation: BleepingComputer Agent Tesla steal '
443	                              'wifi passwords)(Citation: Malware Bytes New AgentTesla variant steals WiFi '
444	                              'credentials)(Citation: Check Point APT35 CharmPower January 2022) Additionally, names '
445	                              'and other details of locally reachable Wi-Fi networks can be discovered using calls to '
446	                              '`wlanAPI.dll` [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) '
447	                              'functions.(Citation: Binary Defense Emotes Wi-Fi Spreader)\n'
448	                              '\n'
449	                              'On Linux, names and passwords of all Wi-Fi-networks a device has previously connected '
450	                              'to may be available in files under ` '
451	                              '/etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/`.(Citation: Wi-Fi Password of All Connected '
452	                              'Networks in Windows/Linux) On macOS, the password of a known Wi-Fi may be identified '
453	                              'with ` security find-generic-password -wa wifiname` (requires admin '

521	                          'a service that accepts remote connections, such as telnet, SSH, and VNC. The adversary may '
522	                          'then perform actions as the logged-on user.\n'
523	                          '\n'
524	                          'In an enterprise environment, servers and workstations can be organized into domains. '
525	                          'Domains provide centralized identity management, allowing users to login using one set of '
526	                          'credentials across the entire network. If an adversary is able to obtain a set of valid '
527	                          'domain credentials, they could login to many different machines using remote access '
528	                          'protocols such as secure shell (SSH) or remote desktop protocol (RDP).(Citation: SSH Secure '
529	                          'Shell)(Citation: TechNet Remote Desktop Services) They could also login to accessible SaaS '
530	                          'or IaaS services, such as those that federate their identities to the domain. \n'
531	                          '\n'
532	                          'Legitimate applications (such as [Software Deployment '
533	                          'Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1072) and other administrative programs) may '
534	                          'utilize [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) to access remote '
535	                          'hosts. For example, Apple Remote Desktop (ARD) on macOS is native software used for remote '
536	                          'management. ARD leverages a blend of protocols, including '
537	                          '[VNC](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/005) to send the screen and control buffers '
538	                          'and [SSH](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/004) for secure file '
539	                          'transfer.(Citation: Remote Management MDM macOS)(Citation: Kickstart Apple Remote Desktop '
540	                          'commands)(Citation: Apple Remote Desktop Admin Guide 3.3) Adversaries can abuse '
541	                          'applications such as ARD to gain remote code execution and perform lateral movement. In '
542	                          'versions of macOS prior to 10.14, an adversary can escalate an SSH session to an ARD '
543	                          'session which enables an adversary to accept TCC (Transparency, Consent, and Control) '
544	                          'prompts without user interaction and gain access to data.(Citation: FireEye 2019 Apple '

572	                              'interact with a remote network share using Server Message Block (SMB). The adversary '
573	                              'may then perform actions as the logged-on user.\n'
574	                              '\n'
575	                              'SMB is a file, printer, and serial port sharing protocol for Windows machines on the '
576	                              'same network or domain. Adversaries may use SMB to interact with file shares, allowing '
577	                              'them to move laterally throughout a network. Linux and macOS implementations of SMB '
578	                              'typically use Samba.\n'
579	                              '\n'
580	                              'Windows systems have hidden network shares that are accessible only to administrators '
581	                              'and provide the ability for remote file copy and other administrative functions. '
582	                              'Example network shares include `C$`, `ADMIN$`, and `IPC$`. Adversaries may use this '
583	                              'technique in conjunction with administrator-level [Valid '
584	                              'Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to remotely access a networked '
585	                              'system over SMB,(Citation: Wikipedia Server Message Block) to interact with systems '
586	                              'using remote procedure calls (RPCs),(Citation: TechNet RPC) transfer files, and run '
587	                              'transferred binaries through remote Execution. Example execution techniques that rely '
588	                              'on authenticated sessions over SMB/RPC are [Scheduled '
589	                              'Task/Job](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053), [Service '
590	                              'Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1569/002), and [Windows Management '
591	                              'Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047). Adversaries can also use '
592	                              'NTLM hashes to access administrator shares on systems with [Pass the '
593	                              'Hash](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/002) and certain configuration and '
594	                              'patch levels.(Citation: Microsoft Admin Shares)',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:599
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
598	               'categories': ['lateral-movement'],
599	               'description': 'Adversaries may use [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to '
600	                              'interact with remote machines by taking advantage of Distributed Component Object Model '
601	                              '(DCOM). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.\n'
602	                              '\n'
603	                              'The Windows Component Object Model (COM) is a component of the native Windows '
604	                              'application programming interface (API) that enables interaction between software '
605	                              'objects, or executable code that implements one or more interfaces. Through COM, a '
606	                              'client object can call methods of server objects, which are typically Dynamic Link '
607	                              'Libraries (DLL) or executables (EXE). Distributed COM (DCOM) is transparent middleware '
608	                              'that extends the functionality of COM beyond a local computer using remote procedure '
609	                              'call (RPC) technology.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019)(Citation: Microsoft '
610	                              'COM)\n'
611	                              '\n'
612	                              'Permissions to interact with local and remote server COM objects are specified by '
613	                              'access control lists (ACL) in the Registry.(Citation: Microsoft Process Wide Com Keys) '
614	                              'By default, only Administrators may remotely activate and launch COM objects through '
615	                              'DCOM.(Citation: Microsoft COM ACL)\n'
616	                              '\n'
617	                              'Through DCOM, adversaries operating in the context of an appropriately privileged user '
618	                              'can remotely obtain arbitrary and even direct shellcode execution through Office '
619	                              'applications(Citation: Enigma Outlook DCOM Lateral Movement Nov 2017) as well as other '
620	                              'Windows objects that contain insecure methods.(Citation: Enigma MMC20 COM Jan '
621	                              '2017)(Citation: Enigma DCOM Lateral Movement Jan 2017) DCOM can also execute macros in '
622	                              'existing documents(Citation: Enigma Excel DCOM Sept 2017) and may also invoke [Dynamic '
623	                              'Data Exchange](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/002) (DDE) execution directly '
624	                              'through a COM created instance of a Microsoft Office application(Citation: Cyberreason '
625	                              'DCOM DDE Lateral Movement Nov 2017), bypassing the need for a malicious document. DCOM '
626	                              'can be used as a method of remotely interacting with [Windows Management '
627	                              'Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047). (Citation: MSDN WMI)',
628	               'name': 'Distributed Component Object Model',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:647
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
646	               'categories': ['lateral-movement'],
647	               'description': 'Adversaries may use [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to '
648	                              'remotely control machines using Virtual Network Computing (VNC).  VNC is a '
649	                              'platform-independent desktop sharing system that uses the RFB (“remote framebuffer”) '
650	                              'protocol to enable users to remotely control another computer’s display by relaying the '
651	                              'screen, mouse, and keyboard inputs over the network.(Citation: The Remote Framebuffer '
652	                              'Protocol)\n'
653	                              '\n'
654	                              'VNC differs from [Remote Desktop '
655	                              'Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/001) as VNC is screen-sharing '
656	                              "software rather than resource-sharing software. By default, VNC uses the system's "
657	                              'authentication, but it can be configured to use credentials specific to VNC.(Citation: '
658	                              'MacOS VNC software for Remote Desktop)(Citation: VNC Authentication)\n'
659	                              '\n'
660	                              'Adversaries may abuse VNC to perform malicious actions as the logged-on user such as '
661	                              'opening documents, downloading files, and running arbitrary commands. An adversary '
662	                              'could use VNC to remotely control and monitor a system to collect data and information '

668	                              'authentication bug)',
669	               'name': 'VNC',

892	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
893	               'description': 'Adversaries may obfuscate then dynamically resolve API functions called by their '
894	                              'malware in order to conceal malicious functionalities and impair defensive analysis. '
895	                              'Malware commonly uses various [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) '
896	                              'functions provided by the OS to perform various tasks such as those involving '
897	                              'processes, files, and other system artifacts.\n'
898	                              '\n'
899	                              'API functions called by malware may leave static artifacts such as strings in payload '
900	                              'files. Defensive analysts may also uncover which functions a binary file may execute '
901	                              'via an import address table (IAT) or other structures that help dynamically link '
902	                              'calling code to the shared modules that provide functions.(Citation: Huntress API '
903	                              'Hash)(Citation: IRED API Hashing)\n'
904	                              '\n'
905	                              'To avoid static or other defensive analysis, adversaries may use dynamic API resolution '
906	                              'to conceal malware characteristics and functionalities. Similar to [Software '
907	                              'Packing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002), dynamic API resolution may '
908	                              'change file signatures and obfuscate malicious API function calls until they are '
909	                              'resolved and invoked during runtime.\n'
910	                              '\n'
911	                              'Various methods may be used to obfuscate malware calls to API functions. For example, '
912	                              'hashes of function names are commonly stored in malware in lieu of literal strings. '
913	                              'Malware can use these hashes (or other identifiers) to manually reproduce the linking '
914	                              'and loading process using functions such as `GetProcAddress()` and `LoadLibrary()`. '
915	                              'These hashes/identifiers can also be further obfuscated using encryption or other '
916	                              'string manipulation tricks (requiring various forms of [Deobfuscate/Decode Files or '
917	                              'Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140) during execution).(Citation: '
918	                              'BlackHat API Packers)(Citation: Drakonia HInvoke)(Citation: Huntress API Hash)',
919	               'name': 'Dynamic API Resolution',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:972

971	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
972	               'description': 'Adversaries may obfuscate content during command execution to impede detection. '
973	                              'Command-line obfuscation is a method of making strings and patterns within commands and '
974	                              'scripts more difficult to signature and analyze. This type of obfuscation can be '
975	                              'included within commands executed by delivered payloads (e.g., '
976	                              '[Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) and [Drive-by '
977	                              'Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189)) or interactively via [Command '
978	                              'and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059).(Citation: Akamai '
979	                              'JS)(Citation: Malware Monday VBE)\n'
980	                              '\n'
981	                              'For example, adversaries may abuse syntax that utilizes various symbols and escape '
982	                              'characters (such as spacing,  `^`, `+`. `$`, and `%`) to make commands difficult to '
983	                              'analyze while maintaining the same intended functionality.(Citation: RC PowerShell) '
984	                              'Many languages support built-in obfuscation in the form of base64 or URL '
985	                              'encoding.(Citation: Microsoft PowerShellB64) Adversaries may also manually implement '
986	                              'command obfuscation via string splitting (`“Wor”+“d.Application”`), order and casing of '
987	                              "characters (`rev <<<'dwssap/cte/ tac'`), globing (`mkdir -p '/tmp/:&$NiA'`), as well as "
988	                              'various tricks involving passing strings through tokens/environment variables/input '
989	                              'streams.(Citation: Bashfuscator Command Obfuscators)(Citation: FireEye Obfuscation June '
990	                              '2017)\n'
991	                              '\n'
992	                              'Adversaries may also use tricks such as directory traversals to obfuscate references to '
993	                              'the binary being invoked by a command '
994	                              '(`C:\\voi\\pcw\\..\\..\\Windows\\tei\\qs\\k\\..\\..\\..\\system32\\erool\\..\\wbem\\wg\\je\\..\\..\\wmic.exe '
995	                              'shadowcopy delete`).(Citation: Twitter Richard WMIC)\n'
996	                              '\n'
997	                              'Tools such as <code>Invoke-Obfuscation</code> and <code>Invoke-DOSfucation</code> have '
998	                              'also been used to obfuscate commands.(Citation: Invoke-DOSfuscation)(Citation: '
999	                              'Invoke-Obfuscation)',
1000	               'name': 'Command Obfuscation',
1001	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows']},

1006	                              'Common examples of non-volatile fileless storage include the Windows Registry, event '
1007	                              'logs, or WMI repository.(Citation: Microsoft Fileless)(Citation: SecureList Fileless)\n'
1008	                              '\n'

1010	                              'Loading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1620) and [Process '
1011	                              'Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055), fileless data storage may remain '
1012	                              'undetected by anti-virus and other endpoint security tools that can only access '
1013	                              'specific file formats from disk storage.\n'
1014	                              '\n'
1015	                              'Adversaries may use fileless storage to conceal various types of stored data, including '

1052	                              'patterns to impede detection. Encrypting and/or encoding file content aims to conceal '
1053	                              'malicious artifacts within a file used in an intrusion. Many other techniques, such as '
1054	                              '[Software Packing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002), '
1055	                              '[Steganography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/003), and [Embedded '
1056	                              'Payloads](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/009), share this same broad '
1057	                              'objective. Encrypting and/or encoding files could lead to a lapse in detection of '
1058	                              'static signatures, only for this malicious content to be revealed (i.e., '
1059	                              '[Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140)) '

1065	                              'obfuscated using standard encoding/compression schemes such as Base64.\n'
1066	                              '\n'

1074	                              'function by attaching the intended archived content to a decompressor stub that is '

1076	                              'Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: SFX - '

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:1132
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
1131	           'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation'],
1132	           'description': '**This technique has been deprecated. Please use [Path Interception by PATH Environment '
1133	                          'Variable](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/007), [Path Interception by Search '
1134	                          'Order Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/008), and/or [Path Interception '
1135	                          'by Unquoted Path](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/009).**\n'
1136	                          '\n'
1137	                          'Path interception occurs when an executable is placed in a specific path so that it is '
1138	                          'executed by an application instead of the intended target. One example of this was the use '
1139	                          'of a copy of [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) in the current working '
1140	                          'directory of a vulnerable application that loads a CMD or BAT file with the CreateProcess '
1141	                          'function. (Citation: TechNet MS14-019)\n'
1142	                          '\n'
1143	                          'There are multiple distinct weaknesses or misconfigurations that adversaries may take '
1144	                          'advantage of when performing path interception: unquoted paths, path environment variable '
1145	                          'misconfigurations, and search order hijacking. The first vulnerability deals with full '
1146	                          'program paths, while the second and third occur when program paths are not specified. These '
1147	                          'techniques can be used for persistence if executables are called on a regular basis, as '
1148	                          'well as privilege escalation if intercepted executables are started by a higher privileged '
1149	                          'process.\n'
1150	                          '\n'
1151	                          '### Unquoted Paths\n'
1152	                          'Service paths (stored in Windows Registry keys) (Citation: Microsoft Subkey) and shortcut '
1153	                          'paths are vulnerable to path interception if the path has one or more spaces and is not '
1154	                          'surrounded by quotation marks (e.g., <code>C:\\unsafe path with space\\program.exe</code> '
1155	                          'vs. <code>"C:\\safe path with space\\program.exe"</code>). (Citation: Baggett 2012) An '
1156	                          'adversary can place an executable in a higher level directory of the path, and Windows will '
1157	                          'resolve that executable instead of the intended executable. For example, if the path in a '
1158	                          'shortcut is <code>C:\\program files\\myapp.exe</code>, an adversary may create a program at '
1159	                          '<code>C:\\program.exe</code> that will be run instead of the intended program. (Citation: '
1160	                          'SecurityBoulevard Unquoted Services APR 2018) (Citation: SploitSpren Windows Priv Jan '
1161	                          '2018)\n'
1162	                          '\n'
1163	                          '### PATH Environment Variable Misconfiguration\n'
1164	                          'The PATH environment variable contains a list of directories. Certain methods of executing '
1165	                          'a program (namely using cmd.exe or the command-line) rely solely on the PATH environment '
1166	                          'variable to determine the locations that are searched for a program when the path for the '
1167	                          'program is not given. If any directories are listed in the PATH environment variable before '
1168	                          'the Windows directory, <code>%SystemRoot%\\system32</code> (e.g., '
1169	                          '<code>C:\\Windows\\system32</code>), a program may be placed in the preceding directory '
1170	                          'that is named the same as a Windows program (such as cmd, PowerShell, or Python), which '
1171	                          'will be executed when that command is executed from a script or command-line.\n'
1172	                          '\n'
1173	                          'For example, if <code>C:\\example path</code> precedes <code>C:\\Windows\\system32</code> '
1174	                          'is in the PATH environment variable, a program that is named net.exe and placed in '
1175	                          '<code>C:\\example path</code> will be called instead of the Windows system "net" when "net" '
1176	                          'is executed from the command-line.\n'
1177	                          '\n'
1178	                          '### Search Order Hijacking\n'
1179	                          'Search order hijacking occurs when an adversary abuses the order in which Windows searches '
1180	                          'for programs that are not given a path. The search order differs depending on the method '
1181	                          'that is used to execute the program. (Citation: Microsoft CreateProcess) (Citation: Hill NT '
1182	                          'Shell) (Citation: Microsoft WinExec) However, it is common for Windows to search in the '
1183	                          'directory of the initiating program before searching through the Windows system directory. '
1184	                          'An adversary who finds a program vulnerable to search order hijacking (i.e., a program that '
1185	                          'does not specify the path to an executable) may take advantage of this vulnerability by '
1186	                          'creating a program named after the improperly specified program and placing it within the '
1187	                          "initiating program's directory.\n"
1188	                          '\n'
1189	                          'For example, "example.exe" runs "cmd.exe" with the command-line argument <code>net '
1190	                          'user</code>. An adversary may place a program called "net.exe" within the same directory as '
1191	                          'example.exe, "net.exe" will be run instead of the Windows system utility net. In addition, '
1192	                          'if an adversary places a program called "net.com" in the same directory as "net.exe", then '
1193	                          '<code>cmd.exe /C net user</code> will execute "net.com" instead of "net.exe" due to the '
1194	                          'order of executable extensions defined under PATHEXT. (Citation: MSDN Environment '
1195	                          'Property)\n'
1196	                          '\n'
1197	                          'Search order hijacking is also a common practice for hijacking DLL loads and is covered in '
1198	                          '[DLL Search Order Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1038).',
1199	           'name': 'Path Interception',
1200	           'platforms': ['Windows']},
1201	 'T1036': {'attack_id': 'T1036',
1202	           'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
1203	           'description': 'Adversaries may attempt to manipulate features of their artifacts to make them appear '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:1230
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
1229	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
1230	               'description': 'Adversaries may abuse the right-to-left override (RTLO or RLO) character (U+202E) to '
1231	                              'disguise a string and/or file name to make it appear benign. RTLO is a non-printing '
1232	                              'Unicode character that causes the text that follows it to be displayed in reverse. For '
1233	                              'example, a Windows screensaver executable named <code>March 25 \\u202Excod.scr</code> '
1234	                              'will display as <code>March 25 rcs.docx</code>. A JavaScript file named '
1235	                              '<code>photo_high_re\\u202Egnp.js</code> will be displayed as '
1236	                              '<code>photo_high_resj.png</code>.(Citation: Infosecinstitute RTLO Technique)\n'
1237	                              '\n'
1238	                              'Adversaries may abuse the RTLO character as a means of tricking a user into executing '
1239	                              'what they think is a benign file type. A common use of this technique is with '
1240	                              '[Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001)/[Malicious '
1241	                              'File](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002) since it can trick both end users '
1242	                              'and defenders if they are not aware of how their tools display and render the RTLO '
1243	                              'character. Use of the RTLO character has been seen in many targeted intrusion attempts '
1244	                              'and criminal activity.(Citation: Trend Micro PLEAD RTLO)(Citation: Kaspersky RTLO Cyber '
1245	                              'Crime) RTLO can be used in the Windows Registry as well, where regedit.exe displays the '
1246	                              'reversed characters but the command line tool reg.exe does not by default.',

1312	                              'true file type. A file name may include a secondary file type extension that may cause '
1313	                              'only the first extension to be displayed (ex: <code>File.txt.exe</code> may render in '
1314	                              'some views as just <code>File.txt</code>). However, the second extension is the true '
1315	                              'file type that determines how the file is opened and executed. The real file extension '
1316	                              'may be hidden by the operating system in the file browser (ex: explorer.exe), as well '
1317	                              'as in any software configured using or similar to the system’s policies.(Citation: '
1318	                              'PCMag DoubleExtension)(Citation: SOCPrime DoubleExtension) \n'
1319	                              '\n'
1320	                              'Adversaries may abuse double extensions to attempt to conceal dangerous file types of '
1321	                              'payloads. A very common usage involves tricking a user into opening what they think is '
1322	                              'a benign file type but is actually executable code. Such files often pose as email '
1323	                              'attachments and allow an adversary to gain [Initial '
1324	                              'Access](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0001) into a user’s system via '
1325	                              '[Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001) then [User '
1326	                              'Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204). For example, an executable file '
1327	                              'attachment named <code>Evil.txt.exe</code> may display as <code>Evil.txt</code> to a '
1328	                              'user. The user may then view it as a benign text file and open it, inadvertently '
1329	                              'executing the hidden malware.(Citation: SOCPrime DoubleExtension)\n'
1330	                              '\n'
1331	                              'Common file types, such as text files (.txt, .doc, etc.) and image files (.jpg, .gif, '
1332	                              'etc.) are typically used as the first extension to appear benign. Executable extensions '
1333	                              'commonly regarded as dangerous, such as .exe, .lnk, .hta, and .scr, often appear as the '
1334	                              'second extension and true file type.',
1335	               'name': 'Double File Extension',
1336	               'platforms': ['Windows']},
1337	 'T1036.008': {'attack_id': 'T1036.008',
1338	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
1339	               'description': 'Adversaries may masquerade malicious payloads as legitimate files through changes to '

1340	                              "the payload's formatting, including the file’s signature, extension, and contents. "
1341	                              'Various file types have a typical standard format, including how they are encoded and '
1342	                              'organized. For example, a file’s signature (also known as header or magic bytes) is the '
1343	                              'beginning bytes of a file and is often used to identify the file’s type. For example, '
1344	                              'the header of a JPEG file,  is <code> 0xFF 0xD8</code> and the file extension is either '
1345	                              '`.JPE`, `.JPEG` or `.JPG`. \n'
1346	                              '\n'
1347	                              'Adversaries may edit the header’s hex code and/or the file extension of a malicious '
1348	                              'payload in order to bypass file validation checks and/or input sanitization. This '
1349	                              'behavior is commonly used when payload files are transferred (e.g., [Ingress Tool '
1350	                              'Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105)) and stored (e.g., [Upload '
1351	                              'Malware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1608/001)) so that adversaries may move '
1352	                              'their malware without triggering detections. \n'
1353	                              '\n'
1354	                              'Common non-executable file types and extensions, such as text files (`.txt`) and image '
1355	                              'files (`.jpg`, `.gif`, etc.) may be typically treated as benign.  Based on this, '
1356	                              'adversaries may use a file extension to disguise malware, such as naming a PHP backdoor '
1357	                              'code with a file name of <code>test.gif</code>. A user may not know that a file is '
1358	                              'malicious due to the benign appearance and file extension.\n'
1359	                              '\n'
1360	                              'Polygot files, which are files that have multiple different file types and that '
1361	                              'function differently based on the application that will execute them, may also be used '
1362	                              'to disguise malicious malware and capabilities.(Citation: polygot_icedID)',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:1367

1366	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
1367	               'description': 'An adversary may attempt to evade process tree-based analysis by modifying executed '
1368	                              "malware's parent process ID (PPID). If endpoint protection software leverages the "
1369	                              '“parent-child" relationship for detection, breaking this relationship could result in '
1370	                              'the adversary’s behavior not being associated with previous process tree activity. On '
1371	                              'Unix-based systems breaking this process tree is common practice for administrators to '
1372	                              'execute software using scripts and programs.(Citation: 3OHA double-fork 2022) \n'
1373	                              '\n'
1374	                              'On Linux systems, adversaries may execute a series of [Native '
1375	                              "API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) calls to alter malware's process tree. "
1376	                              'For example, adversaries can execute their payload without any arguments, call the '
1377	                              '`fork()` API call twice, then have the parent process exit. This creates a grandchild '
1378	                              'process with no parent process that is immediately adopted by the `init` system process '
1379	                              "(PID 1), which successfully disconnects the execution of the adversary's payload from "
1380	                              'its previous process tree.\n'
1381	                              '\n'
1382	                              'Another example is using the “daemon” syscall to detach from the current parent process '
1383	                              'and run in the background.(Citation: Sandfly BPFDoor 2022)(Citation: Microsoft XorDdos '
1384	                              'Linux Stealth 2022) ',
1385	               'name': 'Break Process Trees',
1386	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS']},

1422	                              'privileges upon user logon. The plist file is located in the '
1423	                              '<code>/Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist</code> file and can be modified '
1424	                              'using the <code>defaults</code> command-line utility. This behavior is the same for '
1425	                              'logout hooks where a script can be executed upon user logout. All hooks require '
1426	                              'administrator permissions to modify or create hooks.(Citation: Login Scripts Apple '
1427	                              'Dev)(Citation: LoginWindowScripts Apple Dev) \n'
1428	                              '\n'
1429	                              'Adversaries can add or insert a path to a malicious script in the '
1430	                              '<code>com.apple.loginwindow.plist</code> file, using the <code>LoginHook</code> or '
1431	                              '<code>LogoutHook</code> key-value pair. The malicious script is executed upon the next '
1432	                              'user login. If a login hook already exists, adversaries can add additional commands to '
1433	                              'an existing login hook. There can be only one login and logout hook on a system at a '
1434	                              'time.(Citation: S1 macOs Persistence)(Citation: Wardle Persistence Chapter)\n'
1435	                              '\n'

1516	                          'environment, including authentication material passed over the network. Network sniffing '
1517	                          'refers to using the network interface on a system to monitor or capture information sent '
1518	                          'over a wired or wireless connection. An adversary may place a network interface into '
1519	                          'promiscuous mode to passively access data in transit over the network, or use span ports to '
1520	                          'capture a larger amount of data.\n'
1521	                          '\n'
1522	                          'Data captured via this technique may include user credentials, especially those sent over '
1523	                          'an insecure, unencrypted protocol. Techniques for name service resolution poisoning, such '
1524	                          'as [LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557/001), '
1525	                          'can also be used to capture credentials to websites, proxies, and internal systems by '
1526	                          'redirecting traffic to an adversary.\n'

1529	                          'numbers, and other network characteristics (e.g. IP addresses, hostnames, VLAN IDs) '
1530	                          'necessary for subsequent [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) and/or '
1531	                          '[Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0005) activities. Adversaries may '
1532	                          'likely also utilize network sniffing during '
1533	                          '[Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) (AiTM) to passively '
1534	                          'gain additional knowledge about the environment.\n'
1535	                          '\n'
1536	                          'In cloud-based environments, adversaries may still be able to use traffic mirroring '
1537	                          'services to sniff network traffic from virtual machines. For example, AWS Traffic '
1538	                          'Mirroring, GCP Packet Mirroring, and Azure vTap allow users to define specified instances '
1539	                          'to collect traffic from and specified targets to send collected traffic to.(Citation: AWS '
1540	                          'Traffic Mirroring)(Citation: GCP Packet Mirroring)(Citation: Azure Virtual Network TAP) '
1541	                          'Often, much of this traffic will be in cleartext due to the use of TLS termination at the '
1542	                          'load balancer level to reduce the strain of encrypting and decrypting traffic.(Citation: '
1543	                          'Rhino Security Labs AWS VPC Traffic Mirroring)(Citation: SpecterOps AWS Traffic Mirroring) '
1544	                          'The adversary can then use exfiltration techniques such as Transfer Data to Cloud Account '

1794	                              'Windows, Linux, and macOS for scheduling tasks at a specified time and date. Although '
1795	                              'deprecated in favor of [Scheduled '

1800	                              'group.\n'
1801	                              '\n'
1802	                              'On Linux and macOS, [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110) may be invoked by the '
1803	                              'superuser as well as any users added to the <code>at.allow</code> file. If the '
1804	                              '<code>at.allow</code> file does not exist, the <code>at.deny</code> file is checked. '
1805	                              'Every username not listed in <code>at.deny</code> is allowed to invoke '
1806	                              '[at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110). If the <code>at.deny</code> exists and '
1807	                              'is empty, global use of [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110) is permitted. If '
1808	                              'neither file exists (which is often the baseline) only the superuser is allowed to use '

1810	                              '\n'

1816	                              'Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) and/or to run a process under the '

1824	                              'allowed to run as superuser via <code>sudo</code>.(Citation: GTFObins at)',

2018	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
2019	               'description': 'Adversaries may inject malicious code into hijacked processes in order to evade '
2020	                              'process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Thread Execution '
2021	                              'Hijacking is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate '
2022	                              'live process. \n'
2023	                              '\n'
2024	                              'Thread Execution Hijacking is commonly performed by suspending an existing process then '
2025	                              'unmapping/hollowing its memory, which can then be replaced with malicious code or the '
2026	                              'path to a DLL. A handle to an existing victim process is first created with native '
2027	                              'Windows API calls such as <code>OpenThread</code>. At this point the process can be '
2028	                              'suspended then written to, realigned to the injected code, and resumed via '
2029	                              '<code>SuspendThread </code>, <code>VirtualAllocEx</code>, '
2030	                              '<code>WriteProcessMemory</code>, <code>SetThreadContext</code>, then '
2031	                              '<code>ResumeThread</code> respectively.(Citation: Elastic Process Injection July 2017)\n'
2032	                              '\n'
2033	                              'This is very similar to [Process '
2034	                              'Hollowing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/012) but targets an existing '
2035	                              'process rather than creating a process in a suspended state.  \n'
2036	                              '\n'
2037	                              "Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's "
2038	                              'memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via '
2039	                              'Thread Execution Hijacking may also evade detection from security products since the '
2040	                              'execution is masked under a legitimate process. ',

2077	                              'TLS callback injection involves manipulating pointers inside a portable executable (PE) '
2078	                              "to redirect a process to malicious code before reaching the code's legitimate entry "

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:2121
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
2120	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
2121	               'description': 'Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via the /proc filesystem in order '
2122	                              'to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Proc memory '
2123	                              'injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate '
2124	                              'live process. \n'
2125	                              '\n'
2126	                              'Proc memory injection involves enumerating the memory of a process via the /proc '
2127	                              'filesystem (<code>/proc/[pid]</code>) then crafting a return-oriented programming (ROP) '
2128	                              'payload with available gadgets/instructions. Each running process has its own '
2129	                              'directory, which includes memory mappings. Proc memory injection is commonly performed '
2130	                              'by overwriting the target processes’ stack using memory mappings provided by the /proc '
2131	                              'filesystem. This information can be used to enumerate offsets (including the stack) and '
2132	                              'gadgets (or instructions within the program that can be used to build a malicious '
2133	                              'payload) otherwise hidden by process memory protections such as address space layout '
2134	                              'randomization (ASLR). Once enumerated, the target processes’ memory map within '
2135	                              '<code>/proc/[pid]/maps</code> can be overwritten using dd.(Citation: Uninformed '
2136	                              'Needle)(Citation: GDS Linux Injection)(Citation: DD Man) \n'
2137	                              '\n'
2138	                              'Other techniques such as [Dynamic Linker '
2139	                              'Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/006) may be used to populate a '
2140	                              'target process with more available gadgets. Similar to [Process '
2141	                              'Hollowing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/012), proc memory injection may '
2142	                              'target child processes (such as a backgrounded copy of sleep).(Citation: GDS Linux '
2143	                              'Injection) \n'
2144	                              '\n'
2145	                              "Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's "
2146	                              'memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via proc '
2147	                              'memory injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is '
2148	                              'masked under a legitimate process. ',
2149	               'name': 'Proc Memory',
2150	               'platforms': ['Linux']},

2153	               'description': 'Adversaries may inject malicious code into process via Extra Window Memory (EWM) in '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:2191
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
2190	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
2191	               'description': 'Adversaries may inject malicious code into suspended and hollowed processes in order to '
2192	                              'evade process-based defenses. Process hollowing is a method of executing arbitrary code '
2193	                              'in the address space of a separate live process.  \n'
2194	                              '\n'
2195	                              'Process hollowing is commonly performed by creating a process in a suspended state then '
2196	                              'unmapping/hollowing its memory, which can then be replaced with malicious code. A '
2197	                              'victim process can be created with native Windows API calls such as '
2198	                              '<code>CreateProcess</code>, which includes a flag to suspend the processes primary '
2199	                              'thread. At this point the process can be unmapped using APIs calls such as '
2200	                              '<code>ZwUnmapViewOfSection</code> or <code>NtUnmapViewOfSection</code>  before being '
2201	                              'written to, realigned to the injected code, and resumed via '
2202	                              '<code>VirtualAllocEx</code>, <code>WriteProcessMemory</code>, '
2203	                              '<code>SetThreadContext</code>, then <code>ResumeThread</code> respectively.(Citation: '
2204	                              'Leitch Hollowing)(Citation: Elastic Process Injection July 2017)\n'
2205	                              '\n'
2206	                              'This is very similar to [Thread Local '
2207	                              'Storage](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/005) but creates a new process '
2208	                              'rather than targeting an existing process. This behavior will likely not result in '
2209	                              'elevated privileges since the injected process was spawned from (and thus inherits the '
2210	                              'security context) of the injecting process. However, execution via process hollowing '
2211	                              'may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a '
2212	                              'legitimate process. ',
2213	               'name': 'Process Hollowing',
2214	               'platforms': ['Windows']},
2215	 'T1055.013': {'attack_id': 'T1055.013',
2216	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
2217	               'description': 'Adversaries may inject malicious code into process via process doppelgänging in order '

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:2217
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
2216	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
2217	               'description': 'Adversaries may inject malicious code into process via process doppelgänging in order '
2218	                              'to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Process '
2219	                              'doppelgänging is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a '
2220	                              'separate live process. \n'
2221	                              '\n'
2222	                              'Windows Transactional NTFS (TxF) was introduced in Vista as a method to perform safe '
2223	                              'file operations. (Citation: Microsoft TxF) To ensure data integrity, TxF enables only '
2224	                              'one transacted handle to write to a file at a given time. Until the write handle '
2225	                              'transaction is terminated, all other handles are isolated from the writer and may only '
2226	                              'read the committed version of the file that existed at the time the handle was opened. '
2227	                              '(Citation: Microsoft Basic TxF Concepts) To avoid corruption, TxF performs an automatic '
2228	                              'rollback if the system or application fails during a write transaction. (Citation: '
2229	                              'Microsoft Where to use TxF)\n'
2230	                              '\n'
2231	                              'Although deprecated, the TxF application programming interface (API) is still enabled '
2232	                              'as of Windows 10. (Citation: BlackHat Process Doppelgänging Dec 2017)\n'
2233	                              '\n'
2234	                              'Adversaries may abuse TxF to a perform a file-less variation of [Process '
2235	                              'Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055). Similar to [Process '
2236	                              'Hollowing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/012), process doppelgänging '
2237	                              'involves replacing the memory of a legitimate process, enabling the veiled execution of '
2238	                              "malicious code that may evade defenses and detection. Process doppelgänging's use of "
2239	                              'TxF also avoids the use of highly-monitored API functions such as '
2240	                              '<code>NtUnmapViewOfSection</code>, <code>VirtualProtectEx</code>, and '
2241	                              '<code>SetThreadContext</code>. (Citation: BlackHat Process Doppelgänging Dec 2017)\n'
2242	                              '\n'
2243	                              'Process Doppelgänging is implemented in 4 steps (Citation: BlackHat Process '
2244	                              'Doppelgänging Dec 2017):\n'
2245	                              '\n'
2246	                              '* Transact – Create a TxF transaction using a legitimate executable then overwrite the '
2247	                              'file with malicious code. These changes will be isolated and only visible within the '
2248	                              'context of the transaction.\n'
2249	                              '* Load – Create a shared section of memory and load the malicious executable.\n'
2250	                              '* Rollback – Undo changes to original executable, effectively removing malicious code '
2251	                              'from the file system.\n'
2252	                              '* Animate – Create a process from the tainted section of memory and initiate '
2253	                              'execution.\n'
2254	                              '\n'
2255	                              'This behavior will likely not result in elevated privileges since the injected process '
2256	                              'was spawned from (and thus inherits the security context) of the injecting process. '
2257	                              'However, execution via process doppelgänging may evade detection from security products '
2258	                              'since the execution is masked under a legitimate process. ',
2259	               'name': 'Process Doppelgänging',
2260	               'platforms': ['Windows']},
2261	 'T1055.014': {'attack_id': 'T1055.014',
2262	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
2263	               'description': 'Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via VDSO hijacking in order to '

2264	                              'evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Virtual dynamic '
2265	                              'shared object (vdso) hijacking is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address '
2266	                              'space of a separate live process. \n'
2267	                              '\n'
2268	                              'VDSO hijacking involves redirecting calls to dynamically linked shared libraries. '
2269	                              'Memory protections may prevent writing executable code to a process via [Ptrace System '
2270	                              'Calls](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/008). However, an adversary may hijack '
2271	                              'the syscall interface code stubs mapped into a process from the vdso shared object to '
2272	                              'execute syscalls to open and map a malicious shared object. This code can then be '
2273	                              'invoked by redirecting the execution flow of the process via patched memory address '
2274	                              "references stored in a process' global offset table (which store absolute addresses of "
2275	                              'mapped library functions).(Citation: ELF Injection May 2009)(Citation: Backtrace '
2276	                              'VDSO)(Citation: VDSO Aug 2005)(Citation: Syscall 2014)\n'
2277	                              '\n'
2278	                              "Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's "
2279	                              'memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via VDSO '
2280	                              'hijacking may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked '
2281	                              'under a legitimate process.  ',

2285	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
2286	               'description': 'Adversaries may abuse list-view controls to inject malicious code into hijacked '
2287	                              'processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate '
2288	                              'privileges. ListPlanting is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space '
2289	                              'of a separate live process. Code executed via ListPlanting may also evade detection '
2290	                              'from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process.\n'
2291	                              '\n'
2292	                              'List-view controls are user interface windows used to display collections of '
2293	                              "items.(Citation: Microsoft List View Controls) Information about an application's "
2294	                              "list-view settings are stored within the process' memory in a "
2295	                              '<code>SysListView32</code> control.\n'
2296	                              '\n'
2297	                              'ListPlanting (a form of message-passing "shatter attack") may be performed by copying '
2298	                              'code into the virtual address space of a process that uses a list-view control then '
2299	                              'using that code as a custom callback for sorting the listed items.(Citation: Modexp '
2300	                              'Windows Process Injection) Adversaries must first copy code into the target process’ '
2301	                              'memory space, which can be performed various ways including by directly obtaining a '
2302	                              'handle to the <code>SysListView32</code> child of the victim process window (via '
2303	                              'Windows API calls such as <code>FindWindow</code> and/or <code>EnumWindows</code>) or '
2304	                              'other [Process Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055) methods.\n'
2305	                              '\n'
2306	                              'Some variations of ListPlanting may allocate memory in the target process but then use '
2307	                              'window messages to copy the payload, to avoid the use of the highly monitored '
2308	                              '<code>WriteProcessMemory</code> function. For example, an adversary can use the '
2309	                              '<code>PostMessage</code> and/or <code>SendMessage</code> API functions to send '
2310	                              '<code>LVM_SETITEMPOSITION</code> and <code>LVM_GETITEMPOSITION</code> messages, '
2311	                              'effectively copying a payload 2 bytes at a time to the allocated memory.(Citation: ESET '
2312	                              'InvisiMole June 2020) \n'
2313	                              '\n'
2314	                              'Finally, the payload is triggered by sending the <code>LVM_SORTITEMS</code> message to '
2315	                              'the <code>SysListView32</code> child of the process window, with the payload within the '
2316	                              'newly allocated buffer passed and executed as the <code>ListView_SortItems</code> '
2317	                              'callback.',
2318	               'name': 'ListPlanting',
2319	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

2504	               'description': 'Adversaries may abuse AppleScript for execution. AppleScript is a macOS scripting '
2505	                              'language designed to control applications and parts of the OS via inter-application '
2506	                              'messages called AppleEvents.(Citation: Apple AppleScript) These AppleEvent messages can '
2507	                              'be sent independently or easily scripted with AppleScript. These events can locate open '
2508	                              'windows, send keystrokes, and interact with almost any open application locally or '
2509	                              'remotely.\n'
2510	                              '\n'
2511	                              'Scripts can be run from the command-line via <code>osascript /path/to/script</code> or '
2512	                              '<code>osascript -e "script here"</code>. Aside from the command line, scripts can be '
2513	                              'executed in numerous ways including Mail rules, Calendar.app alarms, and Automator '
2514	                              'workflows. AppleScripts can also be executed as plain text shell scripts by adding '
2515	                              '<code>#!/usr/bin/osascript</code> to the start of the script file.(Citation: '
2516	                              'SentinelOne AppleScript)\n'
2517	                              '\n'
2518	                              'AppleScripts do not need to call <code>osascript</code> to execute. However, they may '
2519	                              'be executed from within mach-O binaries by using the macOS [Native '
2520	                              'API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106)s\xa0<code>NSAppleScript</code>\xa0or\xa0'
2521	                              '<code>OSAScript</code>, both of which execute code independent of the '
2522	                              '<code>/usr/bin/osascript</code> command line utility.\n'
2523	                              '\n'
2524	                              'Adversaries may abuse AppleScript to execute various behaviors, such as interacting '
2525	                              'with an open SSH connection, moving to remote machines, and even presenting users with '
2526	                              'fake dialog boxes. These events cannot start applications remotely (they can start them '
2527	                              "locally), but they can interact with applications if they're already running remotely. "
2528	                              'On macOS 10.10 Yosemite and higher, AppleScript has the ability to execute [Native '
2529	                              'API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106)s, which otherwise would require '
2530	                              'compilation and execution in a mach-O binary file format.(Citation: SentinelOne macOS '
2531	                              'Red Team) Since this is a scripting language, it can be used to launch more common '
2532	                              'techniques as well such as a reverse shell via '
2533	                              '[Python](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/006).(Citation: Macro Malware '
2534	                              'Targets Macs)',

2752	                          'Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) where appropriate.**\n'
2753	                          '\n'
2754	                          'Adversaries may use scripts to aid in operations and perform multiple actions that would '
2755	                          'otherwise be manual. Scripting is useful for speeding up operational tasks and reducing the '
2756	                          'time required to gain access to critical resources. Some scripting languages may be used to '
2757	                          'bypass process monitoring mechanisms by directly interacting with the operating system at '
2758	                          'an API level instead of calling other programs. Common scripting languages for Windows '
2759	                          'include VBScript and [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) but could also '
2760	                          'be in the form of command-line batch scripts.\n'
2761	                          '\n'
2762	                          'Scripts can be embedded inside Office documents as macros that can be set to execute when '
2763	                          'files used in [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1193) and '
2764	                          'other types of spearphishing are opened. Malicious embedded macros are an alternative means '
2765	                          'of execution than software exploitation through [Exploitation for Client '
2766	                          'Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1203), where adversaries will rely on '
2767	                          'macros being allowed or that the user will accept to activate them.\n'
2768	                          '\n'
2769	                          'Many popular offensive frameworks exist which use forms of scripting for security testers '
2770	                          'and adversaries alike. Metasploit (Citation: Metasploit_Ref), Veil (Citation: Veil_Ref), '
2771	                          'and PowerSploit (Citation: Powersploit) are three examples that are popular among '
2772	                          'penetration testers for exploit and post-compromise operations and include many features '
2773	                          'for evading defenses. Some adversaries are known to use PowerShell. (Citation: Alperovitch '
2774	                          '2014)',

2780	                          'Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a '
2781	                          'programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel '
2782	                          'itself to execute adversary-controlled code. Security constructs such as permission levels '
2783	                          'will often hinder access to information and use of certain techniques, so adversaries will '
2784	                          'likely need to perform privilege escalation to include use of software exploitation to '
2785	                          'circumvent those restrictions.\n'
2786	                          '\n'
2787	                          'When initially gaining access to a system, an adversary may be operating within a lower '
2788	                          'privileged process which will prevent them from accessing certain resources on the system. '
2789	                          'Vulnerabilities may exist, usually in operating system components and software commonly '
2790	                          'running at higher permissions, that can be exploited to gain higher levels of access on the '
2791	                          'system. This could enable someone to move from unprivileged or user level permissions to '
2792	                          'SYSTEM or root permissions depending on the component that is vulnerable. This could also '
2793	                          'enable an adversary to move from a virtualized environment, such as within a virtual '
2794	                          'machine or container, onto the underlying host. This may be a necessary step for an '
2795	                          'adversary compromising an endpoint system that has been properly configured and limits '
2796	                          'other privilege escalation methods.\n'
