7390	           'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
7391	           'description': 'Adversaries may use execution guardrails to constrain execution or actions based on '
7392	                          'adversary supplied and environment specific conditions that are expected to be present on '
7393	                          'the target. Guardrails ensure that a payload only executes against an intended target and '
7394	                          'reduces collateral damage from an adversary’s campaign.(Citation: FireEye Kevin Mandia '
7395	                          'Guardrails) Values an adversary can provide about a target system or environment to use as '
7396	                          'guardrails may include specific network share names, attached physical devices, files, '
7397	                          'joined Active Directory (AD) domains, and local/external IP addresses.(Citation: FireEye '
7398	                          'Outlook Dec 2019)\n'
7399	                          '\n'
7400	                          'Guardrails can be used to prevent exposure of capabilities in environments that are not '
7401	                          'intended to be compromised or operated within. This use of guardrails is distinct from '
7402	                          'typical [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497). While '
7403	                          'use of [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497) may '
7404	                          'involve checking for known sandbox values and continuing with execution only if there is no '
7405	                          'match, the use of guardrails will involve checking for an expected target-specific value '
7406	                          'and only continuing with execution if there is such a match.',
7407	           'name': 'Execution Guardrails',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:7411
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
7410	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
7411	               'description': 'Adversaries may environmentally key payloads or other features of malware to evade '
7412	                              'defenses and constraint execution to a specific target environment. Environmental '
7413	                              'keying uses cryptography to constrain execution or actions based on adversary supplied '
7414	                              'environment specific conditions that are expected to be present on the target. '
7415	                              'Environmental keying is an implementation of [Execution '
7416	                              'Guardrails](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1480) that utilizes cryptographic '
7417	                              'techniques for deriving encryption/decryption keys from specific types of values in a '
7418	                              'given computing environment.(Citation: EK Clueless Agents)\n'
7419	                              '\n'
7420	                              'Values can be derived from target-specific elements and used to generate a decryption '
7421	                              'key for an encrypted payload. Target-specific values can be derived from specific '
7422	                              'network shares, physical devices, software/software versions, files, joined AD domains, '
7423	                              'system time, and local/external IP addresses.(Citation: Kaspersky Gauss '
7424	                              'Whitepaper)(Citation: Proofpoint Router Malvertising)(Citation: EK Impeding Malware '
7425	                              'Analysis)(Citation: Environmental Keyed HTA)(Citation: Ebowla: Genetic Malware) By '
7426	                              'generating the decryption keys from target-specific environmental values, environmental '
7427	                              'keying can make sandbox detection, anti-virus detection, crowdsourcing of information, '
7428	                              'and reverse engineering difficult.(Citation: Kaspersky Gauss Whitepaper)(Citation: '
7429	                              'Ebowla: Genetic Malware) These difficulties can slow down the incident response process '
7430	                              'and help adversaries hide their tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).\n'
7431	                              '\n'
7432	                              'Similar to [Obfuscated Files or '
7433	                              'Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027), adversaries may use '
7434	                              'environmental keying to help protect their TTPs and evade detection. Environmental '
7435	                              'keying may be used to deliver an encrypted payload to the target that will use '
7436	                              'target-specific values to decrypt the payload before execution.(Citation: Kaspersky '
7437	                              'Gauss Whitepaper)(Citation: EK Impeding Malware Analysis)(Citation: Environmental Keyed '
7438	                              'HTA)(Citation: Ebowla: Genetic Malware)(Citation: Demiguise Guardrail Router Logo) By '
7439	                              'utilizing target-specific values to decrypt the payload the adversary can avoid '
7440	                              'packaging the decryption key with the payload or sending it over a potentially '
7441	                              'monitored network connection. Depending on the technique for gathering target-specific '
7442	                              'values, reverse engineering of the encrypted payload can be exceptionally '
7443	                              'difficult.(Citation: Kaspersky Gauss Whitepaper) This can be used to prevent exposure '
7444	                              'of capabilities in environments that are not intended to be compromised or operated '
7445	                              'within.\n'
7446	                              '\n'
7447	                              'Like other [Execution Guardrails](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1480), '
7448	                              'environmental keying can be used to prevent exposure of capabilities in environments '
7449	                              'that are not intended to be compromised or operated within. This activity is distinct '
7450	                              'from typical [Virtualization/Sandbox '
7451	                              'Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497). While use of '
7452	                              '[Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497) may involve '
7453	                              'checking for known sandbox values and continuing with execution only if there is no '
7454	                              'match, the use of environmental keying will involve checking for an expected '
7455	                              'target-specific value that must match for decryption and subsequent execution to be '
7456	                              'successful.',
7457	               'name': 'Environmental Keying',
7458	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:7598

7597	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
7598	               'description': 'Adversaries may modify Group Policy Objects (GPOs) to subvert the intended '
7599	                              'discretionary access controls for a domain, usually with the intention of escalating '
7600	                              'privileges on the domain. Group policy allows for centralized management of user and '
7601	                              'computer settings in Active Directory (AD). GPOs are containers for group policy '
7602	                              'settings made up of files stored within a predictable network path '
7603	                              '`\\<DOMAIN>\\SYSVOL\\<DOMAIN>\\Policies\\`.(Citation: TechNet Group Policy '
7604	                              'Basics)(Citation: ADSecurity GPO Persistence 2016) \n'
7605	                              '\n'
7606	                              'Like other objects in AD, GPOs have access controls associated with them. By default '
7607	                              'all user accounts in the domain have permission to read GPOs. It is possible to '
7608	                              'delegate GPO access control permissions, e.g. write access, to specific users or groups '
7609	                              'in the domain.\n'
7610	                              '\n'
7611	                              'Malicious GPO modifications can be used to implement many other malicious behaviors '
7612	                              'such as [Scheduled Task/Job](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053), [Disable or '
7613	                              'Modify Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/001), [Ingress Tool '
7614	                              'Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105), [Create '
7615	                              'Account](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1136), [Service '
7616	                              'Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1569/002),  and more.(Citation: '
7617	                              'ADSecurity GPO Persistence 2016)(Citation: Wald0 Guide to GPOs)(Citation: Harmj0y '
7618	                              'Abusing GPO Permissions)(Citation: Mandiant M Trends 2016)(Citation: Microsoft Hacking '
7619	                              'Team Breach) Since GPOs can control so many user and machine settings in the AD '
7620	                              'environment, there are a great number of potential attacks that can stem from this GPO '
7621	                              'abuse.(Citation: Wald0 Guide to GPOs)\n'
7622	                              '\n'
7623	                              'For example, publicly available scripts such as <code>New-GPOImmediateTask</code> can '
7624	                              'be leveraged to automate the creation of a malicious [Scheduled '
7625	                              'Task/Job](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053) by modifying GPO settings, in this '
7626	                              'case modifying '
7627	                              '<code>&lt;GPO_PATH&gt;\\Machine\\Preferences\\ScheduledTasks\\ScheduledTasks.xml</code>.(Citation: '
7628	                              'Wald0 Guide to GPOs)(Citation: Harmj0y Abusing GPO Permissions) In some cases an '
7629	                              'adversary might modify specific user rights like SeEnableDelegationPrivilege, set in '
7630	                              '<code>&lt;GPO_PATH&gt;\\MACHINE\\Microsoft\\Windows NT\\SecEdit\\GptTmpl.inf</code>, to '
7631	                              'achieve a subtle AD backdoor with complete control of the domain because the user '
7632	                              "account under the adversary's control would then be able to modify GPOs.(Citation: "
7633	                              'Harmj0y SeEnableDelegationPrivilege Right)',
7634	               'name': 'Group Policy Modification',

7653	                              'domain to a federated domain using Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS), which '
7654	                              'may enable malicious trust modifications such as altering the claim issuance rules to '

7667	                          'likely to render stored data irrecoverable by forensic techniques through overwriting files '
7668	                          'or data on local and remote drives.(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye '
7669	                          'Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill '
7670	                          '2017)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer 2018) Common '
7671	                          'operating system file deletion commands such as <code>del</code> and <code>rm</code> often '
7672	                          'only remove pointers to files without wiping the contents of the files themselves, making '
7673	                          'the files recoverable by proper forensic methodology. This behavior is distinct from [Disk '
7674	                          'Content Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/001) and [Disk Structure '
7675	                          'Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/002) because individual files are destroyed '
7676	                          "rather than sections of a storage disk or the disk's logical structure.\n"

7687	                          'Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential '

7701	           'description': 'Adversaries may encrypt data on target systems or on large numbers of systems in a network '
7702	                          'to interrupt availability to system and network resources. They can attempt to render '
7703	                          'stored data inaccessible by encrypting files or data on local and remote drives and '
7704	                          'withholding access to a decryption key. This may be done in order to extract monetary '
7705	                          'compensation from a victim in exchange for decryption or a decryption key (ransomware) or '
7706	                          'to render data permanently inaccessible in cases where the key is not saved or '
7707	                          'transmitted.(Citation: US-CERT Ransomware 2016)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)(Citation: '
7708	                          'US-CERT NotPetya 2017)(Citation: US-CERT SamSam 2018)\n'
7709	                          '\n'
7710	                          'In the case of ransomware, it is typical that common user files like Office documents, '
7711	                          'PDFs, images, videos, audio, text, and source code files will be encrypted (and often '
7712	                          'renamed and/or tagged with specific file markers). Adversaries may need to first employ '
7713	                          'other behaviors, such as [File and Directory Permissions '
7714	                          'Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1222) or [System '
7715	                          'Shutdown/Reboot](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1529), in order to unlock and/or gain '
7716	                          'access to manipulate these files.(Citation: CarbonBlack Conti July 2020) In some cases, '
7717	                          'adversaries may encrypt critical system files, disk partitions, and the MBR.(Citation: '
7718	                          'US-CERT NotPetya 2017) \n'
7719	                          '\n'
7720	                          'To maximize impact on the target organization, malware designed for encrypting data may '
7721	                          'have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging other attack techniques '
7722	                          'like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential '
7723	                          'Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin '
7724	                          'Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: FireEye WannaCry '
7725	                          '2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017) Encryption malware may also leverage [Internal '
7726	                          'Defacement](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1491/001), such as changing victim '
7727	                          'wallpapers, or otherwise intimidate victims by sending ransom notes or other messages to '
7728	                          'connected printers (known as "print bombing").(Citation: NHS Digital Egregor Nov 2020)\n'
7729	                          '\n'
7730	                          'In cloud environments, storage objects within compromised accounts may also be '
7731	                          'encrypted.(Citation: Rhino S3 Ransomware Part 1)',
7732	           'name': 'Data Encrypted for Impact',
7733	           'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows', 'IaaS']},

7753	           'categories': ['impact'],
7754	           'description': 'Adversaries may delete or remove built-in data and turn off services designed to aid in the '
7755	                          'recovery of a corrupted system to prevent recovery.(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer '
7756	                          '2018)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017) This may deny access to available backups and '
7757	                          'recovery options.\n'
7758	                          '\n'
7759	                          'Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a '
7760	                          'backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may '
7761	                          'disable or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of [Data '
7762	                          'Destruction](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485) and [Data Encrypted for '
7763	                          'Impact](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486).(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer '
7764	                          '2018)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017) Furthermore, adversaries may disable recovery '
7765	                          'notifications, then corrupt backups.(Citation: disable_notif_synology_ransom)\n'
7766	                          '\n'
7767	                          'A number of native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete '
7768	                          'system recovery features:\n'
7769	                          '\n'
7770	                          '* <code>vssadmin.exe</code> can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system - '
7771	                          '<code>vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet</code>\n'
7772	                          '* [Windows Management Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047) can be '
7773	                          'used to delete volume shadow copies - <code>wmic shadowcopy delete</code>\n'
7774	                          '* <code>wbadmin.exe</code> can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog - '
7775	                          '<code>wbadmin.exe delete catalog -quiet</code>\n'
7776	                          '* <code>bcdedit.exe</code> can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by '
7777	                          'modifying boot configuration data - <code>bcdedit.exe /set {default} bootstatuspolicy '
7778	                          'ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set {default} recoveryenabled no</code>\n'
7779	                          '* <code>REAgentC.exe</code> can be used to disable Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE) '
7780	                          'repair/recovery options of an infected system\n'
7781	                          '* <code>diskshadow.exe</code> can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system - '
7782	                          '<code>diskshadow delete shadows all</code> (Citation: Diskshadow) (Citation: Crytox '
7783	                          'Ransomware)\n'
7784	                          '\n'
7785	                          'On network devices, adversaries may leverage [Disk '
7786	                          'Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561) to delete backup firmware images and '
7787	                          'reformat the file system, then [System '
7788	                          'Shutdown/Reboot](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1529) to reload the device. Together '
7789	                          'this activity may leave network devices completely inoperable and inhibit recovery '
7790	                          'operations.\n'
7791	                          '\n'
7792	                          'Adversaries may also delete “online” backups that are connected to their network – whether '
7793	                          'via network storage media or through folders that sync to cloud services.(Citation: ZDNet '
7794	                          'Ransomware Backups 2020) In cloud environments, adversaries may disable versioning and '
7795	                          'backup policies and delete snapshots, machine images, and prior versions of objects '
7796	                          'designed to be used in disaster recovery scenarios.(Citation: Dark Reading Code Spaces '
7797	                          'Cyber Attack)(Citation: Rhino Security Labs AWS S3 Ransomware)',
7798	           'name': 'Inhibit System Recovery',

7870	                          'mining.(Citation: CloudSploit - Unused AWS Regions) Containerized environments may also be '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:7911
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
7910	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'discovery'],
7911	               'description': 'Adversaries may employ various system checks to detect and avoid virtualization and '
7912	                              'analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of '
7913	                              'checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) '
7914	                              'or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage '
7915	                              'from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for '
7916	                              'VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the '
7917	                              'information learned from [Virtualization/Sandbox '
7918	                              'Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497) during automated discovery to shape '
7919	                              'follow-on behaviors.(Citation: Deloitte Environment Awareness)\n'
7920	                              '\n'
7921	                              'Specific checks will vary based on the target and/or adversary, but may involve '
7922	                              'behaviors such as [Windows Management '
7923	                              'Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047), '
7924	                              '[PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001), [System Information '
7925	                              'Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082), and [Query '
7926	                              'Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1012) to obtain system information and '
7927	                              'search for VME artifacts. Adversaries may search for VME artifacts in memory, '
7928	                              'processes, file system, hardware, and/or the Registry. Adversaries may use scripting to '
7929	                              'automate these checks  into one script and then have the program exit if it determines '
7930	                              'the system to be a virtual environment. \n'
7931	                              '\n'
7932	                              'Checks could include generic system properties such as host/domain name and samples of '
7933	                              'network traffic. Adversaries may also check the network adapters addresses, CPU core '
7934	                              'count, and available memory/drive size. Once executed, malware may also use [File and '
7935	                              'Directory Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083) to check if it was '
7936	                              'saved in a folder or file with unexpected or even analysis-related naming artifacts '
7937	                              'such as `malware`, `sample`, or `hash`.\n'
7938	                              '\n'
7939	                              'Other common checks may enumerate services running that are unique to these '
7940	                              'applications, installed programs on the system, manufacturer/product fields for strings '
7941	                              'relating to virtual machine applications, and VME-specific hardware/processor '
7942	                              'instructions.(Citation: McAfee Virtual Jan 2017) In applications like VMWare, '
7943	                              'adversaries can also use a special I/O port to send commands and receive output. \n'
7944	                              ' \n'
7945	                              'Hardware checks, such as the presence of the fan, temperature, and audio devices, could '
7946	                              'also be used to gather evidence that can be indicative a virtual environment. '
7947	                              'Adversaries may also query for specific readings from these devices.(Citation: Unit 42 '
7948	                              'OilRig Sept 2018)',
7949	               'name': 'System Checks',
7950	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows']},

7979	                              '\n'
7980	                              'Adversaries may employ various time-based evasions, such as delaying malware '
7981	                              'functionality upon initial execution using programmatic sleep commands or native system '
7982	                              'scheduling functionality (ex: [Scheduled '
7983	                              'Task/Job](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053)). Delays may also be based on '
7984	                              'waiting for specific victim conditions to be met (ex: system time, events, etc.) or '
7985	                              'employ scheduled [Multi-Stage Channels](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1104) to '
7986	                              'avoid analysis and scrutiny.(Citation: Deloitte Environment Awareness)\n'
7987	                              '\n'
7988	                              'Benign commands or other operations may also be used to delay malware execution. Loops '
7989	                              'or otherwise needless repetitions of commands, such as '
7990	                              '[Ping](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0097)s, may be used to delay malware '
7991	                              'execution and potentially exceed time thresholds of automated analysis '
7992	                              'environments.(Citation: Revil Independence Day)(Citation: Netskope Nitol) Another '
7993	                              'variation, commonly referred to as API hammering, involves making various calls to '
7994	                              '[Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) functions in order to delay '
7995	                              'execution (while also potentially overloading analysis environments with junk '
7996	                              'data).(Citation: Joe Sec Nymaim)(Citation: Joe Sec Trickbot)\n'
7997	                              '\n'
7998	                              'Adversaries may also use time as a metric to detect sandboxes and analysis '
7999	                              'environments, particularly those that attempt to manipulate time mechanisms to simulate '
8000	                              'longer elapses of time. For example, an adversary may be able to identify a sandbox '
8001	                              "accelerating time by sampling and calculating the expected value for an environment's "
8002	                              'timestamp before and after execution of a sleep function.(Citation: ISACA Malware '
8003	                              'Tricks)',
8004	               'name': 'Time Based Evasion',
8005	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows']},

8007	           'categories': ['impact'],
8008	           'description': 'Adversaries may perform Network Denial of Service (DoS) attacks to degrade or block the '
8009	                          'availability of targeted resources to users. Network DoS can be performed by exhausting the '
8010	                          'network bandwidth services rely on. Example resources include specific websites, email '
8011	                          'services, DNS, and web-based applications. Adversaries have been observed conducting '
8012	                          'network DoS attacks for political purposes(Citation: FireEye OpPoisonedHandover February '
8013	                          '2016) and to support other malicious activities, including distraction(Citation: FSISAC '
8014	                          'FraudNetDoS September 2012), hacktivism, and extortion.(Citation: Symantec DDoS October '
8015	                          '2014)\n'
8016	                          '\n'
8017	                          'A Network DoS will occur when the bandwidth capacity of the network connection to a system '
8018	                          'is exhausted due to the volume of malicious traffic directed at the resource or the network '
8019	                          'connections and network devices the resource relies on. For example, an adversary may send '
8020	                          '10Gbps of traffic to a server that is hosted by a network with a 1Gbps connection to the '
8021	                          'internet. This traffic can be generated by a single system or multiple systems spread '
8022	                          'across the internet, which is commonly referred to as a distributed DoS (DDoS).\n'
8023	                          '\n'
8024	                          'To perform Network DoS attacks several aspects apply to multiple methods, including IP '
8025	                          'address spoofing, and botnets.\n'
8026	                          '\n'
8027	                          'Adversaries may use the original IP address of an attacking system, or spoof the source IP '
8028	                          'address to make the attack traffic more difficult to trace back to the attacking system or '
8029	                          'to enable reflection. This can increase the difficulty defenders have in defending against '
8030	                          'the attack by reducing or eliminating the effectiveness of filtering by the source address '
8031	                          'on network defense devices.\n'
8032	                          '\n'
8033	                          'For DoS attacks targeting the hosting system directly, see [Endpoint Denial of '
8034	                          'Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499).',

8049	                              'availability and functionality of the targeted system(s) and network. [Direct Network '
8050	                              'Flood](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1498/001)s are when one or more systems are '
8051	                              "used to send a high-volume of network packets towards the targeted service's network. "
8052	                              'Almost any network protocol may be used for flooding. Stateless protocols such as UDP '
8053	                              'or ICMP are commonly used but stateful protocols such as TCP can be used as well.\n'
8054	                              '\n'
8055	                              'Botnets are commonly used to conduct network flooding attacks against networks and '
8056	                              'services. Large botnets can generate a significant amount of traffic from systems '
8057	                              'spread across the global Internet. Adversaries may have the resources to build out and '
8058	                              'control their own botnet infrastructure or may rent time on an existing botnet to '
8059	                              'conduct an attack. In some of the worst cases for distributed DoS (DDoS), so many '
8060	                              'systems are used to generate the flood that each one only needs to send out a small '
8061	                              'amount of traffic to produce enough volume to saturate the target network. In such '
8062	                              'circumstances, distinguishing DDoS traffic from legitimate clients becomes exceedingly '
8063	                              'difficult. Botnets have been used in some of the most high-profile DDoS flooding '
8064	                              'attacks, such as the 2012 series of incidents that targeted major US banks.(Citation: '
8065	                              'USNYAG IranianBotnet March 2016)',

8110	           'categories': ['impact'],
8111	           'description': 'Adversaries may perform Endpoint Denial of Service (DoS) attacks to degrade or block the '
8112	                          'availability of services to users. Endpoint DoS can be performed by exhausting the system '
8113	                          'resources those services are hosted on or exploiting the system to cause a persistent crash '
8114	                          'condition. Example services include websites, email services, DNS, and web-based '
8115	                          'applications. Adversaries have been observed conducting DoS attacks for political '
8116	                          'purposes(Citation: FireEye OpPoisonedHandover February 2016) and to support other malicious '
8117	                          'activities, including distraction(Citation: FSISAC FraudNetDoS September 2012), hacktivism, '
8118	                          'and extortion.(Citation: Symantec DDoS October 2014)\n'
8119	                          '\n'
8120	                          'An Endpoint DoS denies the availability of a service without saturating the network used to '
8121	                          'provide access to the service. Adversaries can target various layers of the application '
8122	                          'stack that is hosted on the system used to provide the service. These layers include the '
8123	                          'Operating Systems (OS), server applications such as web servers, DNS servers, databases, '
8124	                          'and the (typically web-based) applications that sit on top of them. Attacking each layer '
8125	                          'requires different techniques that take advantage of bottlenecks that are unique to the '
8126	                          'respective components. A DoS attack may be generated by a single system or multiple systems '
8127	                          'spread across the internet, which is commonly referred to as a distributed DoS (DDoS).\n'
8128	                          '\n'
8129	                          'To perform DoS attacks against endpoint resources, several aspects apply to multiple '
8130	                          'methods, including IP address spoofing and botnets.\n'
8131	                          '\n'
8132	                          'Adversaries may use the original IP address of an attacking system, or spoof the source IP '
8133	                          'address to make the attack traffic more difficult to trace back to the attacking system or '
8134	                          'to enable reflection. This can increase the difficulty defenders have in defending against '
8135	                          'the attack by reducing or eliminating the effectiveness of filtering by the source address '
8136	                          'on network defense devices.\n'
8137	                          '\n'
8138	                          'Botnets are commonly used to conduct DDoS attacks against networks and services. Large '
8139	                          'botnets can generate a significant amount of traffic from systems spread across the global '
8140	                          'internet. Adversaries may have the resources to build out and control their own botnet '
8141	                          'infrastructure or may rent time on an existing botnet to conduct an attack. In some of the '
8142	                          'worst cases for DDoS, so many systems are used to generate requests that each one only '
8143	                          'needs to send out a small amount of traffic to produce enough volume to exhaust the '
8144	                          "target's resources. In such circumstances, distinguishing DDoS traffic from legitimate "
8145	                          'clients becomes exceedingly difficult. Botnets have been used in some of the most '
8146	                          'high-profile DDoS attacks, such as the 2012 series of incidents that targeted major US '
8147	                          'banks.(Citation: USNYAG IranianBotnet March 2016)\n'
8148	                          '\n'
8149	                          'In cases where traffic manipulation is used, there may be points in the global network '
8150	                          '(such as high traffic gateway routers) where packets can be altered and cause legitimate '
8151	                          'clients to execute code that directs network packets toward a target in high volume. This '
8152	                          'type of capability was previously used for the purposes of web censorship where client HTTP '
8153	                          'traffic was modified to include a reference to JavaScript that generated the DDoS code to '
8154	                          'overwhelm target web servers.(Citation: ArsTechnica Great Firewall of China)\n'
8155	                          '\n'
8156	                          'For attacks attempting to saturate the providing network, see [Network Denial of '
8157	                          'Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1498).\n',

8505	                              'is looking for. It is becoming more common to see macOS malware perform checks for '
8506	                              'LittleSnitch and KnockKnock software.\n'

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:8535
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
8534	               'categories': ['command-and-control'],
8535	               'description': 'Adversaries may employ a known asymmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and '
8536	                              'control traffic, rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a '
8537	                              'communication protocol. Asymmetric cryptography, also known as public key cryptography, '
8538	                              'uses a keypair per party: one public that can be freely distributed, and one private '
8539	                              'that should not be distributed. Due to how asymmetric algorithms work, the sender '
8540	                              'encrypts data with the receiver’s public key and the receiver decrypts the data with '
8541	                              'their private key. This ensures that only the intended recipient can read the encrypted '
8542	                              'data. Common public key encryption algorithms include RSA, ElGamal, and ECDSA.\n'
8543	                              '\n'
8544	                              'For efficiency, many protocols (including SSL/TLS) use symmetric cryptography once a '
8545	                              'connection is established, but use asymmetric cryptography to establish or transmit a '
8546	                              'key. As such, these protocols are classified as [Asymmetric '
8547	                              'Cryptography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1521/002).',
8548	               'name': 'Asymmetric Cryptography',
8549	               'platforms': ['Android', 'iOS']},
8550	 'T1521.003': {'attack_id': 'T1521.003',
8551	               'categories': ['command-and-control'],
8552	               'description': 'Adversaries may use [SSL Pinning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1521/003)  to '

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:8552
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
8551	               'categories': ['command-and-control'],
8552	               'description': 'Adversaries may use [SSL Pinning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1521/003)  to '
8553	                              'protect the C2 traffic from being intercepted and analyzed.\n'
8554	                              '\n'
8555	                              '[SSL Pinning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1521/003)  is a technique commonly '
8556	                              'utilized by legitimate websites to ensure that encrypted communications are only '
8557	                              'allowed with a pre-defined certificate. If another certificate is presented, it could '
8558	                              'indicate device compromise, traffic interception, or another upstream issue. While '
8559	                              'benign usages are common, it is also possible for adversaries to abuse this technology '
8560	                              'to protect malicious C2 traffic.\n'
8561	                              '\n'
8562	                              'In normal, not pinned SSL validation, when a client connects to a server using HTTPS, '
8563	                              'it typically checks whether the server’s SSL/TLS certificate is signed by a trusted '
8564	                              'Certificate Authority (CA) in the device’s trust store. If the certificate is valid and '
8565	                              'signed by a trusted CA, the connection is established. However, with [SSL '
8566	                              'Pinning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1521/003) , the client is configured to '
8567	                              'trust a specific SSL/TLS certificate or public key, rather than relying on the device’s '
8568	                              'trust store. This means that even if the server’s certificate is signed by a trusted '
8569	                              'CA, the client will only establish the connection of the certificate or key is pinned.\n'
8570	                              '\n'
8571	                              'There are two types of [SSL Pinning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1521/003) :\n'
8572	                              '\n'
8573	                              '1.\tCertificate Pinning: The client stores a copy of the server’s certificate and '
8574	                              'compares it with the certificate received during the SSL handshake. If the certificates '
8575	                              'match, then the client proceeds with the connection. This approach also works with '
8576	                              'self-signed certificates.\n'
8577	                              '\n'
8578	                              '2.\tPublic Key Pinning: Instead of pinning the entire certificate, the client pins just '
8579	                              'the public key extracted from the certificate. This is often more flexible, as it '
8580	                              'allows the server to renew its certificate without having to update the pinned '
8581	                              'certificate or breaking the SSL connection.',
8582	               'name': 'SSL Pinning',
8583	               'platforms': ['Android', 'iOS']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:8633

8632	           'categories': ['credential-access'],
8633	           'description': 'Adversaries can steal application access tokens as a means of acquiring credentials to '
8634	                          'access remote systems and resources.\n'
8635	                          '\n'
8636	                          'Application access tokens are used to make authorized API requests on behalf of a user or '
8637	                          'service and are commonly used as a way to access resources in cloud and container-based '
8638	                          'applications and software-as-a-service (SaaS).(Citation: Auth0 - Why You Should Always Use '
8639	                          'Access Tokens to Secure APIs Sept 2019)  Adversaries who steal account API tokens in cloud '
8640	                          'and containerized environments may be able to access data and perform actions with the '
8641	                          'permissions of these accounts, which can lead to privilege escalation and further '
8642	                          'compromise of the environment.\n'
8643	                          '\n'
8644	                          'For example, in Kubernetes environments, processes running inside a container may '
8645	                          'communicate with the Kubernetes API server using service account tokens. If a container is '
8646	                          'compromised, an adversary may be able to steal the container’s token and thereby gain '
8647	                          'access to Kubernetes API commands.(Citation: Kubernetes Service Accounts)  Similarly, '
8648	                          'instances within continuous-development / continuous-integration (CI/CD) pipelines will '
8649	                          'often use API tokens to authenticate to other services for testing and '
8650	                          'deployment.(Citation: Cider Security Top 10 CICD Security Risks) If these pipelines are '
8651	                          'compromised, adversaries may be able to steal these tokens and leverage their privileges.\n'
8652	                          '\n'
8653	                          'Token theft can also occur through social engineering, in which case user action may be '
8654	                          'required to grant access. OAuth is one commonly implemented framework that issues tokens to '
8655	                          'users for access to systems. An application desiring access to cloud-based services or '
8656	                          'protected APIs can gain entry using OAuth 2.0 through a variety of authorization protocols. '
8657	                          "An example commonly-used sequence is Microsoft's Authorization Code Grant flow.(Citation: "
8658	                          'Microsoft Identity Platform Protocols May 2019)(Citation: Microsoft - OAuth Code '
8659	                          'Authorization flow - June 2019) An OAuth access token enables a third-party application to '
8660	                          'interact with resources containing user data in the ways requested by the application '
8661	                          'without obtaining user credentials. \n'
8662	                          ' \n'
8663	                          'Adversaries can leverage OAuth authorization by constructing a malicious application '
8664	                          "designed to be granted access to resources with the target user's OAuth token.(Citation: "
8665	                          'Amnesty OAuth Phishing Attacks, August 2019)(Citation: Trend Micro Pawn Storm OAuth 2017) '
8666	                          'The adversary will need to complete registration of their application with the '
8667	                          'authorization server, for example Microsoft Identity Platform using Azure Portal, the '
8668	                          'Visual Studio IDE, the command-line interface, PowerShell, or REST API calls.(Citation: '
8669	                          'Microsoft - Azure AD App Registration - May 2019) Then, they can send a [Spearphishing '
8670	                          'Link](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/002) to the target user to entice them to '
8671	                          'grant access to the application. Once the OAuth access token is granted, the application '
8672	                          'can gain potentially long-term access to features of the user account through [Application '
8673	                          'Access Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/001).(Citation: Microsoft - Azure '
8674	                          'AD Identity Tokens - Aug 2019)\n'
8675	                          '\n'
8676	                          'Application access tokens may function within a limited lifetime, limiting how long an '
8677	                          'adversary can utilize the stolen token. However, in some cases, adversaries can also steal '
8678	                          'application refresh tokens(Citation: Auth0 Understanding Refresh Tokens), allowing them to '
8679	                          'obtain new access tokens without prompting the user.  \n'
8680	                          '\n',
8681	           'name': 'Steal Application Access Token',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:8815

8814	           'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
8815	           'description': 'Adversaries may create cloud instances in unused geographic service regions in order to '
8816	                          'evade detection. Access is usually obtained through compromising accounts used to manage '
8817	                          'cloud infrastructure.\n'
8818	                          '\n'
8819	                          'Cloud service providers often provide infrastructure throughout the world in order to '
8820	                          'improve performance, provide redundancy, and allow customers to meet compliance '
8821	                          'requirements. Oftentimes, a customer will only use a subset of the available regions and '
8822	                          'may not actively monitor other regions. If an adversary creates resources in an unused '
8823	                          'region, they may be able to operate undetected.\n'

9107	                              'applications called services that perform background system functions.(Citation: '
9108	                              'TechNet Services) Windows service configuration information, including the file path to '
9109	                              "the service's executable or recovery programs/commands, is stored in the Windows "
9110	                              'Registry.\n'
9111	                              '\n'
9112	                              'Adversaries may install a new service or modify an existing service to execute at '
9113	                              'startup in order to persist on a system. Service configurations can be set or modified '

9115	                              'interacting directly with the Windows API. \n'

9119	                              'and registered via [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) functions '

9121	                              '`ZwSetValueKey()`), by creating the required service Registry values (i.e. [Modify '
9122	                              'Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112)), or by using command-line '

9149	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation'],
9150	               'description': 'Adversaries may create or modify Launch Daemons to execute malicious payloads as part '
9151	                              'of persistence. Launch Daemons are plist files used to interact with Launchd, the '
9152	                              'service management framework used by macOS. Launch Daemons require elevated privileges '
9153	                              'to install, are executed for every user on a system prior to login, and run in the '
9154	                              'background without the need for user interaction. During the macOS initialization '
9155	                              'startup, the launchd process loads the parameters for launch-on-demand system-level '
9156	                              'daemons from plist files found in <code>/System/Library/LaunchDaemons/</code> and '
9157	                              '<code>/Library/LaunchDaemons/</code>. Required Launch Daemons parameters include a '
9158	                              '<code>Label</code> to identify the task, <code>Program</code> to provide a path to the '
9159	                              'executable, and <code>RunAtLoad</code> to specify when the task is run. Launch Daemons '
9160	                              'are often used to provide access to shared resources, updates to software, or conduct '
9161	                              'automation tasks.(Citation: AppleDocs Launch Agent Daemons)(Citation: Methods of Mac '
9162	                              'Malware Persistence)(Citation: launchd Keywords for plists)\n'
9163	                              '\n'
9164	                              'Adversaries may install a Launch Daemon configured to execute at startup by using the '
9165	                              '<code>RunAtLoad</code> parameter set to <code>true</code> and the <code>Program</code> '
9166	                              'parameter set to the malicious executable path. The daemon name may be disguised by '
9167	                              'using a name from a related operating system or benign software (i.e. '
9168	                              '[Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036)). When the Launch Daemon is '
9169	                              'executed, the program inherits administrative permissions.(Citation: '
9170	                              'WireLurker)(Citation: OSX Malware Detection)\n'
9171	                              '\n'
9172	                              'Additionally, system configuration changes (such as the installation of third party '
9173	                              'package managing software) may cause folders such as <code>usr/local/bin</code> to '
9174	                              'become globally writeable. So, it is possible for poor configurations to allow an '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:9307
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
9306	               'categories': ['privilege-escalation', 'persistence'],
9307	               'description': 'Adversaries may establish persistence through executing malicious commands triggered by '
9308	                              'a user’s shell. User [Unix Shell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/004)s '
9309	                              'execute several configuration scripts at different points throughout the session based '
9310	                              'on events. For example, when a user opens a command-line interface or remotely logs in '
9311	                              '(such as via SSH) a login shell is initiated. The login shell executes scripts from the '
9312	                              'system (<code>/etc</code>) and the user’s home directory (<code>~/</code>) to configure '
9313	                              'the environment. All login shells on a system use /etc/profile when initiated. These '
9314	                              'configuration scripts run at the permission level of their directory and are often used '
9315	                              'to set environment variables, create aliases, and customize the user’s environment. '
9316	                              'When the shell exits or terminates, additional shell scripts are executed to ensure the '
9317	                              'shell exits appropriately. \n'
9318	                              '\n'
9319	                              'Adversaries may attempt to establish persistence by inserting commands into scripts '
9320	                              'automatically executed by shells. Using bash as an example, the default shell for most '
9321	                              'GNU/Linux systems, adversaries may add commands that launch malicious binaries into the '
9322	                              '<code>/etc/profile</code> and <code>/etc/profile.d</code> files.(Citation: '
9323	                              'intezer-kaiji-malware)(Citation: bencane blog bashrc) These files typically require '
9324	                              'root permissions to modify and are executed each time any shell on a system launches. '
9325	                              'For user level permissions, adversaries can insert malicious commands into '
9326	                              '<code>~/.bash_profile</code>, <code>~/.bash_login</code>, or <code>~/.profile</code> '
9327	                              'which are sourced when a user opens a command-line interface or connects '
9328	                              'remotely.(Citation: anomali-rocke-tactics)(Citation: Linux manual bash invocation) '
9329	                              'Since the system only executes the first existing file in the listed order, adversaries '
9330	                              'have used <code>~/.bash_profile</code> to ensure execution. Adversaries have also '
9331	                              'leveraged the <code>~/.bashrc</code> file which is additionally executed if the '
9332	                              'connection is established remotely or an additional interactive shell is opened, such '
9333	                              'as a new tab in the command-line interface.(Citation: Tsunami)(Citation: '
9334	                              'anomali-rocke-tactics)(Citation: anomali-linux-rabbit)(Citation: Magento) Some malware '
9335	                              'targets the termination of a program to trigger execution, adversaries can use the '
9336	                              '<code>~/.bash_logout</code> file to execute malicious commands at the end of a '
9337	                              'session. \n'
9338	                              '\n'
9339	                              'For macOS, the functionality of this technique is similar but may leverage zsh, the '
9340	                              'default shell for macOS 10.15+. When the Terminal.app is opened, the application '
9341	                              'launches a zsh login shell and a zsh interactive shell. The login shell configures the '
9342	                              'system environment using <code>/etc/profile</code>, <code>/etc/zshenv</code>, '
9343	                              '<code>/etc/zprofile</code>, and <code>/etc/zlogin</code>.(Citation: ScriptingOSX '
9344	                              'zsh)(Citation: PersistentJXA_leopitt)(Citation: code_persistence_zsh)(Citation: macOS '
9345	                              'MS office sandbox escape) The login shell then configures the user environment with '
9346	                              '<code>~/.zprofile</code> and <code>~/.zlogin</code>. The interactive shell uses the '
9347	                              '<code>~/.zshrc</code> to configure the user environment. Upon exiting, '
9348	                              '<code>/etc/zlogout</code> and <code>~/.zlogout</code> are executed. For legacy '
9349	                              'programs, macOS executes <code>/etc/bashrc</code> on startup.',
9350	               'name': 'Unix Shell Configuration Modification',
9351	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS']},

9402	               'categories': ['privilege-escalation', 'persistence'],
9403	               'description': 'Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious '
9404	                              'content triggered by accessibility features. Windows contains accessibility features '
9405	                              'that may be launched with a key combination before a user has logged in (ex: when the '
9406	                              'user is on the Windows logon screen). An adversary can modify the way these programs '
9407	                              'are launched to get a command prompt or backdoor without logging in to the system.\n'
9408	                              '\n'
9409	                              'Two common accessibility programs are <code>C:\\Windows\\System32\\sethc.exe</code>, '
9410	                              'launched when the shift key is pressed five times and '
9411	                              '<code>C:\\Windows\\System32\\utilman.exe</code>, launched when the Windows + U key '
9412	                              'combination is pressed. The sethc.exe program is often referred to as "sticky keys", '
9413	                              'and has been used by adversaries for unauthenticated access through a remote desktop '
9414	                              'login screen. (Citation: FireEye Hikit Rootkit)\n'
9415	                              '\n'
9416	                              'Depending on the version of Windows, an adversary may take advantage of these features '
9417	                              'in different ways. Common methods used by adversaries include replacing accessibility '
9418	                              'feature binaries or pointers/references to these binaries in the Registry. In newer '
9419	                              'versions of Windows, the replaced binary needs to be digitally signed for x64 systems, '
9420	                              'the binary must reside in <code>%systemdir%\\</code>, and it must be protected by '
9421	                              'Windows File or Resource Protection (WFP/WRP). (Citation: DEFCON2016 Sticky Keys) The '
9422	                              '[Image File Execution Options Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012) '
9423	                              'debugger method was likely discovered as a potential workaround because it does not '
9424	                              'require the corresponding accessibility feature binary to be replaced.\n'
9425	                              '\n'
9426	                              'For simple binary replacement on Windows XP and later as well as and Windows Server '
9427	                              '2003/R2 and later, for example, the program (e.g., '
9428	                              '<code>C:\\Windows\\System32\\utilman.exe</code>) may be replaced with "cmd.exe" (or '
9429	                              'another program that provides backdoor access). Subsequently, pressing the appropriate '
9430	                              'key combination at the login screen while sitting at the keyboard or when connected '
9431	                              'over [Remote Desktop Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/001) will '
9432	                              'cause the replaced file to be executed with SYSTEM privileges. (Citation: Tilbury '
9433	                              '2014)\n'
9434	                              '\n'
9435	                              'Other accessibility features exist that may also be leveraged in a similar fashion: '
9436	                              '(Citation: DEFCON2016 Sticky Keys)(Citation: Narrator Accessibility Abuse)\n'

9442	                              '* App Switcher: <code>C:\\Windows\\System32\\AtBroker.exe</code>',

9484	               'categories': ['privilege-escalation', 'persistence'],
9485	               'description': 'Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious '
9486	                              'content triggered by application shims. The Microsoft Windows Application Compatibility '
9487	                              'Infrastructure/Framework (Application Shim) was created to allow for backward '
9488	                              'compatibility of software as the operating system codebase changes over time. For '
9489	                              'example, the application shimming feature allows developers to apply fixes to '
9490	                              'applications (without rewriting code) that were created for Windows XP so that it will '
9491	                              'work with Windows 10. (Citation: Elastic Process Injection July 2017)\n'
9492	                              '\n'
9493	                              'Within the framework, shims are created to act as a buffer between the program (or more '
9494	                              'specifically, the Import Address Table) and the Windows OS. When a program is executed, '
9495	                              'the shim cache is referenced to determine if the program requires the use of the shim '
9496	                              'database (.sdb). If so, the shim database uses hooking to redirect the code as '
9497	                              'necessary in order to communicate with the OS. \n'
9498	                              '\n'
9499	                              'A list of all shims currently installed by the default Windows installer (sdbinst.exe) '
9500	                              'is kept in:\n'
9501	                              '\n'
9502	                              '* <code>%WINDIR%\\AppPatch\\sysmain.sdb</code> and\n'
9503	                              '* <code>hklm\\software\\microsoft\\windows '
9504	                              'nt\\currentversion\\appcompatflags\\installedsdb</code>\n'
9505	                              '\n'
9506	                              'Custom databases are stored in:\n'
9507	                              '\n'
9508	                              '* <code>%WINDIR%\\AppPatch\\custom & %WINDIR%\\AppPatch\\AppPatch64\\Custom</code> and\n'
9509	                              '* <code>hklm\\software\\microsoft\\windows '
9510	                              'nt\\currentversion\\appcompatflags\\custom</code>\n'
9511	                              '\n'
9512	                              'To keep shims secure, Windows designed them to run in user mode so they cannot modify '
9513	                              'the kernel and you must have administrator privileges to install a shim. However, '
9514	                              'certain shims can be used to [Bypass User Account '
9515	                              'Control](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1548/002) (UAC and RedirectEXE), inject '
9516	                              'DLLs into processes (InjectDLL), disable Data Execution Prevention (DisableNX) and '
9517	                              'Structure Exception Handling (DisableSEH), and intercept memory addresses '
9518	                              '(GetProcAddress).\n'
9519	                              '\n'
9520	                              'Utilizing these shims may allow an adversary to perform several malicious acts such as '
9521	                              'elevate privileges, install backdoors, disable defenses like Windows Defender, etc. '
9522	                              '(Citation: FireEye Application Shimming) Shims can also be abused to establish '
9523	                              'persistence by continuously being invoked by affected programs.',
9524	               'name': 'Application Shimming',
9525	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

9527	               'categories': ['privilege-escalation', 'persistence'],
9528	               'description': 'Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious '
9529	                              'content triggered by Image File Execution Options (IFEO) debuggers. IFEOs enable a '
9530	                              'developer to attach a debugger to an application. When a process is created, a debugger '
9531	                              'present in an application’s IFEO will be prepended to the application’s name, '
9532	                              'effectively launching the new process under the debugger (e.g., <code>C:\\dbg\\ntsd.exe '
9533	                              '-g  notepad.exe</code>). (Citation: Microsoft Dev Blog IFEO Mar 2010)\n'
9534	                              '\n'
9535	                              'IFEOs can be set directly via the Registry or in Global Flags via the GFlags tool. '
9536	                              '(Citation: Microsoft GFlags Mar 2017) IFEOs are represented as <code>Debugger</code> '
9537	                              'values in the Registry under <code>HKLM\\SOFTWARE{\\Wow6432Node}\\Microsoft\\Windows '
9538	                              'NT\\CurrentVersion\\Image File Execution Options\\<executable></code> where '
9539	                              '<code>&lt;executable&gt;</code> is the binary on which the debugger is attached. '
9540	                              '(Citation: Microsoft Dev Blog IFEO Mar 2010)\n'
9541	                              '\n'
9542	                              'IFEOs can also enable an arbitrary monitor program to be launched when a specified '
9543	                              'program silently exits (i.e. is prematurely terminated by itself or a second, non '
9544	                              'kernel-mode process). (Citation: Microsoft Silent Process Exit NOV 2017) (Citation: '
9545	                              'Oddvar Moe IFEO APR 2018) Similar to debuggers, silent exit monitoring can be enabled '
9546	                              'through GFlags and/or by directly modifying IFEO and silent process exit Registry '
9547	                              'values in <code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows '
9548	                              'NT\\CurrentVersion\\SilentProcessExit\\</code>. (Citation: Microsoft Silent Process '
9549	                              'Exit NOV 2017) (Citation: Oddvar Moe IFEO APR 2018)\n'
9550	                              '\n'
9551	                              'Similar to [Accessibility Features](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/008), on '
9552	                              'Windows Vista and later as well as Windows Server 2008 and later, a Registry key may be '
9553	                              'modified that configures "cmd.exe," or another program that provides backdoor access, '
9554	                              'as a "debugger" for an accessibility program (ex: utilman.exe). After the Registry is '
9555	                              'modified, pressing the appropriate key combination at the login screen while at the '
9556	                              'keyboard or when connected with [Remote Desktop '
9557	                              'Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/001) will cause the "debugger" '
9558	                              'program to be executed with SYSTEM privileges. (Citation: Tilbury 2014)\n'
9559	                              '\n'
9560	                              'Similar to [Process Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055), these values '
9561	                              'may also be abused to obtain privilege escalation by causing a malicious executable to '
9562	                              'be loaded and run in the context of separate processes on the computer. (Citation: '
9563	                              'Elastic Process Injection July 2017) Installing IFEO mechanisms may also provide '
9564	                              'Persistence via continuous triggered invocation.\n'
9565	                              '\n'
9566	                              'Malware may also use IFEO to [Impair '
9567	                              'Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) by registering invalid debuggers '
9568	                              'that redirect and effectively disable various system and security applications. '
9569	                              '(Citation: FSecure Hupigon) (Citation: Symantec Ushedix June 2008)',
9570	               'name': 'Image File Execution Options Injection',
9571	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

9602	                              'Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004) that accepts events from various '
9603	                              'services, runs them through a simple rules engine, and takes action. The emond binary '
9604	                              'at <code>/sbin/emond</code> will load any rules from the '
9605	                              '<code>/etc/emond.d/rules/</code> directory and take action once an explicitly defined '
9606	                              'event takes place.\n'
9607	                              '\n'
9608	                              'The rule files are in the plist format and define the name, event type, and action to '
9609	                              'take. Some examples of event types include system startup and user authentication. '
9610	                              'Examples of actions are to run a system command or send an email. The emond service '
9611	                              'will not launch if there is no file present in the QueueDirectories path '
9612	                              '<code>/private/var/db/emondClients</code>, specified in the [Launch '
9613	                              'Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004) configuration file '
9614	                              'at<code>/System/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.apple.emond.plist</code>.(Citation: xorrior '
9615	                              'emond Jan 2018)(Citation: magnusviri emond Apr 2016)(Citation: sentinelone macos '
9616	                              'persist Jun 2019)\n'
9617	                              '\n'

9619	                              'event occurs, such as system start up or user authentication.(Citation: xorrior emond '

9646	               'categories': ['privilege-escalation', 'persistence'],
9647	               'description': 'Adversaries may establish persistence and elevate privileges by using an installer to '
9648	                              'trigger the execution of malicious content. Installer packages are OS specific and '
9649	                              'contain the resources an operating system needs to install applications on a system. '
9650	                              'Installer packages can include scripts that run prior to installation as well as after '
9651	                              'installation is complete. Installer scripts may inherit elevated permissions when '
9652	                              'executed. Developers often use these scripts to prepare the environment for '
9653	                              'installation, check requirements, download dependencies, and remove files after '
9654	                              'installation.(Citation: Installer Package Scripting Rich Trouton)\n'
9655	                              '\n'
9656	                              'Using legitimate applications, adversaries have distributed applications with modified '
9657	                              'installer scripts to execute malicious content. When a user installs the application, '
9658	                              'they may be required to grant administrative permissions to allow the installation. At '
9659	                              'the end of the installation process of the legitimate application, content such as '
9660	                              'macOS `postinstall` scripts can be executed with the inherited elevated permissions. '
9661	                              'Adversaries can use these scripts to execute a malicious executable or install other '
9662	                              'malicious components (such as a [Launch '
9663	                              'Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004)) with the elevated '
9664	                              'permissions.(Citation: Application Bundle Manipulation Brandon Dalton)(Citation: wardle '
9665	                              'evilquest parti)(Citation: Windows AppleJeus GReAT)(Citation: Debian Manual Maintainer '
9666	                              'Scripts)\n'
9667	                              '\n'
9668	                              'Depending on the distribution, Linux versions of package installer scripts are '
9669	                              'sometimes called maintainer scripts or post installation scripts. These scripts can '
9670	                              'include `preinst`, `postinst`, `prerm`, `postrm` scripts and run as root when '
9671	                              'executed.\n'
9672	                              '\n'
9673	                              'For Windows, the Microsoft Installer services uses `.msi` files to manage the '
9674	                              'installing, updating, and uninstalling of applications. These installation routines may '
9675	                              'also include instructions to perform additional actions that may be abused by '
9676	                              'adversaries.(Citation: Microsoft Installation Procedures)',

9696	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation'],
9697	               'description': 'Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or '
9698	                              'referencing it with a Registry run key. Adding an entry to the "run keys" in the '
9699	                              'Registry or startup folder will cause the program referenced to be executed when a user '
9700	                              'logs in.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key) These programs will be executed under the context '
9701	                              "of the user and will have the account's associated permissions level.\n"
9702	                              '\n'

9706	                              '* '
9707	                              '<code>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\RunOnce</code>\n'
9708	                              '* <code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run</code>\n'
