9711	                              '\n'
9712	                              'Run keys may exist under multiple hives.(Citation: Microsoft Wow6432Node '
9713	                              '2018)(Citation: Malwarebytes Wow6432Node 2016) The '
9714	                              '<code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\RunOnceEx</code> '
9715	                              'is also available but is not created by default on Windows Vista and newer. Registry '
9716	                              'run key entries can reference programs directly or list them as a dependency.(Citation: '
9717	                              'Microsoft Run Key) For example, it is possible to load a DLL at logon using a "Depend" '
9718	                              'key with RunOnceEx: <code>reg add '
9719	                              'HKLM\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\RunOnceEx\\0001\\Depend /v 1 /d '
9720	                              '"C:\\temp\\evil[.]dll"</code> (Citation: Oddvar Moe RunOnceEx Mar 2018)\n'
9721	                              '\n'
9722	                              'Placing a program within a startup folder will also cause that program to execute when '
9723	                              'a user logs in. There is a startup folder location for individual user accounts as well '
9724	                              'as a system-wide startup folder that will be checked regardless of which user account '
9725	                              'logs in. The startup folder path for the current user is '
9726	                              '<code>C:\\Users\\\\[Username]\\AppData\\Roaming\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start '
9727	                              'Menu\\Programs\\Startup</code>. The startup folder path for all users is '
9728	                              '<code>C:\\ProgramData\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\StartUp</code>.\n'
9729	                              '\n'
9730	                              'The following Registry keys can be used to set startup folder items for persistence:\n'
9731	                              '\n'
9732	                              '* <code>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Explorer\\User '
9733	                              'Shell Folders</code>\n'
9734	                              '* '
9735	                              '<code>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Explorer\\Shell '
9736	                              'Folders</code>\n'
9737	                              '* '
9738	                              '<code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Explorer\\Shell '
9739	                              'Folders</code>\n'
9740	                              '* '
9741	                              '<code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Explorer\\User '
9742	                              'Shell Folders</code>\n'
9743	                              '\n'
9744	                              'The following Registry keys can control automatic startup of services during boot:\n'
9745	                              '\n'
9746	                              '* '
9747	                              '<code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\RunServicesOnce</code>\n'
9748	                              '* '
9749	                              '<code>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\RunServicesOnce</code>\n'
9750	                              '* '
9751	                              '<code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\RunServices</code>\n'
9752	                              '* '
9753	                              '<code>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\RunServices</code>\n'
9754	                              '\n'
9755	                              'Using policy settings to specify startup programs creates corresponding values in '
9756	                              'either of two Registry keys:\n'
9757	                              '\n'
9758	                              '* '
9759	                              '<code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Policies\\Explorer\\Run</code>\n'
9760	                              '* '
9761	                              '<code>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Policies\\Explorer\\Run</code>\n'
9762	                              '\n'
9763	                              'Programs listed in the load value of the registry key '
9764	                              '<code>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows '
9765	                              'NT\\CurrentVersion\\Windows</code> run automatically for the currently logged-on user.\n'
9766	                              '\n'
9767	                              'By default, the multistring <code>BootExecute</code> value of the registry key '
9768	                              '<code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\System\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\Session Manager</code> is '
9769	                              'set to <code>autocheck autochk *</code>. This value causes Windows, at startup, to '
9770	                              'check the file-system integrity of the hard disks if the system has been shut down '
9771	                              'abnormally. Adversaries can add other programs or processes to this registry value '
9772	                              'which will automatically launch at boot.\n'
9773	                              '\n'
9774	                              'Adversaries can use these configuration locations to execute malware, such as remote '
9775	                              'access tools, to maintain persistence through system reboots. Adversaries may also use '
9776	                              '[Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to make the Registry entries '
9777	                              'look as if they are associated with legitimate programs.',
9778	               'name': 'Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder',
9779	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

9858	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation'],
9859	               'description': 'Adversaries may modify the kernel to automatically execute programs on system boot. '
9860	                              'Loadable Kernel Modules (LKMs) are pieces of code that can be loaded and unloaded into '
9861	                              'the kernel upon demand. They extend the functionality of the kernel without the need to '
9862	                              'reboot the system. For example, one type of module is the device driver, which allows '
9863	                              'the kernel to access hardware connected to the system.(Citation: Linux Kernel '
9864	                              'Programming)\xa0\n'
9865	                              '\n'
9866	                              'When used maliciously, LKMs can be a type of kernel-mode '
9867	                              '[Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1014) that run with the highest '
9868	                              'operating system privilege (Ring 0).(Citation: Linux Kernel Module Programming '
9869	                              'Guide)\xa0Common features of LKM based rootkits include: hiding itself, selective '
9870	                              'hiding of files, processes and network activity, as well as log tampering, providing '
9871	                              'authenticated backdoors, and enabling root access to non-privileged users.(Citation: '
9872	                              'iDefense Rootkit Overview)\n'
9873	                              '\n'
9874	                              'Kernel extensions, also called kext, are used in macOS to load functionality onto a '
9875	                              'system similar to LKMs for Linux. Since the kernel is responsible for enforcing '
9876	                              'security and the kernel extensions run as apart of the kernel, kexts are not governed '
9877	                              'by macOS security policies. Kexts are loaded and unloaded through <code>kextload</code> '
9878	                              'and <code>kextunload</code> commands. Kexts need to be signed with a developer ID that '
9879	                              'is granted privileges by Apple allowing it to sign Kernel extensions. Developers '
9880	                              'without these privileges may still sign kexts but they will not load unless SIP is '
9881	                              'disabled. If SIP is enabled, the kext signature is verified before being added to the '
9882	                              'AuxKC.(Citation: System and kernel extensions in macOS)\n'
9883	                              '\n'
9884	                              'Since macOS Catalina 10.15, kernel extensions have been deprecated in favor of System '
9885	                              'Extensions. However, kexts are still allowed as "Legacy System Extensions" since there '
9886	                              'is no System Extension for Kernel Programming Interfaces.(Citation: Apple Kernel '
9887	                              'Extension Deprecation)\n'
9888	                              '\n'
9889	                              'Adversaries can use LKMs and kexts to conduct '
9890	                              '[Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003) and/or [Privilege '
9891	                              'Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0004) on a system. Examples have been '
9892	                              'found in the wild, and there are some relevant open source projects as well.(Citation: '
9893	                              'Volatility Phalanx2)(Citation: CrowdStrike Linux Rootkit)(Citation: GitHub '
9894	                              'Reptile)(Citation: GitHub Diamorphine)(Citation: RSAC 2015 San Francisco Patrick '
9895	                              'Wardle)(Citation: Synack Secure Kernel Extension Broken)(Citation: Securelist '
9896	                              'Ventir)(Citation: Trend Micro Skidmap)',
9897	               'name': 'Kernel Modules and Extensions',
9898	               'platforms': ['macOS', 'Linux']},

10006	                              'commands when a user’s desktop environment is loaded at login. XDG Autostart entries '
10007	                              'are available for any XDG-compliant Linux system. XDG Autostart entries use Desktop '
10008	                              'Entry files (`.desktop`) to configure the user’s desktop environment upon user login. '
10009	                              'These configuration files determine what applications launch upon user login, define '
10010	                              'associated applications to open specific file types, and define applications used to '
10011	                              'open removable media.(Citation: Free Desktop Application Autostart Feb 2006)(Citation: '
10012	                              'Free Desktop Entry Keys)\n'
10013	                              '\n'
10014	                              'Adversaries may abuse this feature to establish persistence by adding a path to a '
10015	                              'malicious binary or command to the `Exec` directive in the `.desktop` configuration '
10016	                              'file. When the user’s desktop environment is loaded at user login, the `.desktop` files '
10017	                              'located in the XDG Autostart directories are automatically executed. System-wide '
10018	                              'Autostart entries are located in the `/etc/xdg/autostart` directory while the user '
10019	                              'entries are located in the `~/.config/autostart` directory.\n'
10020	                              '\n'

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:10050

10049	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation'],
10050	               'description': 'Adversaries may add login items to execute upon user login to gain persistence or '
10051	                              'escalate privileges. Login items are applications, documents, folders, or server '
10052	                              'connections that are automatically launched when a user logs in.(Citation: Open Login '
10053	                              'Items Apple) Login items can be added via a shared file list or Service Management '
10054	                              'Framework.(Citation: Adding Login Items) Shared file list login items can be set using '
10055	                              'scripting languages such as '
10056	                              '[AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002), whereas the Service '
10057	                              'Management Framework uses the API call <code>SMLoginItemSetEnabled</code>.\n'
10058	                              '\n'
10059	                              'Login items installed using the Service Management Framework leverage '
10060	                              '<code>launchd</code>, are not visible in the System Preferences, and can only be '
10061	                              'removed by the application that created them.(Citation: Adding Login Items)(Citation: '
10062	                              'SMLoginItemSetEnabled Schroeder 2013) Login items created using a shared file list are '
10063	                              'visible in System Preferences, can hide the application when it launches, and are '
10064	                              'executed through LaunchServices, not launchd, to open applications, documents, or URLs '
10065	                              'without using Finder.(Citation: Launch Services Apple Developer) Users and applications '
10066	                              'use login items to configure their user environment to launch commonly used services or '
10067	                              'applications, such as email, chat, and music applications.\n'
10068	                              '\n'
10069	                              'Adversaries can utilize [AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002) '
10070	                              'and [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) calls to create a login '
10071	                              'item to spawn malicious executables.(Citation: ELC Running at startup) Prior to version '
10072	                              '10.5 on macOS, adversaries can add login items by using '
10073	                              '[AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002) to send an Apple events to '
10074	                              'the “System Events” process, which has an AppleScript dictionary for manipulating login '
10075	                              'items.(Citation: Login Items AE) Adversaries can use a command such as <code>tell '
10076	                              'application “System Events” to make login item at end with properties '
10077	                              '/path/to/executable</code>.(Citation: Startup Items Eclectic)(Citation: hexed osx.dok '
10078	                              'analysis 2019)(Citation: Add List Remove Login Items Apple Script) This command adds '
10079	                              'the path of the malicious executable to the login item file list located in '
10080	                              '<code>~/Library/Application '
10081	                              'Support/com.apple.backgroundtaskmanagementagent/backgrounditems.btm</code>.(Citation: '
10082	                              'Startup Items Eclectic) Adversaries can also use login items to launch executables that '
10083	                              'can be used to control the victim system remotely or as a means to gain privilege '
10084	                              'escalation by prompting for user credentials.(Citation: objsee mac malware '
10085	                              '2017)(Citation: CheckPoint Dok)(Citation: objsee netwire backdoor 2019)',
10086	               'name': 'Login Items',

10088	 'T1548': {'attack_id': 'T1548',
10089	           'categories': ['privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
10090	           'description': 'Adversaries may circumvent mechanisms designed to control elevate privileges to gain '

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:10101
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
10100	               'categories': ['privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
10101	               'description': 'An adversary may abuse configurations where an application has the setuid or setgid '
10102	                              'bits set in order to get code running in a different (and possibly more privileged) '
10103	                              'user’s context. On Linux or macOS, when the setuid or setgid bits are set for an '
10104	                              'application binary, the application will run with the privileges of the owning user or '
10105	                              'group respectively.(Citation: setuid man page) Normally an application is run in the '
10106	                              'current user’s context, regardless of which user or group owns the application. '
10107	                              'However, there are instances where programs need to be executed in an elevated context '
10108	                              'to function properly, but the user running them may not have the specific required '
10109	                              'privileges.\n'
10110	                              '\n'
10111	                              'Instead of creating an entry in the sudoers file, which must be done by root, any user '
10112	                              'can specify the setuid or setgid flag to be set for their own applications (i.e. [Linux '
10113	                              'and Mac File and Directory Permissions '
10114	                              'Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1222/002)). The <code>chmod</code> '
10115	                              'command can set these bits with bitmasking, <code>chmod 4777 [file]</code> or via '
10116	                              'shorthand naming, <code>chmod u+s [file]</code>. This will enable the setuid bit. To '
10117	                              'enable the setgid bit, <code>chmod 2775</code> and <code>chmod g+s</code> can be used.\n'
10118	                              '\n'
10119	                              "Adversaries can use this mechanism on their own malware to make sure they're able to "
10120	                              'execute in elevated contexts in the future.(Citation: OSX Keydnap malware) This abuse '
10121	                              'is often part of a "shell escape" or other actions to bypass an execution environment '
10122	                              'with restricted permissions.\n'
10123	                              '\n'
10124	                              'Alternatively, adversaries may choose to find and target vulnerable binaries with the '
10125	                              'setuid or setgid bits already enabled (i.e. [File and Directory '
10126	                              'Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083)). The setuid and setguid bits are '
10127	                              'indicated with an "s" instead of an "x" when viewing a file\'s attributes via <code>ls '
10128	                              '-l</code>. The <code>find</code> command can also be used to search for such files. For '
10129	                              'example, <code>find / -perm +4000 2>/dev/null</code> can be used to find files with '
10130	                              'setuid set and <code>find / -perm +2000 2>/dev/null</code> may be used for setgid. '
10131	                              'Binaries that have these bits set may then be abused by adversaries.(Citation: GTFOBins '

10136	               'categories': ['privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
10137	               'description': 'Adversaries may bypass UAC mechanisms to elevate process privileges on system. Windows '
10138	                              'User Account Control (UAC) allows a program to elevate its privileges (tracked as '
10139	                              'integrity levels ranging from low to high) to perform a task under administrator-level '
10140	                              'permissions, possibly by prompting the user for confirmation. The impact to the user '
10141	                              'ranges from denying the operation under high enforcement to allowing the user to '
10142	                              'perform the action if they are in the local administrators group and click through the '
10143	                              'prompt or allowing them to enter an administrator password to complete the '
10144	                              'action.(Citation: TechNet How UAC Works)\n'
10145	                              '\n'
10146	                              'If the UAC protection level of a computer is set to anything but the highest level, '
10147	                              'certain Windows programs can elevate privileges or execute some elevated [Component '
10148	                              'Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/001) objects without prompting '
10149	                              'the user through the UAC notification box.(Citation: TechNet Inside UAC)(Citation: MSDN '
10150	                              'COM Elevation) An example of this is use of '
10151	                              '[Rundll32](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218/011) to load a specifically '
10152	                              'crafted DLL which loads an auto-elevated [Component Object '
10153	                              'Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/001) object and performs a file '
10154	                              'operation in a protected directory which would typically require elevated access. '
10155	                              'Malicious software may also be injected into a trusted process to gain elevated '
10156	                              'privileges without prompting a user.(Citation: Davidson Windows)\n'
10157	                              '\n'
10158	                              'Many methods have been discovered to bypass UAC. The Github readme page for UACME '
10159	                              'contains an extensive list of methods(Citation: Github UACMe) that have been discovered '
10160	                              'and implemented, but may not be a comprehensive list of bypasses. Additional bypass '
10161	                              'methods are regularly discovered and some used in the wild, such as:\n'
10162	                              '\n'
10163	                              '* <code>eventvwr.exe</code> can auto-elevate and execute a specified binary or '
10164	                              'script.(Citation: enigma0x3 Fileless UAC Bypass)(Citation: Fortinet Fareit)\n'
10165	                              '\n'
10166	                              'Another bypass is possible through some lateral movement techniques if credentials for '
10167	                              'an account with administrator privileges are known, since UAC is a single system '
10168	                              'security mechanism, and the privilege or integrity of a process running on one system '
10169	                              'will be unknown on remote systems and default to high integrity.(Citation: SANS UAC '
10170	                              'Bypass)',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:10248

10247	               'categories': ['privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
10248	               'description': 'Adversaries may abuse permission configurations that allow them to gain temporarily '
10249	                              'elevated access to cloud resources. Many cloud environments allow administrators to '
10250	                              'grant user or service accounts permission to request just-in-time access to roles, '
10251	                              'impersonate other accounts, pass roles onto resources and services, or otherwise gain '
10252	                              'short-term access to a set of privileges that may be distinct from their own. \n'
10253	                              '\n'
10254	                              'Just-in-time access is a mechanism for granting additional roles to cloud accounts in a '
10255	                              'granular, temporary manner. This allows accounts to operate with only the permissions '
10256	                              'they need on a daily basis, and to request additional permissions as necessary. '
10257	                              'Sometimes just-in-time access requests are configured to require manual approval, while '
10258	                              'other times the desired permissions are automatically granted.(Citation: Azure Just in '
10259	                              'Time Access 2023)\n'
10260	                              '\n'
10261	                              'Account impersonation allows user or service accounts to temporarily act with the '
10262	                              'permissions of another account. For example, in GCP users with the '
10263	                              '`iam.serviceAccountTokenCreator` role can create temporary access tokens or sign '
10264	                              'arbitrary payloads with the permissions of a service account, while service accounts '
10265	                              'with domain-wide delegation permission are permitted to impersonate Google Workspace '
10266	                              'accounts.(Citation: Google Cloud Service Account Authentication Roles)(Citation: '
10267	                              'Hunters Domain Wide Delegation Google Workspace 2023)(Citation: Google Cloud Just in '
10268	                              'Time Access 2023)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 Google Workspace Domain Wide Delegation '
10269	                              '2023) In Exchange Online, the `ApplicationImpersonation` role allows a service account '
10270	                              'to use the permissions associated with specified user accounts.(Citation: Microsoft '
10271	                              'Impersonation and EWS in Exchange) \n'
10272	                              '\n'
10273	                              'Many cloud environments also include mechanisms for users to pass roles to resources '
10274	                              'that allow them to perform tasks and authenticate to other services. While the user '
10275	                              'that creates the resource does not directly assume the role they pass to it, they may '
10276	                              "still be able to take advantage of the role's access -- for example, by configuring the "
10277	                              'resource to perform certain actions with the permissions it has been granted. In AWS, '
10278	                              'users with the `PassRole` permission can allow a service they create to assume a given '
10279	                              'role, while in GCP, users with the `iam.serviceAccountUser` role can attach a service '
10280	                              'account to a resource.(Citation: AWS PassRole)(Citation: Google Cloud Service Account '
10281	                              'Authentication Roles)\n'
10282	                              '\n'
10283	                              'While users require specific role assignments in order to use any of these features, '
10284	                              'cloud administrators may misconfigure permissions. This could result in escalation '
10285	                              'paths that allow adversaries to gain access to resources beyond what was originally '
10286	                              'intended.(Citation: Rhino Google Cloud Privilege Escalation)(Citation: Rhino Security '
10287	                              'Labs AWS Privilege Escalation)\n'
10288	                              '\n'
10289	                              '**Note:** this technique is distinct from [Additional Cloud '
10290	                              'Roles](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1098/003), which involves assigning '
10291	                              'permanent roles to accounts rather than abusing existing permissions structures to gain '
10292	                              'temporarily elevated access to resources. However, adversaries that compromise a '
10293	                              'sufficiently privileged account may grant another account they control [Additional '
10294	                              'Cloud Roles](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1098/003) that would allow them to '
10295	                              'also abuse these features. This may also allow for greater stealth than would be had by '
10296	                              'directly using the highly privileged account, especially when logs do not clarify when '
10297	                              'role impersonation is taking place.(Citation: CrowdStrike StellarParticle January 2022)',
10298	               'name': 'Temporary Elevated Cloud Access',
10299	               'platforms': ['IaaS', 'Azure AD', 'Office 365', 'Google Workspace']},

10301	               'categories': ['defense-evasion', 'privilege-escalation'],
10302	               'description': 'Adversaries can manipulate or abuse the Transparency, Consent, & Control (TCC) service '
10303	                              'or database to execute malicious applications with elevated permissions. TCC is a '
10304	                              'Privacy & Security macOS control mechanism used to determine if the running process has '
10305	                              'permission to access the data or services protected by TCC, such as screen sharing, '
10306	                              'camera, microphone, or Full Disk Access (FDA).\n'
10307	                              '\n'
10308	                              'When an application requests to access data or a service protected by TCC, the TCC '
10309	                              'daemon (`tccd`) checks the TCC database, located at `/Library/Application '
10310	                              'Support/com.apple.TCC/TCC.db` (and `~/` equivalent), for existing permissions. If '
10311	                              'permissions do not exist, then the user is prompted to grant permission. Once '
10312	                              "permissions are granted, the database stores the application's permissions and will not "
10313	                              'prompt the user again unless reset. For example, when a web browser requests '
10314	                              "permissions to the user's webcam, once granted the web browser may not explicitly "
10315	                              'prompt the user again.(Citation: welivesecurity TCC)\n'
10316	                              '\n'
10317	                              'Adversaries may manipulate the TCC database or otherwise abuse the TCC service to '
10318	                              'execute malicious content. This can be done in various ways, including using privileged '
10319	                              'system applications to execute malicious payloads or manipulating the database to grant '
10320	                              'their application TCC permissions. \n'
10321	                              '\n'
10322	                              'For example, adversaries can use Finder, which has FDA permissions by default, to '
10323	                              'execute malicious [AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002) while '
10324	                              'preventing a user prompt. For a system without System Integrity Protection (SIP) '
10325	                              'enabled, adversaries have also manipulated the operating system to load an adversary '
10326	                              'controlled TCC database using environment variables and '
10327	                              '[Launchctl](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1569/001).(Citation: TCC macOS '
10328	                              'bypass)(Citation: TCC Database)\n'
10329	                              '\n'
10330	                              'Adversaries may also opt to instead inject code (e.g., [Process '
10331	                              'Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055)) into targeted applications with '
10332	                              'the desired TCC permissions.\n',
10333	               'name': 'TCC Manipulation',

10338	                          'tickets, and application access tokens, in order to move laterally within an environment '
10339	                          'and bypass normal system access controls. \n'
10340	                          '\n'
10341	                          'Authentication processes generally require a valid identity (e.g., username) along with one '
10342	                          'or more authentication factors (e.g., password, pin, physical smart card, token generator, '
10343	                          'etc.). Alternate authentication material is legitimately generated by systems after a user '
10344	                          'or application successfully authenticates by providing a valid identity and the required '
10345	                          'authentication factor(s). Alternate authentication material may also be generated during '
10346	                          'the identity creation process.(Citation: NIST Authentication)(Citation: NIST MFA)\n'
10347	                          '\n'
10348	                          'Caching alternate authentication material allows the system to verify an identity has '
10349	                          'successfully authenticated without asking the user to reenter authentication factor(s). '
10350	                          'Because the alternate authentication must be maintained by the system—either in memory or '
10351	                          'on disk—it may be at risk of being stolen through [Credential '
10352	                          'Access](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0006) techniques. By stealing alternate '
10353	                          'authentication material, adversaries are able to bypass system access controls and '
10354	                          'authenticate to systems without knowing the plaintext password or any additional '
10355	                          'authentication factors.\n',

10409	               'description': 'Adversaries may “pass the hash” using stolen password hashes to move laterally within '
10410	                              'an environment, bypassing normal system access controls. Pass the hash (PtH) is a '
10411	                              "method of authenticating as a user without having access to the user's cleartext "
10412	                              'password. This method bypasses standard authentication steps that require a cleartext '
10413	                              'password, moving directly into the portion of the authentication that uses the password '
10414	                              'hash.\n'
10415	                              '\n'
10416	                              'When performing PtH, valid password hashes for the account being used are captured '
10417	                              'using a [Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0006) technique. '
10418	                              'Captured hashes are used with PtH to authenticate as that user. Once authenticated, PtH '
10419	                              'may be used to perform actions on local or remote systems.\n'
10420	                              '\n'
10421	                              'Adversaries may also use stolen password hashes to "overpass the hash." Similar to PtH, '
10422	                              'this involves using a password hash to authenticate as a user but also uses the '
10423	                              'password hash to create a valid Kerberos ticket. This ticket can then be used to '
10424	                              'perform [Pass the Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/003) '
10425	                              'attacks.(Citation: Stealthbits Overpass-the-Hash)',
10426	               'name': 'Pass the Hash',

10431	                              'within an environment, bypassing normal system access controls. Pass the ticket (PtT) '
10432	                              'is a method of authenticating to a system using Kerberos tickets without having access '
10433	                              "to an account's password. Kerberos authentication can be used as the first step to "
10434	                              'lateral movement to a remote system.\n'
10435	                              '\n'
10436	                              'When preforming PtT, valid Kerberos tickets for [Valid '
10437	                              'Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) are captured by [OS Credential '
10438	                              "Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003). A user's service tickets or ticket "
10439	                              'granting ticket (TGT) may be obtained, depending on the level of access. A service '
10440	                              'ticket allows for access to a particular resource, whereas a TGT can be used to request '
10441	                              'service tickets from the Ticket Granting Service (TGS) to access any resource the user '
10442	                              'has privileges to access.(Citation: ADSecurity AD Kerberos Attacks)(Citation: '
10443	                              'GentilKiwi Pass the Ticket)\n'
10444	                              '\n'
10445	                              'A [Silver Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1558/002) can be obtained for '
10446	                              'services that use Kerberos as an authentication mechanism and are used to generate '
10447	                              'tickets to access that particular resource and the system that hosts the resource '
10448	                              '(e.g., SharePoint).(Citation: ADSecurity AD Kerberos Attacks)\n'
10449	                              '\n'
10450	                              'A [Golden Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1558/001) can be obtained for '
10451	                              'the domain using the Key Distribution Service account KRBTGT account NTLM hash, which '
10452	                              'enables generation of TGTs for any account in Active Directory.(Citation: Campbell '
10453	                              '2014)\n'
10454	                              '\n'
10455	                              'Adversaries may also create a valid Kerberos ticket using other user information, such '
10456	                              'as stolen password hashes or AES keys. For example, "overpassing the hash" involves '
10457	                              'using a NTLM password hash to authenticate as a user (i.e. [Pass the '
10458	                              'Hash](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/002)) while also using the password '
10459	                              'hash to create a valid Kerberos ticket.(Citation: Stealthbits Overpass-the-Hash)',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:10691
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
10690	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
10691	               'description': 'Adversaries may modify file attributes and subvert Gatekeeper functionality to evade '
10692	                              'user prompts and execute untrusted programs. Gatekeeper is a set of technologies that '
10693	                              'act as layer of Apple’s security model to ensure only trusted applications are executed '
10694	                              'on a host. Gatekeeper was built on top of File Quarantine in Snow Leopard (10.6, 2009) '
10695	                              'and has grown to include Code Signing, security policy compliance, Notarization, and '
10696	                              'more. Gatekeeper also treats applications running for the first time differently than '
10697	                              'reopened applications.(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany Quarantine and the '
10698	                              'flag)(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany apple notarization )\n'
10699	                              '\n'
10700	                              'Based on an opt-in system, when files are downloaded an extended attribute (xattr) '
10701	                              'called `com.apple.quarantine` (also known as a quarantine flag) can be set on the file '
10702	                              'by the application performing the download. Launch Services opens the application in a '
10703	                              'suspended state. For first run applications with the quarantine flag set, Gatekeeper '
10704	                              'executes the following functions:\n'
10705	                              '\n'
10706	                              '1. Checks extended attribute – Gatekeeper checks for the quarantine flag, then provides '
10707	                              'an alert prompt to the user to allow or deny execution.(Citation: OceanLotus for OS '
10708	                              'X)(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and Techniques)\n'
10709	                              '\n'
10710	                              '2. Checks System Policies - Gatekeeper checks the system security policy, allowing '
10711	                              'execution of apps downloaded from either just the App Store or the App Store and '
10712	                              'identified developers.\n'
10713	                              '\n'
10714	                              '3. Code Signing – Gatekeeper checks for a valid code signature from an Apple Developer '
10715	                              'ID.\n'
10716	                              '\n'
10717	                              '4. Notarization - Using the `api.apple-cloudkit.com` API, Gatekeeper reaches out to '
10718	                              'Apple servers to verify or pull down the notarization ticket and ensure the ticket is '
10719	                              'not revoked. Users can override notarization, which will result in a prompt of '
10720	                              'executing an “unauthorized app” and the security policy will be modified.\n'
10721	                              '\n'
10722	                              'Adversaries can subvert one or multiple security controls within Gatekeeper checks '
10723	                              'through logic errors (e.g. [Exploitation for Defense '
10724	                              'Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211)), unchecked file types, and '
10725	                              'external libraries. For example, prior to macOS 13 Ventura, code signing and '
10726	                              'notarization checks were only conducted on first launch, allowing adversaries to write '
10727	                              'malicious executables to previously opened applications in order to bypass Gatekeeper '
10728	                              'security checks.(Citation: theevilbit gatekeeper bypass 2021)(Citation: Application '
10729	                              'Bundle Manipulation Brandon Dalton)\n'
10730	                              '\n'
10731	                              'Applications and files loaded onto the system from a USB flash drive, optical disk, '
10732	                              'external hard drive, from a drive shared over the local network, or using the curl '
10733	                              'command may not set the quarantine flag. Additionally, it is possible to avoid setting '
10734	                              'the quarantine flag using [Drive-by '
10735	                              'Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189).',
10736	               'name': 'Gatekeeper Bypass',
10737	               'platforms': ['macOS']},

10739	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],

10743	                              'Signing) The certificates used during an operation may be created, acquired, or stolen '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:10759
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
10758	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
10759	               'description': 'Adversaries may tamper with SIP and trust provider components to mislead the operating '
10760	                              'system and application control tools when conducting signature validation checks. In '
10761	                              'user mode, Windows Authenticode (Citation: Microsoft Authenticode) digital signatures '
10762	                              "are used to verify a file's origin and integrity, variables that may be used to "
10763	                              'establish trust in signed code (ex: a driver with a valid Microsoft signature may be '
10764	                              'handled as safe). The signature validation process is handled via the WinVerifyTrust '
10765	                              'application programming interface (API) function,  (Citation: Microsoft WinVerifyTrust) '
10766	                              'which accepts an inquiry and coordinates with the appropriate trust provider, which is '
10767	                              'responsible for validating parameters of a signature. (Citation: SpectorOps Subverting '
10768	                              'Trust Sept 2017)\n'
10769	                              '\n'
10770	                              'Because of the varying executable file types and corresponding signature formats, '
10771	                              'Microsoft created software components called Subject Interface Packages (SIPs) '
10772	                              '(Citation: EduardosBlog SIPs July 2008) to provide a layer of abstraction between API '
10773	                              'functions and files. SIPs are responsible for enabling API functions to create, '
10774	                              'retrieve, calculate, and verify signatures. Unique SIPs exist for most file formats '
10775	                              '(Executable, PowerShell, Installer, etc., with catalog signing providing a catch-all  '
10776	                              '(Citation: Microsoft Catalog Files and Signatures April 2017)) and are identified by '
10777	                              'globally unique identifiers (GUIDs). (Citation: SpectorOps Subverting Trust Sept 2017)\n'
10778	                              '\n'
10779	                              'Similar to [Code Signing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1553/002), adversaries '
10780	                              'may abuse this architecture to subvert trust controls and bypass security policies that '
10781	                              'allow only legitimately signed code to execute on a system. Adversaries may hijack SIP '
10782	                              'and trust provider components to mislead operating system and application control tools '
10783	                              'to classify malicious (or any) code as signed by: (Citation: SpectorOps Subverting '
10784	                              'Trust Sept 2017)\n'
10785	                              '\n'
10786	                              '* Modifying the <code>Dll</code> and <code>FuncName</code> Registry values in '
10787	                              '<code>HKLM\\SOFTWARE[\\WOW6432Node\\]Microsoft\\Cryptography\\OID\\EncodingType '
10788	                              '0\\CryptSIPDllGetSignedDataMsg\\{SIP_GUID}</code> that point to the dynamic link '
10789	                              'library (DLL) providing a SIP’s CryptSIPDllGetSignedDataMsg function, which retrieves '
10790	                              'an encoded digital certificate from a signed file. By pointing to a maliciously-crafted '
10791	                              'DLL with an exported function that always returns a known good signature value (ex: a '
10792	                              'Microsoft signature for Portable Executables) rather than the file’s real signature, an '
10793	                              'adversary can apply an acceptable signature value to all files using that SIP '
10794	                              '(Citation: GitHub SIP POC Sept 2017) (although a hash mismatch will likely occur, '
10795	                              'invalidating the signature, since the hash returned by the function will not match the '
10796	                              'value computed from the file).\n'
10797	                              '* Modifying the <code>Dll</code> and <code>FuncName</code> Registry values in '
10798	                              '<code>HKLM\\SOFTWARE\\[WOW6432Node\\]Microsoft\\Cryptography\\OID\\EncodingType '
10799	                              '0\\CryptSIPDllVerifyIndirectData\\{SIP_GUID}</code> that point to the DLL providing a '
10800	                              'SIP’s CryptSIPDllVerifyIndirectData function, which validates a file’s computed hash '
10801	                              'against the signed hash value. By pointing to a maliciously-crafted DLL with an '
10802	                              'exported function that always returns TRUE (indicating that the validation was '
10803	                              'successful), an adversary can successfully validate any file (with a legitimate '
10804	                              'signature) using that SIP (Citation: GitHub SIP POC Sept 2017) (with or without '
10805	                              'hijacking the previously mentioned CryptSIPDllGetSignedDataMsg function). This Registry '
10806	                              'value could also be redirected to a suitable exported function from an already present '
10807	                              'DLL, avoiding the requirement to drop and execute a new file on disk.\n'
10808	                              '* Modifying the <code>DLL</code> and <code>Function</code> Registry values in '
10809	                              '<code>HKLM\\SOFTWARE\\[WOW6432Node\\]Microsoft\\Cryptography\\Providers\\Trust\\FinalPolicy\\{trust '
10810	                              'provider GUID}</code> that point to the DLL providing a trust provider’s FinalPolicy '
10811	                              'function, which is where the decoded and parsed signature is checked and the majority '
10812	                              'of trust decisions are made. Similar to hijacking SIP’s CryptSIPDllVerifyIndirectData '
10813	                              'function, this value can be redirected to a suitable exported function from an already '
10814	                              'present DLL or a maliciously-crafted DLL (though the implementation of a trust provider '
10815	                              'is complex).\n'
10816	                              '* **Note:** The above hijacks are also possible without modifying the Registry via [DLL '
10817	                              'Search Order Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/001).\n'
10818	                              '\n'
10819	                              'Hijacking SIP or trust provider components can also enable persistent code execution, '
10820	                              'since these malicious components may be invoked by any application that performs code '
10821	                              'signing or signature validation. (Citation: SpectorOps Subverting Trust Sept 2017)',
10822	               'name': 'SIP and Trust Provider Hijacking',
10823	               'platforms': ['Windows']},
10824	 'T1553.004': {'attack_id': 'T1553.004',
10825	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
10826	               'description': 'Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:10826
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
10825	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
10826	               'description': 'Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings '
10827	                              'when connecting to adversary controlled web servers. Root certificates are used in '
10828	                              'public key cryptography to identify a root certificate authority (CA). When a root '
10829	                              'certificate is installed, the system or application will trust certificates in the '
10830	                              "root's chain of trust that have been signed by the root certificate.(Citation: "
10831	                              'Wikipedia Root Certificate) Certificates are commonly used for establishing secure '
10832	                              'TLS/SSL communications within a web browser. When a user attempts to browse a website '
10833	                              'that presents a certificate that is not trusted an error message will be displayed to '
10834	                              'warn the user of the security risk. Depending on the security settings, the browser may '
10835	                              'not allow the user to establish a connection to the website.\n'
10836	                              '\n'
10837	                              'Installation of a root certificate on a compromised system would give an adversary a '
10838	                              'way to degrade the security of that system. Adversaries have used this technique to '
10839	                              'avoid security warnings prompting users when compromised systems connect over HTTPS to '
10840	                              'adversary controlled web servers that spoof legitimate websites in order to collect '
10841	                              'login credentials.(Citation: Operation Emmental)\n'
10842	                              '\n'
10843	                              'Atypical root certificates have also been pre-installed on systems by the manufacturer '
10844	                              'or in the software supply chain and were used in conjunction with malware/adware to '
10845	                              'provide [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) capability '
10846	                              'for intercepting information transmitted over secure TLS/SSL communications.(Citation: '
10847	                              'Kaspersky Superfish)\n'
10848	                              '\n'
10849	                              'Root certificates (and their associated chains) can also be cloned and reinstalled. '
10850	                              'Cloned certificate chains will carry many of the same metadata characteristics of the '
10851	                              'source and can be used to sign malicious code that may then bypass signature validation '
10852	                              'tools (ex: Sysinternals, antivirus, etc.) used to block execution and/or uncover '
10853	                              'artifacts of Persistence.(Citation: SpectorOps Code Signing Dec 2017)\n'
10854	                              '\n'
10855	                              'In macOS, the Ay MaMi malware uses <code>/usr/bin/security add-trusted-cert -d -r '
10856	                              'trustRoot -k /Library/Keychains/System.keychain /path/to/malicious/cert</code> to '
10857	                              'install a malicious certificate as a trusted root certificate into the system '
10858	                              'keychain.(Citation: objective-see ay mami 2018)',
10859	               'name': 'Install Root Certificate',
10860	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows']},
10861	 'T1553.005': {'attack_id': 'T1553.005',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:10887
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
10886	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
10887	               'description': 'Adversaries may modify code signing policies to enable execution of unsigned or '
10888	                              'self-signed code. Code signing provides a level of authenticity on a program from a '
10889	                              'developer and a guarantee that the program has not been tampered with. Security '
10890	                              'controls can include enforcement mechanisms to ensure that only valid, signed code can '
10891	                              'be run on an operating system. \n'
10892	                              '\n'
10893	                              'Some of these security controls may be enabled by default, such as Driver Signature '
10894	                              'Enforcement (DSE) on Windows or System Integrity Protection (SIP) on macOS.(Citation: '
10895	                              'Microsoft DSE June 2017)(Citation: Apple Disable SIP) Other such controls may be '
10896	                              'disabled by default but are configurable through application controls, such as only '
10897	                              'allowing signed Dynamic-Link Libraries (DLLs) to execute on a system. Since it can be '
10898	                              'useful for developers to modify default signature enforcement policies during the '
10899	                              'development and testing of applications, disabling of these features may be possible '
10900	                              'with elevated permissions.(Citation: Microsoft Unsigned Driver Apr 2017)(Citation: '
10901	                              'Apple Disable SIP)\n'
10902	                              '\n'
10903	                              'Adversaries may modify code signing policies in a number of ways, including through use '
10904	                              'of command-line or GUI utilities, [Modify '
10905	                              'Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112), rebooting the computer in a '
10906	                              'debug/recovery mode, or by altering the value of variables in kernel memory.(Citation: '
10907	                              'Microsoft TESTSIGNING Feb 2021)(Citation: Apple Disable SIP)(Citation: FireEye HIKIT '
10908	                              'Rootkit Part 2)(Citation: GitHub Turla Driver Loader) Examples of commands that can '
10909	                              'modify the code signing policy of a system include <code>bcdedit.exe -set TESTSIGNING '
10910	                              'ON</code> on Windows and <code>csrutil disable</code> on macOS.(Citation: Microsoft '
10911	                              'TESTSIGNING Feb 2021)(Citation: Apple Disable SIP) Depending on the implementation, '
10912	                              'successful modification of a signing policy may require reboot of the compromised '
10913	                              'system. Additionally, some implementations can introduce visible artifacts for the user '
10914	                              '(ex: a watermark in the corner of the screen stating the system is in Test Mode). '
10915	                              'Adversaries may attempt to remove such artifacts.(Citation: F-Secure BlackEnergy 2014)\n'
10916	                              '\n'
10917	                              'To gain access to kernel memory to modify variables related to signature checks, such '
10918	                              'as modifying <code>g_CiOptions</code> to disable Driver Signature Enforcement, '
10919	                              'adversaries may conduct [Exploitation for Privilege '
10920	                              'Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068) using a signed, but vulnerable '
10921	                              'driver.(Citation: Unit42 AcidBox June 2020)(Citation: GitHub Turla Driver Loader)',

11004	               'description': 'Adversaries may acquire credentials from web browsers by reading files specific to the '
11005	                              'target browser.(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer 2018) Web browsers commonly save '
11006	                              'credentials such as website usernames and passwords so that they do not need to be '
11007	                              'entered manually in the future. Web browsers typically store the credentials in an '
11008	                              'encrypted format within a credential store; however, methods exist to extract plaintext '
11009	                              'credentials from web browsers.\n'
11010	                              '\n'
11011	                              'For example, on Windows systems, encrypted credentials may be obtained from Google '
11012	                              'Chrome by reading a database file, <code>AppData\\Local\\Google\\Chrome\\User '
11013	                              'Data\\Default\\Login Data</code> and executing a SQL query: <code>SELECT action_url, '
11014	                              'username_value, password_value FROM logins;</code>. The plaintext password can then be '
11015	                              'obtained by passing the encrypted credentials to the Windows API function '
11016	                              '<code>CryptUnprotectData</code>, which uses the victim’s cached logon credentials as '
11017	                              'the decryption key.(Citation: Microsoft CryptUnprotectData April 2018)\n'
11018	                              ' \n'
11019	                              'Adversaries have executed similar procedures for common web browsers such as FireFox, '
11020	                              'Safari, Edge, etc.(Citation: Proofpoint Vega Credential Stealer May 2018)(Citation: '
11021	                              'FireEye HawkEye Malware July 2017) Windows stores Internet Explorer and Microsoft Edge '
11022	                              'credentials in Credential Lockers managed by the [Windows Credential '
11023	                              'Manager](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1555/004).\n'
11024	                              '\n'
11025	                              'Adversaries may also acquire credentials by searching web browser process memory for '
11026	                              'patterns that commonly match credentials.(Citation: GitHub Mimikittenz July 2016)\n'
11027	                              '\n'
11028	                              'After acquiring credentials from web browsers, adversaries may attempt to recycle the '
11029	                              'credentials across different systems and/or accounts in order to expand access. This '
11030	                              "can result in significantly furthering an adversary's objective in cases where "
11031	                              'credentials gained from web browsers overlap with privileged accounts (e.g. domain '
11032	                              'administrator).',

11037	               'description': 'Adversaries may acquire credentials from the Windows Credential Manager. The Credential '
11038	                              'Manager stores credentials for signing into websites, applications, and/or devices that '
11039	                              'request authentication through NTLM or Kerberos in Credential Lockers (previously known '
11040	                              'as Windows Vaults).(Citation: Microsoft Credential Manager store)(Citation: Microsoft '
11041	                              'Credential Locker)\n'
11042	                              '\n'
11043	                              'The Windows Credential Manager separates website credentials from application or '
11044	                              'network credentials in two lockers. As part of [Credentials from Web '
11045	                              'Browsers](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1555/003), Internet Explorer and '
11046	                              'Microsoft Edge website credentials are managed by the Credential Manager and are stored '
11047	                              'in the Web Credentials locker. Application and network credentials are stored in the '
11048	                              'Windows Credentials locker.\n'
11049	                              '\n'
11050	                              'Credential Lockers store credentials in encrypted `.vcrd` files, located under '
11051	                              '`%Systemdrive%\\Users\\\\[Username]\\AppData\\Local\\Microsoft\\\\[Vault/Credentials]\\`. '
11052	                              'The encryption key can be found in a file named <code>Policy.vpol</code>, typically '
11053	                              'located in the same folder as the credentials.(Citation: passcape Windows '
11054	                              'Vault)(Citation: Malwarebytes The Windows Vault)\n'
11055	                              '\n'
11056	                              'Adversaries may list credentials managed by the Windows Credential Manager through '
11057	                              'several mechanisms. <code>vaultcmd.exe</code> is a native Windows executable that can '
11058	                              'be used to enumerate credentials stored in the Credential Locker through a command-line '
11059	                              'interface. Adversaries may also gather credentials by directly reading files located '
11060	                              'inside of the Credential Lockers. Windows APIs, such as <code>CredEnumerateA</code>, '
11061	                              'may also be absued to list credentials managed by the Credential Manager.(Citation: '
11062	                              'Microsoft CredEnumerate)(Citation: Delpy Mimikatz Crendential Manager)\n'
11063	                              '\n'
11064	                              'Adversaries may also obtain credentials from credential backups. Credential backups and '
11065	                              'restorations may be performed by running <code>rundll32.exe keymgr.dll '
11066	                              'KRShowKeyMgr</code> then selecting the “Back up...” button on the “Stored User Names '
11067	                              'and Passwords” GUI.\n'
11068	                              '\n'
11069	                              'Password recovery tools may also obtain plain text passwords from the Credential '
11070	                              'Manager.(Citation: Malwarebytes The Windows Vault)',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:11218

11217	               'categories': ['credential-access', 'defense-evasion', 'persistence'],
11218	               'description': 'An adversary may abuse Active Directory authentication encryption properties to gain '
11219	                              'access to credentials on Windows systems. The '
11220	                              '<code>AllowReversiblePasswordEncryption</code> property specifies whether reversible '
11221	                              'password encryption for an account is enabled or disabled. By default this property is '
11222	                              'disabled (instead storing user credentials as the output of one-way hashing functions) '
11223	                              'and should not be enabled unless legacy or other software require it.(Citation: '
11224	                              'store_pwd_rev_enc)\n'
11225	                              '\n'
11226	                              'If the property is enabled and/or a user changes their password after it is enabled, an '
11227	                              'adversary may be able to obtain the plaintext of passwords created/changed after the '
11228	                              'property was enabled. To decrypt the passwords, an adversary needs four components:\n'
11229	                              '\n'
11230	                              '1. Encrypted password (<code>G$RADIUSCHAP</code>) from the Active Directory '
11231	                              'user-structure <code>userParameters</code>\n'
11232	                              '2. 16 byte randomly-generated value (<code>G$RADIUSCHAPKEY</code>) also from '
11233	                              '<code>userParameters</code>\n'
11234	                              '3. Global LSA secret (<code>G$MSRADIUSCHAPKEY</code>)\n'
11235	                              '4. Static key hardcoded in the Remote Access Subauthentication DLL '
11236	                              '(<code>RASSFM.DLL</code>)\n'
11237	                              '\n'
11238	                              'With this information, an adversary may be able to reproduce the encryption key and '
11239	                              'subsequently decrypt the encrypted password value.(Citation: '
11240	                              'how_pwd_rev_enc_1)(Citation: how_pwd_rev_enc_2)\n'
11241	                              '\n'
11242	                              'An adversary may set this property at various scopes through Local Group Policy Editor, '
11243	                              'user properties, Fine-Grained Password Policy (FGPP), or via the ActiveDirectory '
11244	                              '[PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) module. For example, an '
11245	                              'adversary may implement and apply a FGPP to users or groups if the Domain Functional '
11246	                              'Level is set to "Windows Server 2008" or higher.(Citation: dump_pwd_dcsync) In '
11247	                              'PowerShell, an adversary may make associated changes to user settings using commands '
11248	                              'similar to <code>Set-ADUser -AllowReversiblePasswordEncryption $true</code>.',
11249	               'name': 'Reversible Encryption',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:11352
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
11351	               'categories': ['credential-access', 'defense-evasion', 'persistence'],
11352	               'description': 'Adversaries may disable or modify conditional access policies to enable persistent '
11353	                              'access to compromised accounts. Conditional access policies are additional '
11354	                              'verifications used by identity providers and identity and access management systems to '
11355	                              'determine whether a user should be granted access to a resource.\n'
11356	                              '\n'
11357	                              'For example, in Azure AD, Okta, and JumpCloud, users can be denied access to '
11358	                              'applications based on their IP address, device enrollment status, and use of '
11359	                              'multi-factor authentication.(Citation: Microsoft Conditional Access)(Citation: '
11360	                              'JumpCloud Conditional Access Policies)(Citation: Okta Conditional Access Policies) In '
11361	                              'some cases, identity providers may also support the use of risk-based metrics to deny '
11362	                              'sign-ins based on a variety of indicators. In AWS and GCP, IAM policies can contain '
11363	                              '`condition` attributes that verify arbitrary constraints such as the source IP, the '
11364	                              'date the request was made, and the nature of the resources or regions being '
11365	                              'requested.(Citation: AWS IAM Conditions)(Citation: GCP IAM Conditions) These measures '
11366	                              'help to prevent compromised credentials from resulting in unauthorized access to data '
11367	                              'or resources, as well as limit user permissions to only those required. \n'
11368	                              '\n'
11369	                              'By modifying conditional access policies, such as adding additional trusted IP ranges, '

11384	                          'traffic (e.g. ARP, DNS, LLMNR, etc.), adversaries may force a device to communicate through '
11385	                          'an adversary controlled system so they can collect information or perform additional '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:11412
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
11411	               'categories': ['credential-access', 'collection'],
11412	               'description': 'By responding to LLMNR/NBT-NS network traffic, adversaries may spoof an authoritative '
11413	                              'source for name resolution to force communication with an adversary controlled system. '
11414	                              'This activity may be used to collect or relay authentication materials. \n'
11415	                              '\n'
11416	                              'Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution (LLMNR) and NetBIOS Name Service (NBT-NS) are '
11417	                              'Microsoft Windows components that serve as alternate methods of host identification. '
11418	                              'LLMNR is based upon the Domain Name System (DNS) format and allows hosts on the same '
11419	                              'local link to perform name resolution for other hosts. NBT-NS identifies systems on a '
11420	                              'local network by their NetBIOS name. (Citation: Wikipedia LLMNR)(Citation: TechNet '
11421	                              'NetBIOS)\n'
11422	                              '\n'
11423	                              'Adversaries can spoof an authoritative source for name resolution on a victim network '
11424	                              'by responding to LLMNR (UDP 5355)/NBT-NS (UDP 137) traffic as if they know the identity '
11425	                              'of the requested host, effectively poisoning the service so that the victims will '
11426	                              'communicate with the adversary controlled system. If the requested host belongs to a '
11427	                              'resource that requires identification/authentication, the username and NTLMv2 hash will '
11428	                              'then be sent to the adversary controlled system. The adversary can then collect the '
11429	                              'hash information sent over the wire through tools that monitor the ports for traffic or '
11430	                              'through [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) and crack the '
11431	                              'hashes offline through [Brute Force](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110) to '
11432	                              'obtain the plaintext passwords.\n'
11433	                              '\n'
11434	                              'In some cases where an adversary has access to a system that is in the authentication '
11435	                              'path between systems or when automated scans that use credentials attempt to '
11436	                              'authenticate to an adversary controlled system, the NTLMv1/v2 hashes can be intercepted '
11437	                              'and relayed to access and execute code against a target system. The relay step can '
11438	                              'happen in conjunction with poisoning but may also be independent of it.(Citation: '
11439	                              'byt3bl33d3r NTLM Relaying)(Citation: Secure Ideas SMB Relay) Additionally, adversaries '
11440	                              'may encapsulate the NTLMv1/v2 hashes into various protocols, such as LDAP, SMB, MSSQL '
11441	                              'and HTTP, to expand and use multiple services with the valid NTLM response.\xa0\n'
11442	                              '\n'
11443	                              'Several tools may be used to poison name services within local networks such as '
11444	                              'NBNSpoof, Metasploit, and '
11445	                              '[Responder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0174).(Citation: GitHub '
11446	                              'NBNSpoof)(Citation: Rapid7 LLMNR Spoofer)(Citation: GitHub Responder)',
11447	               'name': 'LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay',
11448	               'platforms': ['Windows']},
