>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:11451
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
11450	               'categories': ['credential-access', 'collection'],
11451	               'description': 'Adversaries may poison Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) caches to position themselves '
11452	                              'between the communication of two or more networked devices. This activity may be used '
11453	                              'to enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network '
11454	                              'Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data '
11455	                              'Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002).\n'
11456	                              '\n'
11457	                              'The ARP protocol is used to resolve IPv4 addresses to link layer addresses, such as a '
11458	                              'media access control (MAC) address.(Citation: RFC826 ARP) Devices in a local network '
11459	                              'segment communicate with each other by using link layer addresses. If a networked '
11460	                              'device does not have the link layer address of a particular networked device, it may '
11461	                              'send out a broadcast ARP request to the local network to translate the IP address to a '
11462	                              'MAC address. The device with the associated IP address directly replies with its MAC '
11463	                              'address. The networked device that made the ARP request will then use as well as store '
11464	                              'that information in its ARP cache.\n'
11465	                              '\n'
11466	                              'An adversary may passively wait for an ARP request to poison the ARP cache of the '
11467	                              'requesting device. The adversary may reply with their MAC address, thus deceiving the '
11468	                              'victim by making them believe that they are communicating with the intended networked '
11469	                              'device. For the adversary to poison the ARP cache, their reply must be faster than the '
11470	                              'one made by the legitimate IP address owner. Adversaries may also send a gratuitous ARP '
11471	                              'reply that maliciously announces the ownership of a particular IP address to all the '
11472	                              'devices in the local network segment.\n'
11473	                              '\n'
11474	                              'The ARP protocol is stateless and does not require authentication. Therefore, devices '
11475	                              'may wrongly add or update the MAC address of the IP address in their ARP '
11476	                              'cache.(Citation: Sans ARP Spoofing Aug 2003)(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)\n'
11477	                              '\n'
11478	                              'Adversaries may use ARP cache poisoning as a means to intercept network traffic. This '
11479	                              'activity may be used to collect and/or relay data such as credentials, especially those '
11480	                              'sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol.(Citation: Sans ARP Spoofing Aug 2003)\n',
11481	               'name': 'ARP Cache Poisoning',
11482	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'Windows', 'macOS']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:11485
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
11484	               'categories': ['credential-access', 'collection'],
11485	               'description': 'Adversaries may redirect network traffic to adversary-owned systems by spoofing Dynamic '
11486	                              'Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) traffic and acting as a malicious DHCP server on the '
11487	                              'victim network. By achieving the adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position, adversaries '
11488	                              'may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent '
11489	                              'over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as '
11490	                              '[Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data '
11491	                              'Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002).\n'
11492	                              '\n'
11493	                              'DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for '
11494	                              'providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism '
11495	                              'for allocating network addresses to clients.(Citation: rfc2131) The typical '
11496	                              'server-client interaction is as follows: \n'
11497	                              '\n'
11498	                              '1. The client broadcasts a `DISCOVER` message.\n'
11499	                              '\n'
11500	                              '2. The server responds with an `OFFER` message, which includes an available network '
11501	                              'address. \n'
11502	                              '\n'
11503	                              '3. The client broadcasts a `REQUEST` message, which includes the network address '
11504	                              'offered. \n'
11505	                              '\n'
11506	                              '4. The server acknowledges with an `ACK` message and the client receives the network '
11507	                              'configuration parameters.\n'
11508	                              '\n'
11509	                              'Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which '
11510	                              'legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can '
11511	                              'act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized '
11512	                              'computers.(Citation: new_rogue_DHCP_serv_malware)(Citation: w32.tidserv.g) Through the '
11513	                              'malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route '
11514	                              'client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the '
11515	                              'client network.\n'
11516	                              '\n'
11517	                              'DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an '
11518	                              'IP address by sending a <code>INFORMATION-REQUEST (code 11)</code> message to the '
11519	                              '<code>All_DHCP_Relay_Agents_and_Servers</code> multicast address.(Citation: rfc3315) '
11520	                              'Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with '
11521	                              'malicious network configurations.\n'
11522	                              '\n'
11523	                              'Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to '
11524	                              'perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, [Service Exhaustion '
11525	                              'Flood](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/002)) by generating many broadcast '
11526	                              'DISCOVER messages to exhaust a network’s DHCP allocation pool. ',
11527	               'name': 'DHCP Spoofing',
11528	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'Windows', 'macOS']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:11531
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
11530	           'categories': ['credential-access'],
11531	           'description': 'Adversaries may attempt to subvert Kerberos authentication by stealing or forging Kerberos '
11532	                          'tickets to enable [Pass the Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/003). '
11533	                          'Kerberos is an authentication protocol widely used in modern Windows domain environments. '
11534	                          'In Kerberos environments, referred to as “realms”, there are three basic participants: '
11535	                          'client, service, and Key Distribution Center (KDC).(Citation: ADSecurity Kerberos Ring '
11536	                          'Decoder) Clients request access to a service and through the exchange of Kerberos tickets, '
11537	                          'originating from KDC, they are granted access after having successfully authenticated. The '
11538	                          'KDC is responsible for both authentication and ticket granting.  Adversaries may attempt to '
11539	                          'abuse Kerberos by stealing tickets or forging tickets to enable unauthorized access.\n'
11540	                          '\n'
11541	                          'On Windows, the built-in <code>klist</code> utility can be used to list and analyze cached '
11542	                          'Kerberos tickets.(Citation: Microsoft Klist)\n'
11543	                          '\n'
11544	                          'Linux systems on Active Directory domains store Kerberos credentials locally in the '
11545	                          'credential cache file referred to as the "ccache". The credentials are stored in the ccache '
11546	                          "file while they remain valid and generally while a user's session lasts.(Citation: MIT "
11547	                          'ccache) On modern Redhat Enterprise Linux systems, and derivative distributions, the System '
11548	                          'Security Services Daemon (SSSD) handles Kerberos tickets. By default SSSD maintains a copy '
11549	                          'of the ticket database that can be found in <code>/var/lib/sss/secrets/secrets.ldb</code> '
11550	                          'as well as the corresponding key located in '
11551	                          '<code>/var/lib/sss/secrets/.secrets.mkey</code>. Both files require root access to read. If '
11552	                          'an adversary is able to access the database and key, the credential cache Kerberos blob can '
11553	                          'be extracted and converted into a usable Kerberos ccache file that adversaries may use for '
11554	                          '[Pass the Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/003). The ccache file may also '
11555	                          'be converted into a Windows format using tools such as Kekeo.(Citation: Linux Kerberos '
11556	                          'Tickets)(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix)(Citation: Kekeo)\n'
11557	                          '\n'
11558	                          '\n'
11559	                          'Kerberos tickets on macOS are stored in a standard ccache format, similar to Linux. By '
11560	                          'default, access to these ccache entries is federated through the KCM daemon process via the '
11561	                          "Mach RPC protocol, which uses the caller's environment to determine access. The storage "
11562	                          'location for these ccache entries is influenced by the <code>/etc/krb5.conf</code> '
11563	                          'configuration file and the <code>KRB5CCNAME</code> environment variable which can specify '
11564	                          'to save them to disk or keep them protected via the KCM daemon. Users can interact with '
11565	                          'ticket storage using <code>kinit</code>, <code>klist</code>, <code>ktutil</code>, and '
11566	                          "<code>kcc</code> built-in binaries or via Apple's native Kerberos framework. Adversaries "
11567	                          'can use open source tools to interact with the ccache files directly or to use the Kerberos '
11568	                          "framework to call lower-level APIs for extracting the user's TGT or Service "
11569	                          'Tickets.(Citation: SpectorOps Bifrost Kerberos macOS 2019)(Citation: macOS kerberos '
11570	                          'framework MIT)\n',
11571	           'name': 'Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets',
11572	           'platforms': ['Windows', 'Linux', 'macOS']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:11615
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
11614	               'categories': ['credential-access'],
11615	               'description': 'Adversaries may abuse a valid Kerberos ticket-granting ticket (TGT) or sniff network '
11616	                              'traffic to obtain a ticket-granting service (TGS) ticket that may be vulnerable to '
11617	                              '[Brute Force](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110).(Citation: Empire '
11618	                              'InvokeKerberoast Oct 2016)(Citation: AdSecurity Cracking Kerberos Dec 2015) \n'
11619	                              '\n'
11620	                              'Service principal names (SPNs) are used to uniquely identify each instance of a Windows '
11621	                              'service. To enable authentication, Kerberos requires that SPNs be associated with at '
11622	                              'least one service logon account (an account specifically tasked with running a '
11623	                              'service(Citation: Microsoft Detecting Kerberoasting Feb 2018)).(Citation: Microsoft '
11624	                              'SPN)(Citation: Microsoft SetSPN)(Citation: SANS Attacking Kerberos Nov 2014)(Citation: '
11625	                              'Harmj0y Kerberoast Nov 2016)\n'
11626	                              '\n'
11627	                              'Adversaries possessing a valid Kerberos ticket-granting ticket (TGT) may request one or '
11628	                              'more Kerberos ticket-granting service (TGS) service tickets for any SPN from a domain '
11629	                              'controller (DC).(Citation: Empire InvokeKerberoast Oct 2016)(Citation: AdSecurity '
11630	                              'Cracking Kerberos Dec 2015) Portions of these tickets may be encrypted with the RC4 '
11631	                              'algorithm, meaning the Kerberos 5 TGS-REP etype 23 hash of the service account '
11632	                              'associated with the SPN is used as the private key and is thus vulnerable to offline '
11633	                              '[Brute Force](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110) attacks that may expose '
11634	                              'plaintext credentials.(Citation: AdSecurity Cracking Kerberos Dec 2015)(Citation: '
11635	                              'Empire InvokeKerberoast Oct 2016) (Citation: Harmj0y Kerberoast Nov 2016)\n'
11636	                              '\n'
11637	                              'This same behavior could be executed using service tickets captured from network '
11638	                              'traffic.(Citation: AdSecurity Cracking Kerberos Dec 2015)\n'
11639	                              '\n'
11640	                              'Cracked hashes may enable [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003), '
11641	                              '[Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0004), and [Lateral '
11642	                              'Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) via access to [Valid '
11643	                              'Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078).(Citation: SANS Attacking Kerberos '
11644	                              'Nov 2014)',
11645	               'name': 'Kerberoasting',
11646	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:11649
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
11648	               'categories': ['credential-access'],
11649	               'description': 'Adversaries may reveal credentials of accounts that have disabled Kerberos '
11650	                              'preauthentication by [Password Cracking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110/002) '
11651	                              'Kerberos messages.(Citation: Harmj0y Roasting AS-REPs Jan 2017) \n'
11652	                              '\n'
11653	                              'Preauthentication offers protection against offline [Password '
11654	                              'Cracking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110/002). When enabled, a user '
11655	                              'requesting access to a resource initiates communication with the Domain Controller (DC) '
11656	                              'by sending an Authentication Server Request (AS-REQ) message with a timestamp that is '
11657	                              'encrypted with the hash of their password. If and only if the DC is able to '
11658	                              'successfully decrypt the timestamp with the hash of the user’s password, it will then '
11659	                              'send an Authentication Server Response (AS-REP) message that contains the Ticket '
11660	                              'Granting Ticket (TGT) to the user. Part of the AS-REP message is signed with the user’s '
11661	                              'password.(Citation: Microsoft Kerberos Preauth 2014)\n'
11662	                              '\n'
11663	                              'For each account found without preauthentication, an adversary may send an AS-REQ '
11664	                              'message without the encrypted timestamp and receive an AS-REP message with TGT data '
11665	                              'which may be encrypted with an insecure algorithm such as RC4. The recovered encrypted '
11666	                              'data may be vulnerable to offline [Password '
11667	                              'Cracking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110/002) attacks similarly to '
11668	                              '[Kerberoasting](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1558/003) and expose plaintext '
11669	                              'credentials. (Citation: Harmj0y Roasting AS-REPs Jan 2017)(Citation: Stealthbits '
11670	                              'Cracking AS-REP Roasting Jun 2019) \n'
11671	                              '\n'
11672	                              'An account registered to a domain, with or without special privileges, can be abused to '
11673	                              'list all domain accounts that have preauthentication disabled by utilizing Windows '
11674	                              'tools like [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) with an LDAP '
11675	                              'filter. Alternatively, the adversary may send an AS-REQ message for each user. If the '
11676	                              'DC responds without errors, the account does not require preauthentication and the '
11677	                              'AS-REP message will already contain the encrypted data. (Citation: Harmj0y Roasting '
11678	                              'AS-REPs Jan 2017)(Citation: Stealthbits Cracking AS-REP Roasting Jun 2019)\n'
11679	                              '\n'
11680	                              'Cracked hashes may enable [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003), '
11681	                              '[Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0004), and [Lateral '
11682	                              'Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) via access to [Valid '
11683	                              'Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078).(Citation: SANS Attacking Kerberos '
11684	                              'Nov 2014)',
11685	               'name': 'AS-REP Roasting',
11686	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:11689

11688	           'categories': ['execution'],
11689	           'description': 'Adversaries may abuse inter-process communication (IPC) mechanisms for local code or '
11690	                          'command execution. IPC is typically used by processes to share data, communicate with each '
11691	                          'other, or synchronize execution. IPC is also commonly used to avoid situations such as '
11692	                          'deadlocks, which occurs when processes are stuck in a cyclic waiting pattern. \n'
11693	                          '\n'
11694	                          'Adversaries may abuse IPC to execute arbitrary code or commands. IPC mechanisms may differ '
11695	                          'depending on OS, but typically exists in a form accessible through programming '
11696	                          'languages/libraries or native interfaces such as Windows [Dynamic Data '
11697	                          'Exchange](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/002) or [Component Object '
11698	                          'Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/001). Linux environments support several '
11699	                          'different IPC mechanisms, two of which being sockets and pipes.(Citation: Linux IPC) Higher '
11700	                          'level execution mediums, such as those of [Command and Scripting '
11701	                          'Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059)s, may also leverage underlying IPC '
11702	                          'mechanisms. Adversaries may also use [Remote '
11703	                          'Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as [Distributed Component Object '
11704	                          'Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) to facilitate remote IPC '
11705	                          'execution.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019)',
11706	           'name': 'Inter-Process Communication',
11707	           'platforms': ['Windows', 'macOS', 'Linux']},

11710	               'description': 'Adversaries may use the Windows Component Object Model (COM) for local code execution. '
11711	                              'COM is an inter-process communication (IPC) component of the native Windows application '
11712	                              'programming interface (API) that enables interaction between software objects, or '
11713	                              'executable code that implements one or more interfaces.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM '
11714	                              'June 2019) Through COM, a client object can call methods of server objects, which are '
11715	                              'typically binary Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) or executables (EXE).(Citation: Microsoft '
11716	                              'COM) Remote COM execution is facilitated by [Remote '
11717	                              'Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as  [Distributed Component '
11718	                              'Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) (DCOM).(Citation: Fireeye '
11719	                              'Hunting COM June 2019)\n'
11720	                              '\n'
11721	                              'Various COM interfaces are exposed that can be abused to invoke arbitrary execution via '
11722	                              'a variety of programming languages such as C, C++, Java, and [Visual '
11723	                              'Basic](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/005).(Citation: Microsoft COM) '
11724	                              'Specific COM objects also exist to directly perform functions beyond code execution, '
11725	                              'such as creating a [Scheduled Task/Job](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053), '
11726	                              'fileless download/execution, and other adversary behaviors related to privilege '
11727	                              'escalation and persistence.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019)(Citation: '
11728	                              'ProjectZero File Write EoP Apr 2018)',
11729	               'name': 'Component Object Model',

11732	               'categories': ['execution'],
11733	               'description': 'Adversaries may use Windows Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) to execute arbitrary commands. '
11734	                              'DDE is a client-server protocol for one-time and/or continuous inter-process '
11735	                              'communication (IPC) between applications. Once a link is established, applications can '
11736	                              'autonomously exchange transactions consisting of strings, warm data links '
11737	                              '(notifications when a data item changes), hot data links (duplications of changes to a '
11738	                              'data item), and requests for command execution.\n'
11739	                              '\n'
11740	                              'Object Linking and Embedding (OLE), or the ability to link data between documents, was '
11741	                              'originally implemented through DDE. Despite being superseded by [Component Object '
11742	                              'Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/001), DDE may be enabled in Windows 10 '
11743	                              'and most of Microsoft Office 2016 via Registry keys.(Citation: BleepingComputer DDE '
11744	                              'Disabled in Word Dec 2017)(Citation: Microsoft ADV170021 Dec 2017)(Citation: Microsoft '
11745	                              'DDE Advisory Nov 2017)\n'
11746	                              '\n'
11747	                              'Microsoft Office documents can be poisoned with DDE commands, directly or through '
11748	                              'embedded files, and used to deliver execution via '
11749	                              '[Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) campaigns or hosted Web content, '
11750	                              'avoiding the use of Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros.(Citation: SensePost PS '
11751	                              'DDE May 2016)(Citation: Kettle CSV DDE Aug 2014)(Citation: Enigma Reviving DDE Jan '
11752	                              '2018)(Citation: SensePost MacroLess DDE Oct 2017) Similarly, adversaries may infect '
11753	                              'payloads to execute applications and/or commands on a victim device by way of embedding '
11754	                              'DDE formulas within a CSV file intended to be opened through a Windows spreadsheet '
11755	                              'program.(Citation: OWASP CSV Injection)(Citation: CSV Excel Macro Injection )\n'
11756	                              '\n'
11757	                              'DDE could also be leveraged by an adversary operating on a compromised machine who does '
11758	                              'not have direct access to a [Command and Scripting '
11759	                              'Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059). DDE execution can be invoked '
11760	                              'remotely via [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as '
11761	                              '[Distributed Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) '
11762	                              '(DCOM).(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019)',

11767	               'description': 'Adversaries can provide malicious content to an XPC service daemon for local code '
11768	                              'execution. macOS uses XPC services for basic inter-process communication between '
11769	                              'various processes, such as between the XPC Service daemon and third-party application '
11770	                              'privileged helper tools. Applications can send messages to the XPC Service daemon, '
11771	                              'which runs as root, using the low-level XPC Service <code>C API</code> or the high '
11772	                              'level <code>NSXPCConnection API</code> in order to handle tasks that require elevated '
11773	                              'privileges (such as network connections). Applications are responsible for providing '
11774	                              'the protocol definition which serves as a blueprint of the XPC services. Developers '
11775	                              'typically use XPC Services to provide applications stability and privilege separation '
11776	                              'between the application client and the daemon.(Citation: creatingXPCservices)(Citation: '
11777	                              'Designing Daemons Apple Dev)\n'
11778	                              '\n'
11779	                              'Adversaries can abuse XPC services to execute malicious content. Requests for malicious '
11780	                              "execution can be passed through the application's XPC Services handler.(Citation: "
11781	                              'CVMServer Vuln)(Citation: Learn XPC Exploitation) This may also include identifying and '
11782	                              'abusing improper XPC client validation and/or poor sanitization of input parameters to '

11945	               'description': 'Adversaries may modify and/or disable security tools to avoid possible detection of '
11946	                              'their malware/tools and activities. This may take many forms, such as killing security '
11947	                              'software processes or services, modifying / deleting Registry keys or configuration '
11948	                              'files so that tools do not operate properly, or other methods to interfere with '
11949	                              'security tools scanning or reporting information. Adversaries may also disable updates '
11950	                              'to prevent the latest security patches from reaching tools on victim systems.(Citation: '
11951	                              'SCADAfence_ransomware)\n'
11952	                              '\n'
11953	                              'Adversaries may also tamper with artifacts deployed and utilized by security tools. '
11954	                              'Security tools may make dynamic changes to system components in order to maintain '
11955	                              'visibility into specific events. For example, security products may load their own '
11956	                              'modules and/or modify those loaded by processes to facilitate data collection. Similar '
11957	                              'to [Indicator Blocking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/006), adversaries may '
11958	                              'unhook or otherwise modify these features added by tools (especially those that exist '
11959	                              'in userland or are otherwise potentially accessible to adversaries) to avoid '
11960	                              'detection.(Citation: OutFlank System Calls)(Citation: MDSec System Calls) \n'
11961	                              '\n'
11962	                              'Adversaries may also focus on specific applications such as Sysmon. For example, the '
11963	                              '“Start” and “Enable” values in '
11964	                              '<code>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\WMI\\Autologger\\EventLog-Microsoft-Windows-Sysmon-Operational</code> '
11965	                              'may be modified to tamper with and potentially disable Sysmon logging.(Citation: '
11966	                              'disable_win_evt_logging) \n'
11967	                              '\n'
11968	                              'On network devices, adversaries may attempt to skip digital signature verification '
11969	                              'checks by altering startup configuration files and effectively disabling firmware '
11970	                              'verification that typically occurs at boot.(Citation: Fortinet Zero-Day and Custom '
11971	                              'Malware Used by Suspected Chinese Actor in Espionage Operation)(Citation: Analysis of '
11972	                              'FG-IR-22-369)\n'
11973	                              '\n'
11974	                              'In cloud environments, tools disabled by adversaries may include cloud monitoring '
11975	                              'agents that report back to services such as AWS CloudWatch or Google Cloud Monitor.\n'
11976	                              '\n'
11977	                              'Furthermore, although defensive tools may have anti-tampering mechanisms, adversaries '
11978	                              'may abuse tools such as legitimate rootkit removal kits to impair and/or disable these '
11979	                              'tools.(Citation: chasing_avaddon_ransomware)(Citation: dharma_ransomware)(Citation: '
11980	                              'demystifying_ryuk)(Citation: doppelpaymer_crowdstrike) For example, adversaries have '
11981	                              'used tools such as GMER to find and shut down hidden processes and antivirus software '
11982	                              'on infected systems.(Citation: demystifying_ryuk)\n'
11983	                              '\n'

11985	                              'gain access to kernel space (i.e. [Exploitation for Privilege '
11986	                              'Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068)), which may lead to bypassing '
11987	                              'anti-tampering features.(Citation: avoslocker_ransomware)',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:12046
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
12045	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
12046	               'description': 'Adversaries may impair command history logging to hide commands they run on a '
12047	                              'compromised system. Various command interpreters keep track of the commands users type '
12048	                              "in their terminal so that users can retrace what they've done. \n"
12049	                              '\n'
12050	                              'On Linux and macOS, command history is tracked in a file pointed to by the environment '
12051	                              'variable <code>HISTFILE</code>. When a user logs off a system, this information is '
12052	                              "flushed to a file in the user's home directory called <code>~/.bash_history</code>. The "
12053	                              '<code>HISTCONTROL</code> environment variable keeps track of what should be saved by '
12054	                              'the <code>history</code> command and eventually into the <code>~/.bash_history</code> '
12055	                              'file when a user logs out. <code>HISTCONTROL</code> does not exist by default on macOS, '
12056	                              'but can be set by the user and will be respected.\n'
12057	                              '\n'
12058	                              'Adversaries may clear the history environment variable (<code>unset HISTFILE</code>) or '
12059	                              'set the command history size to zero (<code>export HISTFILESIZE=0</code>) to prevent '
12060	                              'logging of commands. Additionally, <code>HISTCONTROL</code> can be configured to ignore '
12061	                              'commands that start with a space by simply setting it to "ignorespace". '
12062	                              '<code>HISTCONTROL</code> can also be set to ignore duplicate commands by setting it to '
12063	                              '"ignoredups". In some Linux systems, this is set by default to "ignoreboth" which '
12064	                              'covers both of the previous examples. This means that “ ls” will not be saved, but “ls” '
12065	                              'would be saved by history. Adversaries can abuse this to operate without leaving traces '
12066	                              'by simply prepending a space to all of their terminal commands. \n'
12067	                              '\n'
12068	                              'On Windows systems, the <code>PSReadLine</code> module tracks commands used in all '
12069	                              'PowerShell sessions and writes them to a file '
12070	                              '(<code>$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Windows\\PowerShell\\PSReadLine\\ConsoleHost_history.txt</code> '
12071	                              'by default). Adversaries may change where these logs are saved using '
12072	                              '<code>Set-PSReadLineOption -HistorySavePath {File Path}</code>. This will cause '
12073	                              '<code>ConsoleHost_history.txt</code> to stop receiving logs. Additionally, it is '
12074	                              'possible to turn off logging to this file using the PowerShell command '
12075	                              '<code>Set-PSReadlineOption -HistorySaveStyle SaveNothing</code>.(Citation: Microsoft '
12076	                              'PowerShell Command History)(Citation: Sophos PowerShell command audit)(Citation: Sophos '
12077	                              'PowerShell Command History Forensics)\n'
12078	                              '\n'
12079	                              'Adversaries may also leverage a [Network Device '
12080	                              'CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) on network devices to disable '
12081	                              'historical command logging (e.g. <code>no logging</code>).',
12082	               'name': 'Impair Command History Logging',
12083	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS', 'Windows', 'Network']},

12295	                              'environment. Secure Shell (SSH) is a standard means of remote access on Linux and macOS '
12296	                              'systems. It allows a user to connect to another system via an encrypted tunnel, '
12297	                              'commonly authenticating through a password, certificate or the use of an asymmetric '
12298	                              'encryption key pair.\n'
12299	                              '\n'
12300	                              'In order to move laterally from a compromised host, adversaries may take advantage of '
12301	                              'trust relationships established with other systems via public key authentication in '
12302	                              'active SSH sessions by hijacking an existing connection to another system. This may '
12303	                              "occur through compromising the SSH agent itself or by having access to the agent's "
12304	                              'socket. If an adversary is able to obtain root access, then hijacking SSH sessions is '
12305	                              'likely trivial.(Citation: Slideshare Abusing SSH)(Citation: SSHjack Blackhat)(Citation: '
12306	                              'Clockwork SSH Agent Hijacking)(Citation: Breach Post-mortem SSH Hijack)\n'
12307	                              '\n'

12317	                              'within an environment. Remote desktop is a common feature in operating systems. It '
12318	                              'allows a user to log into an interactive session with a system desktop graphical user '
12319	                              'interface on a remote system. Microsoft refers to its implementation of the Remote '
12320	                              'Desktop Protocol (RDP) as Remote Desktop Services (RDS).(Citation: TechNet Remote '
12321	                              'Desktop Services)\n'
12322	                              '\n'
12323	                              'Adversaries may perform RDP session hijacking which involves stealing a legitimate '
12324	                              "user's remote session. Typically, a user is notified when someone else is trying to "
12325	                              'steal their session. With System permissions and using Terminal Services Console, '
12326	                              '`c:\\windows\\system32\\tscon.exe [session number to be stolen]`, an adversary can '
12327	                              'hijack a session without the need for credentials or prompts to the user.(Citation: RDP '
12328	                              'Hijacking Korznikov) This can be done remotely or locally and with active or '
12329	                              'disconnected sessions.(Citation: RDP Hijacking Medium) It can also lead to [Remote '
12330	                              'System Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1018) and Privilege Escalation '
12331	                              'by stealing a Domain Admin or higher privileged account session. All of this can be '
12332	                              'done by using native Windows commands, but it has also been added as a feature in red '
12333	                              'teaming tools.(Citation: Kali Redsnarf)',

12429	                              '(plist) files. One of the tags in these files can be <code>apple.awt.UIElement</code>, '
12430	                              "which allows for Java applications to prevent the application's icon from appearing in "
12431	                              "the Dock. A common use for this is when applications run in the system tray, but don't "

12436	                              'Basic](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/005) to make windows hidden. One '
12437	                              'example of this is <code>powershell.exe -WindowStyle Hidden</code>.(Citation: '

12439	                              '\n'
12440	                              'In addition, Windows supports the `CreateDesktop()` API that can create a hidden '
12441	                              'desktop window with its own corresponding <code>explorer.exe</code> process.(Citation: '
12442	                              'Hidden VNC)(Citation: Anatomy of an hVNC Attack)  All applications running on the '
12443	                              'hidden desktop window, such as a hidden VNC (hVNC) session,(Citation: Hidden VNC) will '
12444	                              'be invisible to other desktops windows.',

12534	               'description': "Adversaries may use email rules to hide inbound emails in a compromised user's mailbox. "
12535	                              'Many email clients allow users to create inbox rules for various email functions, '
12536	                              'including moving emails to other folders, marking emails as read, or deleting emails. '
12537	                              'Rules may be created or modified within email clients or through external features such '
12538	                              'as the <code>New-InboxRule</code> or <code>Set-InboxRule</code> '
12539	                              '[PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) cmdlets on Windows '
12540	                              'systems.(Citation: Microsoft Inbox Rules)(Citation: MacOS Email Rules)(Citation: '
12541	                              'Microsoft New-InboxRule)(Citation: Microsoft Set-InboxRule)\n'
12542	                              '\n'
12543	                              "Adversaries may utilize email rules within a compromised user's mailbox to delete "
12544	                              'and/or move emails to less noticeable folders. Adversaries may do this to hide security '
12545	                              'alerts, C2 communication, or responses to [Internal '
12546	                              'Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534) emails sent from the '
12547	                              'compromised account.\n'
12548	                              '\n'
12549	                              'Any user or administrator within the organization (or adversary with valid credentials) '
12550	                              'may be able to create rules to automatically move or delete emails. These rules can be '
12551	                              'abused to impair/delay detection had the email content been immediately seen by a user '
12552	                              'or defender. Malicious rules commonly filter out emails based on key words (such as '
12553	                              '<code>malware</code>, <code>suspicious</code>, <code>phish</code>, and '
12554	                              '<code>hack</code>) found in message bodies and subject lines. (Citation: Microsoft '
12555	                              'Cloud App Security)\n'
12556	                              '\n'
12557	                              'In some environments, administrators may be able to enable email rules that operate '
12558	                              'organization-wide rather than on individual inboxes. For example, Microsoft Exchange '
12559	                              'supports transport rules that evaluate all mail an organization receives against '
12560	                              'user-specified conditions, then performs a user-specified action on mail that adheres '
12561	                              'to those conditions.(Citation: Microsoft Mail Flow Rules 2023) Adversaries that abuse '
12562	                              'such features may be able to automatically modify or delete all emails related to '
12563	                              'specific topics (such as internal security incident notifications).',

12587	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
12588	               'description': 'Adversaries may attempt to hide process command-line arguments by overwriting process '
12589	                              'memory. Process command-line arguments are stored in the process environment block '
12590	                              '(PEB), a data structure used by Windows to store various information about/used by a '
12591	                              'process. The PEB includes the process command-line arguments that are referenced when '
12592	                              'executing the process. When a process is created, defensive tools/sensors that monitor '
12593	                              'process creations may retrieve the process arguments from the PEB.(Citation: Microsoft '
12594	                              'PEB 2021)(Citation: Xpn Argue Like Cobalt 2019)\n'
12595	                              '\n'
12596	                              'Adversaries may manipulate a process PEB to evade defenses. For example, [Process '
12597	                              'Hollowing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/012) can be abused to spawn a '
12598	                              'process in a suspended state with benign arguments. After the process is spawned and '
12599	                              'the PEB is initialized (and process information is potentially logged by '
12600	                              'tools/sensors), adversaries may override the PEB to modify the command-line arguments '
12601	                              '(ex: using the [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) '
12602	                              '<code>WriteProcessMemory()</code> function) then resume process execution with '
12603	                              'malicious arguments.(Citation: Cobalt Strike Arguments 2019)(Citation: Xpn Argue Like '
12604	                              'Cobalt 2019)(Citation: Nviso Spoof Command Line 2020)\n'
12605	                              '\n'
12606	                              'Adversaries may also execute a process with malicious command-line arguments then patch '
12607	                              'the memory with benign arguments that may bypass subsequent process memory '
12608	                              'analysis.(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)\n'
12609	                              '\n'
12610	                              'This behavior may also be combined with other tricks (such as [Parent PID '
12611	                              'Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1134/004)) to manipulate or further '
12612	                              'evade process-based detections.',
12613	               'name': 'Process Argument Spoofing',
12614	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

12618	                              'interrupt signals. Many operating systems use signals to deliver messages to control '
12619	                              'process behavior. Command interpreters often include specific commands/flags that '
12620	                              'ignore errors and other hangups, such as when the user of the active session logs '
12621	                              'off.(Citation: Linux Signal Man)  These interrupt signals may also be used by defensive '
12622	                              'tools and/or analysts to pause or terminate specified running processes. \n'
12623	                              '\n'
12624	                              'Adversaries may invoke processes using `nohup`, '
12625	                              '[PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) `-ErrorAction '
12626	                              'SilentlyContinue`, or similar commands that may be immune to hangups.(Citation: nohup '
12627	                              'Linux Man)(Citation: Microsoft PowerShell SilentlyContinue) This may enable malicious '
12628	                              'commands and malware to continue execution through system events that would otherwise '
12629	                              'terminate its execution, such as users logging off or the termination of its C2 network '
12630	                              'connection.\n'
12631	                              '\n'
12632	                              'Hiding from process interrupt signals may allow malware to continue execution, but '
12633	                              'unlike [Trap](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/005) this does not establish '
12634	                              '[Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003) since the process will not be '
12635	                              're-invoked once actually terminated.',

12728	                          'phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known '
12729	                          'as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be '
12730	                          'targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, '
12731	                          'such as in mass malware spam campaigns.\n'
12732	                          '\n'
12733	                          'Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to '
12734	                          'execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party '
12735	                          'services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering '
12736	                          'techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as '
12737	                          'removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused '
12738	                          'to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding '
12739	                          'Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam '
12740	                          '2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is '
12741	                          'by forging or spoofing(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender which can be '
12742	                          'used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools.(Citation: '
12743	                          'cyberproof-double-bounce) \n'

12753	               'categories': ['initial-access'],
12754	               'description': 'Adversaries may send spearphishing emails with a malicious attachment in an attempt to '
12755	                              'gain access to victim systems. Spearphishing attachment is a specific variant of '
12756	                              'spearphishing. Spearphishing attachment is different from other forms of spearphishing '
12757	                              'in that it employs the use of malware attached to an email. All forms of spearphishing '
12758	                              'are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at a specific individual, '
12759	                              'company, or industry. In this scenario, adversaries attach a file to the spearphishing '
12760	                              'email and usually rely upon [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) '
12761	                              'to gain execution.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018) Spearphishing may also '
12762	                              'involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source.\n'
12763	                              '\n'
12764	                              'There are many options for the attachment such as Microsoft Office documents, '
12765	                              'executables, PDFs, or archived files. Upon opening the attachment (and potentially '
12766	                              "clicking past protections), the adversary's payload exploits a vulnerability or "
12767	                              "directly executes on the user's system. The text of the spearphishing email usually "
12768	                              'tries to give a plausible reason why the file should be opened, and may explain how to '
12769	                              'bypass system protections in order to do so. The email may also contain instructions on '
12770	                              'how to decrypt an attachment, such as a zip file password, in order to evade email '
12771	                              'boundary defenses. Adversaries frequently manipulate file extensions and icons in order '
12772	                              'to make attached executables appear to be document files, or files exploiting one '
12773	                              'application appear to be a file for a different one. ',
12774	               'name': 'Spearphishing Attachment',

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:12778
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
12777	               'categories': ['initial-access'],
12778	               'description': 'Adversaries may send spearphishing emails with a malicious link in an attempt to gain '
12779	                              'access to victim systems. Spearphishing with a link is a specific variant of '
12780	                              'spearphishing. It is different from other forms of spearphishing in that it employs the '
12781	                              'use of links to download malware contained in email, instead of attaching malicious '
12782	                              'files to the email itself, to avoid defenses that may inspect email attachments. '
12783	                              'Spearphishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a '
12784	                              'trusted source.\n'
12785	                              '\n'
12786	                              'All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at '
12787	                              'a specific individual, company, or industry. In this case, the malicious emails contain '
12788	                              'links. Generally, the links will be accompanied by social engineering text and require '
12789	                              'the user to actively click or copy and paste a URL into a browser, leveraging [User '
12790	                              'Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204). The visited website may '
12791	                              'compromise the web browser using an exploit, or the user will be prompted to download '
12792	                              'applications, documents, zip files, or even executables depending on the pretext for '
12793	                              'the email in the first place.\n'
12794	                              '\n'
12795	                              'Adversaries may also include links that are intended to interact directly with an email '
12796	                              'reader, including embedded images intended to exploit the end system directly. '
12797	                              'Additionally, adversaries may use seemingly benign links that abuse special characters '
12798	                              'to mimic legitimate websites (known as an "IDN homograph attack").(Citation: CISA IDN '
12799	                              'ST05-016) URLs may also be obfuscated by taking advantage of quirks in the URL schema, '
12800	                              'such as the acceptance of integer- or hexadecimal-based hostname formats and the '
12801	                              'automatic discarding of text before an “@” symbol: for example, '
12802	                              '`hxxp://google.com@1157586937`.(Citation: Mandiant URL Obfuscation 2023)\n'
12803	                              '\n'
12804	                              'Adversaries may also utilize links to perform consent phishing, typically with OAuth '
12805	                              '2.0 request URLs that when accepted by the user provide permissions/access for '
12806	                              'malicious applications, allowing adversaries to  [Steal Application Access '
12807	                              'Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)s.(Citation: Trend Micro Pawn Storm '
12808	                              'OAuth 2017) These stolen access tokens allow the adversary to perform various actions '
12809	                              'on behalf of the user via API calls. (Citation: Microsoft OAuth 2.0 Consent Phishing '
12810	                              '2021)\n'
12811	                              '\n'
12812	                              'Adversaries may also utilize spearphishing links to [Steal Application Access '
12813	                              'Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)s that grant immediate access to the '
12814	                              'victim environment. For example, a user may be lured through “consent phishing” into '
12815	                              'granting adversaries permissions/access via a malicious OAuth 2.0 request URL '
12816	                              '.(Citation: Trend Micro Pawn Storm OAuth 2017)(Citation: Microsoft OAuth 2.0 Consent '
12817	                              'Phishing 2021)\n'
12818	                              '\n'
12819	                              'Similarly, malicious links may also target device-based authorization, such as OAuth '
12820	                              '2.0 device authorization grant flow which is typically used to authenticate devices '
12821	                              'without UIs/browsers. Known as “device code phishing,” an adversary may send a link '
12822	                              'that directs the victim to a malicious authorization page where the user is tricked '

13004	                              'istgmxdejdnxuyla.ru) when they construct domain names by generating each letter. '
13005	                              'Alternatively, some DGAs employ whole words as the unit by concatenating words together '
13006	                              'instead of letters (ex: cityjulydish.net). Many DGAs are time-based, generating a '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:13119

13118	           'categories': ['command-and-control'],
13119	           'description': 'Adversaries may tunnel network communications to and from a victim system within a separate '
13120	                          'protocol to avoid detection/network filtering and/or enable access to otherwise unreachable '
13121	                          'systems. Tunneling involves explicitly encapsulating a protocol within another. This '
13122	                          'behavior may conceal malicious traffic by blending in with existing traffic and/or provide '
13123	                          'an outer layer of encryption (similar to a VPN). Tunneling could also enable routing of '
13124	                          'network packets that would otherwise not reach their intended destination, such as SMB, '
13125	                          'RDP, or other traffic that would be filtered by network appliances or not routed over the '
13126	                          'Internet. \n'
13127	                          '\n'
13128	                          'There are various means to encapsulate a protocol within another protocol. For example, '
13129	                          'adversaries may perform SSH tunneling (also known as SSH port forwarding), which involves '
13130	                          'forwarding arbitrary data over an encrypted SSH tunnel.(Citation: SSH Tunneling) \n'
13131	                          '\n'
13132	                          '[Protocol Tunneling](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572) may also be abused by '
13133	                          'adversaries during [Dynamic Resolution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1568). Known '
13134	                          'as DNS over HTTPS (DoH), queries to resolve C2 infrastructure may be encapsulated within '
13135	                          'encrypted HTTPS packets.(Citation: BleepingComp Godlua JUL19) \n'
13136	                          '\n'
13137	                          'Adversaries may also leverage [Protocol '
13138	                          'Tunneling](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572) in conjunction with '
13139	                          '[Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090) and/or [Protocol '
13140	                          'Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1001/003) to further conceal C2 '
13141	                          'communications and infrastructure. ',

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:13164
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
13163	               'categories': ['command-and-control'],
13164	               'description': 'Adversaries may employ a known asymmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and '
13165	                              'control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a '
13166	                              'communication protocol. Asymmetric cryptography, also known as public key cryptography, '
13167	                              'uses a keypair per party: one public that can be freely distributed, and one private. '
13168	                              'Due to how the keys are generated, the sender encrypts data with the receiver’s public '
13169	                              'key and the receiver decrypts the data with their private key. This ensures that only '
13170	                              'the intended recipient can read the encrypted data. Common public key encryption '
13171	                              'algorithms include RSA and ElGamal.\n'
13172	                              '\n'
13173	                              'For efficiency, many protocols (including SSL/TLS) use symmetric cryptography once a '
13174	                              'connection is established, but use asymmetric cryptography to establish or transmit a '
13175	                              'key. As such, these protocols are classified as [Asymmetric '
13176	                              'Cryptography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1573/002).',

13236	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
13237	               'description': 'Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by side-loading DLLs. Similar to '
13238	                              '[DLL Search Order Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/001), '
13239	                              'side-loading involves hijacking which DLL a program loads. But rather than just '
13240	                              'planting the DLL within the search order of a program then waiting for the victim '
13241	                              'application to be invoked, adversaries may directly side-load their payloads by '
13242	                              'planting then invoking a legitimate application that executes their payload(s).\n'
13243	                              '\n'
13244	                              'Side-loading takes advantage of the DLL search order used by the loader by positioning '
13245	                              'both the victim application and malicious payload(s) alongside each other. Adversaries '
13246	                              'likely use side-loading as a means of masking actions they perform under a legitimate, '
13247	                              'trusted, and potentially elevated system or software process. Benign executables used '
13248	                              'to side-load payloads may not be flagged during delivery and/or execution. Adversary '
13249	                              'payloads may also be encrypted/packed or otherwise obfuscated until loaded into the '
13250	                              'memory of the trusted process.(Citation: FireEye DLL Side-Loading)',

13279	               'description': 'Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the binaries used by '
13280	                              'an installer. These processes may automatically execute specific binaries as part of '
13281	                              'their functionality or to perform other actions. If the permissions on the file system '
13282	                              'directory containing a target binary, or permissions on the binary itself, are '
13283	                              'improperly set, then the target binary may be overwritten with another binary using '
13284	                              'user-level permissions and executed by the original process. If the original process '
13285	                              'and thread are running under a higher permissions level, then the replaced binary will '
13286	                              'also execute under higher-level permissions, which could include SYSTEM.\n'
13287	                              '\n'
13288	                              'Another variation of this technique can be performed by taking advantage of a weakness '
13289	                              'that is common in executable, self-extracting installers. During the installation '
13290	                              'process, it is common for installers to use a subdirectory within the '
13291	                              '<code>%TEMP%</code> directory to unpack binaries such as DLLs, EXEs, or other payloads. '
13292	                              'When installers create subdirectories and files they often do not set appropriate '
13293	                              'permissions to restrict write access, which allows for execution of untrusted code '
13294	                              'placed in the subdirectories or overwriting of binaries used in the installation '
13295	                              'process. This behavior is related to and may take advantage of [DLL Search Order '
13296	                              'Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/001).\n'
13297	                              '\n'
13298	                              'Adversaries may use this technique to replace legitimate binaries with malicious ones '
13299	                              'as a means of executing code at a higher permissions level. Some installers may also '
13300	                              'require elevated privileges that will result in privilege escalation when executing '
13301	                              'adversary controlled code. This behavior is related to [Bypass User Account '
13302	                              'Control](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1548/002). Several examples of this '
13303	                              'weakness in existing common installers have been reported to software '
13304	                              'vendors.(Citation: mozilla_sec_adv_2012)  (Citation: Executable Installers are '
13305	                              'Vulnerable) If the executing process is set to run at a specific time or during a '
13306	                              'certain event (e.g., system bootup) then this technique can also be used for '
13307	                              'persistence.',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:13312
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
13311	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
13312	               'description': 'Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking environment variables '
13313	                              'the dynamic linker uses to load shared libraries. During the execution preparation '
13314	                              'phase of a program, the dynamic linker loads specified absolute paths of shared '
13315	                              'libraries from environment variables and files, such as <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> on '
13316	                              'Linux or <code>DYLD_INSERT_LIBRARIES</code> on macOS. Libraries specified in '
13317	                              'environment variables are loaded first, taking precedence over system libraries with '
13318	                              'the same function name.(Citation: Man LD.SO)(Citation: TLDP Shared Libraries)(Citation: '
13319	                              'Apple Doco Archive Dynamic Libraries) These variables are often used by developers to '
13320	                              'debug binaries without needing to recompile, deconflict mapped symbols, and implement '
13321	                              'custom functions without changing the original library.(Citation: Baeldung LD_PRELOAD)\n'
13322	                              '\n'
13323	                              'On Linux and macOS, hijacking dynamic linker variables may grant access to the victim '
13324	                              "process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. This "
13325	                              'method may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked '
13326	                              'under a legitimate process. Adversaries can set environment variables via the command '
13327	                              'line using the <code>export</code> command, <code>setenv</code> function, or '
13328	                              '<code>putenv</code> function. Adversaries can also leverage [Dynamic Linker '
13329	                              'Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/006) to export variables in a '
13330	                              'shell or set variables programmatically using higher level syntax such Python’s '
13331	                              '<code>os.environ</code>.\n'
13332	                              '\n'
13333	                              'On Linux, adversaries may set <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> to point to malicious libraries '
13334	                              'that match the name of legitimate libraries which are requested by a victim program, '
13335	                              "causing the operating system to load the adversary's malicious code upon execution of "
13336	                              'the victim program. <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> can be set via the environment variable or '
13337	                              '<code>/etc/ld.so.preload</code> file.(Citation: Man LD.SO)(Citation: TLDP Shared '
13338	                              'Libraries) Libraries specified by <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> are loaded and mapped into '
13339	                              'memory by <code>dlopen()</code> and <code>mmap()</code> respectively.(Citation: Code '
13340	                              'Injection on Linux and macOS)(Citation: Uninformed Needle) (Citation: Phrack halfdead '
13341	                              '1997)(Citation: Brown Exploiting Linkers) \n'
13342	                              '\n'
13343	                              'On macOS this behavior is conceptually the same as on Linux, differing only in how the '
13344	                              'macOS dynamic libraries (dyld) is implemented at a lower level. Adversaries can set the '
13345	                              '<code>DYLD_INSERT_LIBRARIES</code> environment variable to point to malicious libraries '
13346	                              'containing names of legitimate libraries or functions requested by a victim '
13347	                              'program.(Citation: TheEvilBit DYLD_INSERT_LIBRARIES)(Citation: Timac '
13348	                              'DYLD_INSERT_LIBRARIES)(Citation: Gabilondo DYLD_INSERT_LIBRARIES Catalina Bypass) ',
13349	               'name': 'Dynamic Linker Hijacking',
13350	               'platforms': ['Linux', 'macOS']},

13352	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
13353	               'description': 'Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking environment variables '
13354	                              'used to load libraries. The PATH environment variable contains a list of directories '
13355	                              '(User and System) that the OS searches sequentially through in search of the binary '
13356	                              'that was called from a script or the command line. \n'
13357	                              '\n'
13358	                              'Adversaries can place a malicious program in an earlier entry in the list of '
13359	                              'directories stored in the PATH environment variable, resulting in the operating system '
13360	                              'executing the malicious binary rather than the legitimate binary when it searches '
13361	                              'sequentially through that PATH listing.\n'
13362	                              '\n'
13363	                              'For example, on Windows if an adversary places a malicious program named "net.exe" in '
13364	                              '`C:\\example path`, which by default precedes `C:\\Windows\\system32\\net.exe` in the '
13365	                              'PATH environment variable, when "net" is executed from the command-line the '
13366	                              "`C:\\example path` will be called instead of the system's legitimate executable at "
13367	                              '`C:\\Windows\\system32\\net.exe`. Some methods of executing a program rely on the PATH '
13368	                              'environment variable to determine the locations that are searched when the path for the '
13369	                              'program is not given, such as executing programs from a [Command and Scripting '
13370	                              'Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059).(Citation: ExpressVPN PATH env '
13371	                              'Windows 2021)\n'
13372	                              '\n'
13373	                              'Adversaries may also directly modify the $PATH variable specifying the directories to '
13374	                              'be searched.  An adversary can modify the `$PATH` variable to point to a directory they '
13375	                              'have write access. When a program using the $PATH variable is called, the OS searches '
13376	                              'the specified directory and executes the malicious binary. On macOS, this can also be '
13377	                              'performed through modifying the $HOME variable. These variables can be modified using '
13378	                              'the command-line, launchctl, [Unix Shell Configuration '
13379	                              'Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/004), or modifying the '
13380	                              '`/etc/paths.d` folder contents.(Citation: uptycs Fake POC linux malware 2023)(Citation: '
13381	                              'nixCraft macOS PATH variables)(Citation: Elastic Rules macOS launchctl 2022)',
13382	               'name': 'Path Interception by PATH Environment Variable',
13383	               'platforms': ['Windows', 'macOS', 'Linux']},
