   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:13386
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
13385	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
13386	               'description': 'Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the search order used '
13387	                              'to load other programs. Because some programs do not call other programs using the full '
13388	                              'path, adversaries may place their own file in the directory where the calling program '
13389	                              'is located, causing the operating system to launch their malicious software at the '
13390	                              'request of the calling program.\n'
13391	                              '\n'
13392	                              'Search order hijacking occurs when an adversary abuses the order in which Windows '
13393	                              'searches for programs that are not given a path. Unlike [DLL Search Order '
13394	                              'Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/001), the search order differs '
13395	                              'depending on the method that is used to execute the program. (Citation: Microsoft '
13396	                              'CreateProcess) (Citation: Windows NT Command Shell) (Citation: Microsoft WinExec) '
13397	                              'However, it is common for Windows to search in the directory of the initiating program '
13398	                              'before searching through the Windows system directory. An adversary who finds a program '
13399	                              'vulnerable to search order hijacking (i.e., a program that does not specify the path to '
13400	                              'an executable) may take advantage of this vulnerability by creating a program named '
13401	                              "after the improperly specified program and placing it within the initiating program's "
13402	                              'directory.\n'
13403	                              '\n'
13404	                              'For example, "example.exe" runs "cmd.exe" with the command-line argument <code>net '
13405	                              'user</code>. An adversary may place a program called "net.exe" within the same '
13406	                              'directory as example.exe, "net.exe" will be run instead of the Windows system utility '
13407	                              'net. In addition, if an adversary places a program called "net.com" in the same '
13408	                              'directory as "net.exe", then <code>cmd.exe /C net user</code> will execute "net.com" '
13409	                              'instead of "net.exe" due to the order of executable extensions defined under PATHEXT. '
13410	                              '(Citation: Microsoft Environment Property)\n'
13411	                              '\n'
13412	                              'Search order hijacking is also a common practice for hijacking DLL loads and is covered '
13413	                              'in [DLL Search Order Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/001).',
13414	               'name': 'Path Interception by Search Order Hijacking',
13415	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

13461	               'description': 'Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries '
13462	                              'used by services. Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions for Registry keys '
13463	                              'related to services to redirect from the originally specified executable to one that '
13464	                              'they control, in order to launch their own code when a service starts. Windows stores '
13465	                              'local service configuration information in the Registry under '
13466	                              '<code>HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Services</code>. The information stored under a '
13467	                              "service's Registry keys can be manipulated to modify a service's execution parameters "
13468	                              'through tools such as the service controller, sc.exe,  '
13469	                              '[PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001), or '
13470	                              '[Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075). Access to Registry keys is controlled '
13471	                              'through access control lists and user permissions. (Citation: Registry Key '
13472	                              'Security)(Citation: malware_hides_service)\n'
13473	                              '\n'
13474	                              'If the permissions for users and groups are not properly set and allow access to the '
13475	                              "Registry keys for a service, adversaries may change the service's binPath/ImagePath to "
13476	                              'point to a different executable under their control. When the service starts or is '
13477	                              'restarted, then the adversary-controlled program will execute, allowing the adversary '
13478	                              'to establish persistence and/or privilege escalation to the account context the service '
13479	                              'is set to execute under (local/domain account, SYSTEM, LocalService, or '
13480	                              'NetworkService).\n'
13481	                              '\n'

13483	                              'example, the <code>FailureCommand</code> key may be changed so that the service is '
13484	                              'executed in an elevated context anytime the service fails or is intentionally '
13485	                              'corrupted.(Citation: Kansa Service related collectors)(Citation: Tweet Registry Perms '
13486	                              'Weakness)\n'
13487	                              '\n'
13488	                              "The <code>Performance</code> key contains the name of a driver service's performance "
13489	                              'DLL and the names of several exported functions in the DLL.(Citation: '
13490	                              'microsoft_services_registry_tree) If the <code>Performance</code> key is not already '
13491	                              'present and if an adversary-controlled user has the <code>Create Subkey</code> '
13492	                              'permission, adversaries may create the <code>Performance</code> key in the service’s '
13493	                              'Registry tree to point to a malicious DLL.(Citation: insecure_reg_perms)\n'
13494	                              '\n'
13495	                              'Adversaries may also add the <code>Parameters</code> key, which stores driver-specific '
13496	                              'data, or other custom subkeys for their malicious services to establish persistence or '

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:13507
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
13506	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
13507	               'description': 'Adversaries may leverage the COR_PROFILER environment variable to hijack the execution '
13508	                              'flow of programs that load the .NET CLR. The COR_PROFILER is a .NET Framework feature '
13509	                              'which allows developers to specify an unmanaged (or external of .NET) profiling DLL to '
13510	                              'be loaded into each .NET process that loads the Common Language Runtime (CLR). These '
13511	                              'profilers are designed to monitor, troubleshoot, and debug managed code executed by the '
13512	                              '.NET CLR.(Citation: Microsoft Profiling Mar 2017)(Citation: Microsoft COR_PROFILER Feb '
13513	                              '2013)\n'
13514	                              '\n'
13515	                              'The COR_PROFILER environment variable can be set at various scopes (system, user, or '
13516	                              'process) resulting in different levels of influence. System and user-wide environment '
13517	                              'variable scopes are specified in the Registry, where a [Component Object '
13518	                              'Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/001) (COM) object can be registered as '
13519	                              'a profiler DLL. A process scope COR_PROFILER can also be created in-memory without '
13520	                              'modifying the Registry. Starting with .NET Framework 4, the profiling DLL does not need '
13521	                              'to be registered as long as the location of the DLL is specified in the '
13522	                              'COR_PROFILER_PATH environment variable.(Citation: Microsoft COR_PROFILER Feb 2013)\n'
13523	                              '\n'
13524	                              'Adversaries may abuse COR_PROFILER to establish persistence that executes a malicious '
13525	                              'DLL in the context of all .NET processes every time the CLR is invoked. The '
13526	                              'COR_PROFILER can also be used to elevate privileges (ex: [Bypass User Account '
13527	                              'Control](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1548/002)) if the victim .NET process '
13528	                              'executes at a higher permission level, as well as to hook and [Impair '
13529	                              'Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) provided by .NET '
13530	                              'processes.(Citation: RedCanary Mockingbird May 2020)(Citation: Red Canary COR_PROFILER '
13531	                              'May 2020)(Citation: Almond COR_PROFILER Apr 2019)(Citation: GitHub OmerYa '
13532	                              'Invisi-Shell)(Citation: subTee .NET Profilers May 2017)',
13533	               'name': 'COR_PROFILER',
13534	               'platforms': ['Windows']},

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:13537
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
13536	               'categories': ['persistence', 'privilege-escalation', 'defense-evasion'],
13537	               'description': 'Adversaries may abuse the <code>KernelCallbackTable</code> of a process to hijack its '
13538	                              'execution flow in order to run their own payloads.(Citation: Lazarus APT January '
13539	                              '2022)(Citation: FinFisher exposed ) The <code>KernelCallbackTable</code> can be found '
13540	                              'in the Process Environment Block (PEB) and is initialized to an array of graphic '
13541	                              'functions available to a GUI process once <code>user32.dll</code> is loaded.(Citation: '
13542	                              'Windows Process Injection KernelCallbackTable)\n'
13543	                              '\n'
13544	                              'An adversary may hijack the execution flow of a process using the '
13545	                              '<code>KernelCallbackTable</code> by replacing an original callback function with a '
13546	                              'malicious payload. Modifying callback functions can be achieved in various ways '
13547	                              'involving related behaviors such as [Reflective Code '
13548	                              'Loading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1620) or [Process '
13549	                              'Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055) into another process.\n'
13550	                              '\n'
13551	                              'A pointer to the memory address of the <code>KernelCallbackTable</code> can be obtained '
13552	                              'by locating the PEB (ex: via a call to the <code>NtQueryInformationProcess()</code> '
13553	                              '[Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function).(Citation: '
13554	                              'NtQueryInformationProcess) Once the pointer is located, the '
13555	                              '<code>KernelCallbackTable</code> can be duplicated, and a function in the table (e.g., '
13556	                              '<code>fnCOPYDATA</code>) set to the address of a malicious payload (ex: via '
13557	                              '<code>WriteProcessMemory()</code>). The PEB is then updated with the new address of the '
13558	                              'table. Once the tampered function is invoked, the malicious payload will be '
13559	                              'triggered.(Citation: Lazarus APT January 2022)\n'
13560	                              '\n'
13561	                              'The tampered function is typically invoked using a Windows message. After the process '
13562	                              'is hijacked and malicious code is executed, the <code>KernelCallbackTable</code> may '
13563	                              'also be restored to its original state by the rest of the malicious payload.(Citation: '
13564	                              'Lazarus APT January 2022) Use of the <code>KernelCallbackTable</code> to hijack '
13565	                              'execution flow may evade detection from security products since the execution can be '
13566	                              'masked under a legitimate process.',

13711	                              'victim.\n'

13713	                              'For example, cloud providers often limit customer usage of compute resources via '

13715	                              'computing needs, though these adjustments may require approval from the cloud provider. '
13716	                              'Adversaries who compromise a cloud environment may similarly request quota adjustments '
13717	                              'in order to support their activities, such as enabling additional [Resource '
13718	                              'Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1496) without raising suspicion by '
13719	                              'using up a victim’s entire quota.(Citation: Microsoft Cryptojacking 2023) Adversaries '

13944	               'description': 'Adversaries may purchase online advertisements that can be abused to distribute malware '
13945	                              'to victims. Ads can be purchased to plant as well as favorably position artifacts in '
13946	                              'specific locations  online, such as prominently placed within search engine results. '
13947	                              'These ads may make it more difficult for users to distinguish between actual search '
13948	                              'results and advertisements.(Citation: spamhaus-malvertising) Purchased ads may also '
13949	                              'target specific audiences using the advertising network’s capabilities, potentially '
13950	                              'further taking advantage of the trust inherently given to search engines and popular '
13951	                              'websites. \n'
13952	                              '\n'
13953	                              'Adversaries may purchase ads and other resources to help distribute artifacts '
13954	                              'containing malicious code to victims. Purchased ads may attempt to impersonate or spoof '
13955	                              'well-known brands. For example, these spoofed ads may trick victims into clicking the '
13956	                              'ad which could then send them to a malicious domain that may be a clone of official '
13957	                              'websites containing trojanized versions of the advertised software.(Citation: '
13958	                              'Masquerads-Guardio)(Citation: FBI-search) Adversary’s efforts to create malicious '
13959	                              'domains and purchase advertisements may also be automated at scale to better resist '
13960	                              'cleanup efforts.(Citation: sentinelone-malvertising) \n'
13961	                              '\n'
13962	                              'Malvertising may be used to support [Drive-by '
13963	                              'Target](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1608/004) and [Drive-by '
13964	                              'Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189), potentially requiring limited '
13965	                              'interaction from the user if the ad contains code/exploits that infect the target '
13966	                              "system's web browser.(Citation: BBC-malvertising)\n"
13967	                              '\n'
13968	                              'Adversaries may also employ several techniques to evade detection by the advertising '
13969	                              'network. For example, adversaries may dynamically route ad clicks to send automated '
13970	                              'crawler/policy enforcer traffic to benign sites while validating potential targets then '
13971	                              'sending victims referred from real ad clicks to malicious pages. This infection vector '
13972	                              'may therefore remain hidden from the ad network as well as any visitor not reaching the '
13973	                              'malicious sites with a valid identifier from clicking on the advertisement.(Citation: '
13974	                              'Masquerads-Guardio) Other tricks, such as intentional typos to avoid brand reputation '
13975	                              'monitoring, may also be used to evade automated detection.(Citation: '
13976	                              'spamhaus-malvertising) ',
13977	               'name': 'Malvertising',

13982	                          'Infrastructure solutions include physical or cloud servers, domains, network devices, and '
13983	                          'third-party web and DNS services. Instead of buying, leasing, or renting infrastructure an '
13984	                          'adversary may compromise infrastructure and use it during other phases of the adversary '
13985	                          'lifecycle.(Citation: Mandiant APT1)(Citation: ICANNDomainNameHijacking)(Citation: Talos '
13986	                          'DNSpionage Nov 2018)(Citation: FireEye EPS Awakens Part 2) Additionally, adversaries may '
13987	                          'compromise numerous machines to form a botnet they can leverage.\n'
13988	                          '\n'
13989	                          'Use of compromised infrastructure allows adversaries to stage, launch, and execute '
13990	                          'operations. Compromised infrastructure can help adversary operations blend in with traffic '
13991	                          'that is seen as normal, such as contact with high reputation or trusted sites. For example, '
13992	                          'adversaries may leverage compromised infrastructure (potentially also in conjunction with '
13993	                          '[Digital Certificates](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588/004)) to further blend in '
13994	                          'and support staged information gathering and/or '
13995	                          '[Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) campaigns.(Citation: FireEye DNS '
13996	                          'Hijack 2019) Additionally, adversaries may also compromise infrastructure to support '
13997	                          '[Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090) and/or proxyware services.(Citation: '
13998	                          'amnesty_nso_pegasus)(Citation: Sysdig Proxyjacking)\n'
13999	                          '\n'
14000	                          'By using compromised infrastructure, adversaries may make it difficult to tie their actions '
14001	                          'back to them. Prior to targeting, adversaries may compromise the infrastructure of other '
14002	                          'adversaries.(Citation: NSA NCSC Turla OilRig)',

14418	                              'targeting. SSL/TLS certificates are designed to instill trust. They include information '
14419	                              "about the key, information about its owner's identity, and the digital signature of an "
14420	                              "entity that has verified the certificate's contents are correct. If the signature is "
14421	                              'valid, and the person examining the certificate trusts the signer, then they know they '
14422	                              'can use that key to communicate with its owner. In the case of self-signing, digital '
14423	                              'certificates will lack the element of trust associated with the signature of a '
14424	                              'third-party certificate authority (CA).\n'
14425	                              '\n'
14426	                              'Adversaries may create self-signed SSL/TLS certificates that can be used to further '
14427	                              'their operations, such as encrypting C2 traffic (ex: [Asymmetric '
14428	                              'Cryptography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1573/002) with [Web '
14429	                              'Protocols](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1071/001)) or even enabling '
14430	                              '[Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) if added to the '
14431	                              'root of trust (i.e. [Install Root '
14432	                              'Certificate](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1553/004)).\n'

14541	               'categories': ['resource-development'],
14542	               'description': 'Adversaries may buy and/or steal SSL/TLS certificates that can be used during '
14543	                              'targeting. SSL/TLS certificates are designed to instill trust. They include information '
14544	                              "about the key, information about its owner's identity, and the digital signature of an "
14545	                              "entity that has verified the certificate's contents are correct. If the signature is "
14546	                              'valid, and the person examining the certificate trusts the signer, then they know they '
14547	                              'can use that key to communicate with its owner.\n'
14548	                              '\n'

14550	                              'such as encrypting C2 traffic (ex: [Asymmetric '
14551	                              'Cryptography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1573/002) with [Web '
14552	                              'Protocols](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1071/001)) or even enabling '
14553	                              '[Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) if the certificate '
14554	                              'is trusted or otherwise added to the root of trust (i.e. [Install Root '
14555	                              'Certificate](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1553/004)). The purchase of digital '
14556	                              'certificates may be done using a front organization or using information stolen from a '
14557	                              'previously compromised entity that allows the adversary to validate to a certificate '
14558	                              'provider as that entity. Adversaries may also steal certificate materials directly from '

--------------------------------------------------
>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:15543
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
15542	           'categories': ['reconnaissance'],
15543	           'description': 'Adversaries may send phishing messages to elicit sensitive information that can be used '
15544	                          'during targeting. Phishing for information is an attempt to trick targets into divulging '
15545	                          'information, frequently credentials or other actionable information. Phishing for '
15546	                          'information is different from [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) in that '
15547	                          'the objective is gathering data from the victim rather than executing malicious code.\n'
15548	                          '\n'
15549	                          'All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be '
15550	                          'targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or '
15551	                          'industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct '
15552	                          'non-targeted phishing, such as in mass credential harvesting campaigns.\n'
15553	                          '\n'
15554	                          'Adversaries may also try to obtain information directly through the exchange of emails, '
15555	                          'instant messages, or other electronic conversation means.(Citation: ThreatPost Social Media '
15556	                          'Phishing)(Citation: TrendMictro Phishing)(Citation: PCMag FakeLogin)(Citation: Sophos '
15557	                          'Attachment)(Citation: GitHub Phishery) Victims may also receive phishing messages that '
15558	                          'direct them to call a phone number where the adversary attempts to collect confidential '
15559	                          'information.(Citation: Avertium callback phishing)\n'
15560	                          '\n'
15561	                          'Phishing for information frequently involves social engineering techniques, such as posing '
15562	                          'as a source with a reason to collect information (ex: [Establish '
15563	                          'Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1585) or [Compromise '
15564	                          'Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)) and/or sending multiple, seemingly '
15565	                          'urgent messages. Another way to accomplish this is by forging or spoofing(Citation: '
15566	                          'Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender which can be used to fool both the human '
15567	                          'recipient as well as automated security tools.(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) \n'
15568	                          '\n'
15569	                          'Phishing for information may also involve evasive techniques, such as removing or '
15570	                          'manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send '
15571	                          'messages (e.g., [Email Hiding '
15572	                          'Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam '
15573	                          '2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014)',
15574	           'name': 'Phishing for Information',
15575	           'platforms': ['PRE']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found

15626	               'categories': ['reconnaissance'],
15627	               'description': 'Adversaries may send spearphishing messages with a malicious link to elicit sensitive '
15628	                              'information that can be used during targeting. Spearphishing for information is an '
15629	                              'attempt to trick targets into divulging information, frequently credentials or other '
15630	                              'actionable information. Spearphishing for information frequently involves social '
15631	                              'engineering techniques, such as posing as a source with a reason to collect information '
15632	                              '(ex: [Establish Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1585) or [Compromise '
15633	                              'Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)) and/or sending multiple, '
15634	                              'seemingly urgent messages.\n'
15635	                              '\n'
15636	                              'All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at '
15637	                              'a specific individual, company, or industry. In this scenario, the malicious emails '
15638	                              'contain links generally accompanied by social engineering text to coax the user to '
15639	                              'actively click or copy and paste a URL into a browser.(Citation: TrendMictro '
15640	                              'Phishing)(Citation: PCMag FakeLogin) The given website may be a clone of a legitimate '
15641	                              'site (such as an online or corporate login portal) or may closely resemble a legitimate '
15642	                              'site in appearance and have a URL containing elements from the real site. URLs may also '
15643	                              'be obfuscated by taking advantage of quirks in the URL schema, such as the acceptance '
15644	                              'of integer- or hexadecimal-based hostname formats and the automatic discarding of text '
15645	                              'before an “@” symbol: for example, `hxxp://google.com@1157586937`.(Citation: Mandiant '
15646	                              'URL Obfuscation 2023)\n'
15647	                              '\n'
15648	                              'Adversaries may also embed “tracking pixels”, "web bugs", or "web beacons" within '
15649	                              'phishing messages to verify the receipt of an email, while also potentially profiling '
15650	                              'and tracking victim information such as IP address.(Citation: NIST Web Bug) (Citation: '
15651	                              'Ryte Wiki) These mechanisms often appear as small images (typically one pixel in size) '
15652	                              'or otherwise obfuscated objects and are typically delivered as HTML code containing a '
15653	                              'link to a remote server. (Citation: Ryte Wiki)(Citation: IAPP)\n'
15654	                              '\n'
15655	                              'Adversaries may also be able to spoof a complete website using what is known as a '
15656	                              '"browser-in-the-browser" (BitB) attack. By generating a fake browser popup window with '
15657	                              'an HTML-based address bar that appears to contain a legitimate URL (such as an '
15658	                              'authentication portal), they may be able to prompt users to enter their credentials '
15659	                              'while bypassing typical URL verification methods.(Citation: ZScaler BitB '
15660	                              '2020)(Citation: Mr. D0x BitB 2022)\n'
15661	                              '\n'
15662	                              'Adversaries can use phishing kits such as `EvilProxy` and `Evilginx2` to perform '
15663	                              'adversary-in-the-middle phishing by proxying the connection between the victim and the '
15664	                              'legitimate website. On a successful login, the victim is redirected to the legitimate '
15665	                              'website, while the adversary captures their session cookie (i.e., [Steal Web Session '
15666	                              'Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)) in addition to their username and '
15667	                              'password. This may enable the adversary to then bypass MFA via [Web Session '
15668	                              'Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/004).(Citation: Proofpoint Human '
15669	                              'Factor)\n'
15670	                              '\n'
15671	                              'Adversaries may also send a malicious link in the form of Quick Response (QR) Codes '
15672	                              '(also known as “quishing”). These links may direct a victim to a credential phishing '
15673	                              'page.(Citation: QR-campaign-energy-firm) By using a QR code, the URL may not be exposed '
15674	                              'in the email and may thus go undetected by most automated email security '
15675	                              'scans.(Citation: qr-phish-agriculture) These QR codes may be scanned by or delivered '
15676	                              'directly  to a user’s mobile device (i.e., '
15677	                              '[Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1660)), which may be less secure in '
15678	                              'several relevant ways.(Citation: qr-phish-agriculture) For example, mobile users may '
15679	                              'not be able to notice minor differences between genuine and credential harvesting '
15680	                              'websites due to mobile’s smaller form factor.\n'
15681	                              '\n'
15682	                              'From the fake website, information is gathered in web forms and sent to the adversary. '
15683	                              'Adversaries may also use information from previous reconnaissance efforts (ex: [Search '
15684	                              'Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search '
15685	                              'Victim-Owned Websites](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1594)) to craft persuasive '
15686	                              'and believable lures.',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:15718

15717	           'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
15718	           'description': 'Adversaries may bridge network boundaries by compromising perimeter network devices or '
15719	                          'internal devices responsible for network segmentation. Breaching these devices may enable '
15720	                          'an adversary to bypass restrictions on traffic routing that otherwise separate trusted and '
15721	                          'untrusted networks.\n'
15722	                          '\n'
15723	                          'Devices such as routers and firewalls can be used to create boundaries between trusted and '
15724	                          'untrusted networks.  They achieve this by restricting traffic types to enforce '
15725	                          'organizational policy in an attempt to reduce the risk inherent in such connections.  '
15726	                          'Restriction of traffic can be achieved by prohibiting IP addresses, layer 4 protocol ports, '
15727	                          'or through deep packet inspection to identify applications.  To participate with the rest '
15728	                          'of the network, these devices can be directly addressable or transparent, but their mode of '
15729	                          'operation has no bearing on how the adversary can bypass them when compromised.\n'
15730	                          '\n'
15731	                          'When an adversary takes control of such a boundary device, they can bypass its policy '
15732	                          'enforcement to pass normally prohibited traffic across the trust boundary between the two '
15733	                          'separated networks without hinderance.  By achieving sufficient rights on the device, an '
15734	                          'adversary can reconfigure the device to allow the traffic they want, allowing them to then '
15735	                          'further achieve goals such as command and control via [Multi-hop '
15736	                          'Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090/003) or exfiltration of data via [Traffic '
15737	                          'Duplication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1020/001). Adversaries may also target '
15738	                          'internal devices responsible for network segmentation and abuse these in conjunction with '
15739	                          '[Internal Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090/001) to achieve the same '
15740	                          'goals.(Citation: Kaspersky ThreatNeedle Feb 2021)  In the cases where a border device '
15741	                          'separates two separate organizations, the adversary can also facilitate lateral movement '
15742	                          'into new victim environments.',
15743	           'name': 'Network Boundary Bridging',
15744	           'platforms': ['Network']},

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:15747
   More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b824_url_found.html
15746	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
15747	               'description': 'Adversaries may bridge network boundaries by modifying a network device’s Network '
15748	                              'Address Translation (NAT) configuration. Malicious modifications to NAT may enable an '
15749	                              'adversary to bypass restrictions on traffic routing that otherwise separate trusted and '
15750	                              'untrusted networks.\n'
15751	                              '\n'
15752	                              'Network devices such as routers and firewalls that connect multiple networks together '
15753	                              'may implement NAT during the process of passing packets between networks. When '
15754	                              'performing NAT, the network device will rewrite the source and/or destination addresses '
15755	                              'of the IP address header. Some network designs require NAT for the packets to cross the '
15756	                              'border device.  A typical example of this is environments where internal networks make '
15757	                              'use of non-Internet routable addresses.(Citation: RFC1918)\n'
15758	                              '\n'
15759	                              'When an adversary gains control of a network boundary device, they can either leverage '
15760	                              'existing NAT configurations to send traffic between two separated networks, or they can '
15761	                              'implement NAT configurations of their own design.  In the case of network designs that '
15762	                              'require NAT to function, this enables the adversary to overcome inherent routing '
15763	                              'limitations that would normally prevent them from accessing protected systems behind '
15764	                              'the border device.  In the case of network designs that do not require NAT, address '
15765	                              'translation can be used by adversaries to obscure their activities, as changing the '
15766	                              'addresses of packets that traverse a network boundary device can make monitoring data '
15767	                              'transmissions more challenging for defenders.  \n'
15768	                              '\n'
15769	                              'Adversaries may use [Patch System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601/001) '
15770	                              'to change the operating system of a network device, implementing their own custom NAT '
15771	                              'mechanisms to further obscure their activities',
15772	               'name': 'Network Address Translation Traversal',
15773	               'platforms': ['Network']},

15775	           'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
15776	           'description': 'Adversaries may compromise a network device’s encryption capability in order to bypass '
15777	                          'encryption that would otherwise protect data communications. (Citation: Cisco Synful Knock '
15778	                          'Evolution)\n'
15779	                          '\n'
15780	                          'Encryption can be used to protect transmitted network traffic to maintain its '
15781	                          'confidentiality (protect against unauthorized disclosure) and integrity (protect against '
15782	                          'unauthorized changes). Encryption ciphers are used to convert a plaintext message to '
15783	                          'ciphertext and can be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated '
15784	                          'decryption key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption '
15785	                          'without the key.\n'
15786	                          '\n'
15787	                          'Adversaries can compromise and manipulate devices that perform encryption of network '
15788	                          'traffic. For example, through behaviors such as [Modify System '
15789	                          'Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601), [Reduce Key '
15790	                          'Space](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/001), and [Disable Crypto '
15791	                          'Hardware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/002), an adversary can negatively '
15792	                          'effect and/or eliminate a device’s ability to securely encrypt network traffic. This poses '
15793	                          'a greater risk of unauthorized disclosure and may help facilitate data manipulation, '
15794	                          'Credential Access, or Collection efforts. (Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)',
15795	           'name': 'Weaken Encryption',

15823	                              'network traffic to secure transmission across networks. Often, these devices are '
15824	                              'equipped with special, dedicated encryption hardware to greatly increase the speed of '
15825	                              'the encryption process as well as to prevent malicious tampering. When an adversary '
15826	                              'takes control of such a device, they may disable the dedicated hardware, for example, '

15854	                              'operating system and most of the functionality of the device is contained within a '
15855	                              'single file.  Adversaries may change this file in storage, to be loaded in a future '
15856	                              'boot, or in memory during runtime.\n'
15857	                              '\n'
15858	                              'To change the operating system in storage, the adversary will typically use the '
15859	                              'standard procedures available to device operators. This may involve downloading a new '
15860	                              'file via typical protocols used on network devices, such as TFTP, FTP, SCP, or a '
15861	                              'console connection.  The original file may be overwritten, or a new file may be written '
15862	                              'alongside of it and the device reconfigured to boot to the compromised image.\n'
15863	                              '\n'
15864	                              'To change the operating system in memory, the adversary typically can use one of two '
15865	                              'methods. In the first, the adversary would make use of native debug commands in the '
15866	                              'original, unaltered running operating system that allow them to directly modify the '
15867	                              'relevant memory addresses containing the running operating system.  This method '
15868	                              'typically requires administrative level access to the device.\n'
15869	                              '\n'
15870	                              'In the second method for changing the operating system in memory, the adversary would '
15871	                              'make use of the boot loader. The boot loader is the first piece of software that loads '
15872	                              'when the device starts that, in turn, will launch the operating system.  Adversaries '
15873	                              'may use malicious code previously implanted in the boot loader, such as through the '
15874	                              '[ROMMONkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/004) method, to directly '
15875	                              'manipulate running operating system code in memory.  This malicious code in the '
15876	                              'bootloader provides the capability of direct memory manipulation to the adversary, '
15877	                              'allowing them to patch the live operating system during runtime.\n'
15878	                              '\n'
15879	                              'By modifying the instructions stored in the system image file, adversaries may either '
15880	                              'weaken existing defenses or provision new capabilities that the device did not have '
15881	                              'before. Examples of existing defenses that can be impeded include encryption, via '
15882	                              '[Weaken Encryption](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600), authentication, via '
15883	                              '[Network Device Authentication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1556/004), and '
15884	                              'perimeter defenses, via [Network Boundary '
15885	                              'Bridging](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1599).  Adding new capabilities for the '
15886	                              'adversary’s purpose include '
15887	                              '[Keylogging](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1056/001), [Multi-hop '
15888	                              'Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090/003), and [Port '
15889	                              'Knocking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1205/001).\n'
15890	                              '\n'
15891	                              'Adversaries may also compromise existing commands in the operating system to produce '
15892	                              'false output to mislead defenders.   When this method is used in conjunction with '
15893	                              '[Downgrade System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601/002), one example of '
15894	                              'a compromised system command may include changing the output of the command that shows '
15895	                              'the version of the currently running operating system.  By patching the operating '
15896	                              'system, the adversary can change this command to instead display the original, higher '
15897	                              'revision number that they replaced through the system downgrade. \n'
15898	                              '\n'
15899	                              'When the operating system is patched in storage, this can be achieved in either the '
15900	                              'resident storage (typically a form of flash memory, which is non-volatile) or via [TFTP '
15901	                              'Boot](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/005). \n'
15902	                              '\n'
15903	                              'When the technique is performed on the running operating system in memory and not on '
15904	                              'the stored copy, this technique will not survive across reboots.  However, live memory '
15905	                              'modification of the operating system can be combined with '
15906	                              '[ROMMONkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/004) to achieve persistence. ',
15907	               'name': 'Patch System Image',
15908	               'platforms': ['Network']},
15909	 'T1601.002': {'attack_id': 'T1601.002',
15910	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
15911	               'description': 'Adversaries may install an older version of the operating system of a network device to '

15910	               'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
15911	               'description': 'Adversaries may install an older version of the operating system of a network device to '
15912	                              'weaken security.  Older operating system versions on network devices often have weaker '
15913	                              'encryption ciphers and, in general, fewer/less updated defensive features. (Citation: '
15914	                              'Cisco Synful Knock Evolution)\n'
15915	                              '\n'
15916	                              'On embedded devices, downgrading the version typically only requires replacing the '
15917	                              'operating system file in storage.  With most embedded devices, this can be achieved by '
15918	                              'downloading a copy of the desired version of the operating system file and '
15919	                              'reconfiguring the device to boot from that file on next system restart.  The adversary '
15920	                              'could then restart the device to implement the change immediately or they could wait '
15921	                              'until the next time the system restarts.\n'
15922	                              '\n'
15923	                              'Downgrading the system image to an older versions may allow an adversary to evade '
15924	                              'defenses by enabling behaviors such as [Weaken '
15925	                              'Encryption](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600).  Downgrading of a system image '
15926	                              'can be done on its own, or it can be used in conjunction with [Patch System '
15927	                              'Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601/001).  ',

16189	               'description': 'Adversaries may install SSL/TLS certificates that can be used during targeting. SSL/TLS '
16190	                              'certificates are files that can be installed on servers to enable secure communications '
16191	                              'between systems. Digital certificates include information about the key, information '
16192	                              "about its owner's identity, and the digital signature of an entity that has verified "
16193	                              "the certificate's contents are correct. If the signature is valid, and the person "
16194	                              'examining the certificate trusts the signer, then they know they can use that key to '
16195	                              'communicate securely with its owner. Certificates can be uploaded to a server, then the '
16196	                              'server can be configured to use the certificate to enable encrypted communication with '
16197	                              'it.(Citation: DigiCert Install SSL Cert)\n'
16198	                              '\n'

16219	                              'browsing to adversary controlled sites, as in [Drive-by '
16220	                              "Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189). In such cases, the user's web "
16221	                              'browser is typically targeted for exploitation (often not requiring any extra user '
16222	                              'interaction once landing on the site), but adversaries may also set up websites for '
16223	                              'non-exploitation behavior such as [Application Access '
16224	                              'Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/001). Prior to [Drive-by '
16225	                              'Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189), adversaries must stage '
16226	                              'resources needed to deliver that exploit to users who browse to an adversary controlled '
16227	                              'site. Drive-by content can be staged on adversary controlled infrastructure that has '
16228	                              'been acquired ([Acquire Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583)) or '
16229	                              'previously compromised ([Compromise '
16230	                              'Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584)).\n'
16231	                              '\n'
16232	                              'Adversaries may upload or inject malicious web content, such as '
16233	                              '[JavaScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/007), into websites.(Citation: '
16234	                              'FireEye CFR Watering Hole 2012)(Citation: Gallagher 2015) This may be done in a number '
16235	                              'of ways, including:\n'
16236	                              '\n'
16237	                              '* Inserting malicious scripts into web pages or other user controllable web content '
16238	                              'such as forum posts\n'
16239	                              '* Modifying script files served to websites from publicly writeable cloud storage '
16240	                              'buckets\n'
16241	                              '* Crafting malicious web advertisements and purchasing ad space on a website through '
16242	                              'legitimate ad providers (i.e., '
16243	                              '[Malvertising](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583/008))\n'
16244	                              '\n'
16245	                              "In addition to staging content to exploit a user's web browser, adversaries may also "
16246	                              "stage scripting content to profile the user's browser (as in [Gather Victim Host "
16247	                              'Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1592)) to ensure it is vulnerable '
16248	                              'prior to attempting exploitation.(Citation: ATT ScanBox)\n'
16249	                              '\n'
16250	                              'Websites compromised by an adversary and used to stage a drive-by may be ones visited '
16251	                              'by a specific community, such as government, a particular industry, or region, where '
16252	                              'the goal is to compromise a specific user or set of users based on a shared interest. '
16253	                              'This kind of targeted campaign is referred to a strategic web compromise or watering '
16254	                              'hole attack.\n'
16255	                              '\n'
16256	                              'Adversaries may purchase domains similar to legitimate domains (ex: homoglyphs, '
16257	                              'typosquatting, different top-level domain, etc.) during acquisition of infrastructure '
16258	                              '([Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583/001)) to help facilitate [Drive-by '
16259	                              'Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189).',

16264	               'description': 'Adversaries may put in place resources that are referenced by a link that can be used '
16265	                              'during targeting. An adversary may rely upon a user clicking a malicious link in order '
16266	                              'to divulge information (including credentials) or to gain execution, as in [Malicious '
16267	                              'Link](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/001). Links can be used for '
16268	                              'spearphishing, such as sending an email accompanied by social engineering text to coax '
16269	                              'the user to actively click or copy and paste a URL into a browser. Prior to a phish for '
16270	                              'information (as in [Spearphishing Link](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598/003)) '
16271	                              'or a phish to gain initial access to a system (as in [Spearphishing '
16272	                              'Link](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/002)), an adversary must set up the '
16273	                              'resources for a link target for the spearphishing link. \n'
16274	                              '\n'

16276	                              'client-side script such as [JavaScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/007) '
16277	                              'to decide what content to serve to the user. Adversaries may clone legitimate sites to '
16278	                              'serve as the link target, this can include cloning of login pages of legitimate web '

16379	                          'Overview)\n'
16380	                          '\n'
16381	                          'There are multiple ways an adversary may escape to a host environment. Examples include '
16382	                          'creating a container configured to mount the host’s filesystem using the bind parameter, '
16383	                          'which allows the adversary to drop payloads and execute control utilities such as cron on '
16384	                          'the host; utilizing a privileged container to run commands or load a malicious kernel '
16385	                          'module on the underlying host; or abusing system calls such as `unshare` and `keyctl` to '
16386	                          'escalate privileges and steal secrets.(Citation: Docker Bind Mounts)(Citation: Trend Micro '
16387	                          'Privileged Container)(Citation: Intezer Doki July 20)(Citation: Container Escape)(Citation: '

16518	                          'Android Permissions)\n'

16520	                          'Dialer interface(Citation: Android Permissions)\n'

16527	                          '`ConnectionService`(Citation: Android Permissions)\n'

16529	                          'hide malicious phone calls(Citation: Android Permissions)\n'
16530	                          '\n'
16531	                          'When granted some of these permissions, an application can make a phone call without '
16532	                          'opening the dialer first. However, if an application desires to simply redirect the user to '
16533	                          'the dialer with a phone number filled in, it can launch an Intent using '
16534	                          '`Intent.ACTION_DIAL`, which requires no specific permissions. This then requires the user '
16535	                          'to explicitly initiate the call or use some form of [Input '
16536	                          'Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1516) to programmatically initiate it.',

>> Issue: [B824:url_found] url_found
   Severity: Medium   Confidence: Medium
   Location: /home/blue/PyPIAgent/Dataset/study/unzip_benign/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline-4.6.0.dev5/assemblyline/common/attack_map.py:16567

16566	           'categories': ['defense-evasion'],
16567	           'description': 'Adversaries may reflectively load code into a process in order to conceal the execution of '
16568	                          'malicious payloads. Reflective loading involves allocating then executing payloads directly '
16569	                          'within the memory of the process, vice creating a thread or process backed by a file path '
16570	                          'on disk (e.g., [Shared Modules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1129)).\n'
16571	                          '\n'
16572	                          'Reflectively loaded payloads may be compiled binaries, anonymous files (only present in '
16573	                          'RAM), or just snubs of fileless executable code (ex: position-independent '
16574	                          'shellcode).(Citation: Introducing Donut)(Citation: S1 Custom Shellcode Tool)(Citation: '
16575	                          'Stuart ELF Memory)(Citation: 00sec Droppers)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL) For example, the '
16576	                          '`Assembly.Load()` method executed by '
16577	                          '[PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) may be abused to load raw code '
16578	                          'into the running process.(Citation: Microsoft AssemblyLoad)\n'
16579	                          '\n'
16580	                          'Reflective code injection is very similar to [Process '
16581	                          'Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055) except that the “injection” loads '
16582	                          'code into the processes’ own memory instead of that of a separate process. Reflective '
16583	                          'loading may evade process-based detections since the execution of the arbitrary code may be '
16584	                          'masked within a legitimate or otherwise benign process. Reflectively loading payloads '
16585	                          'directly into memory may also avoid creating files or other artifacts on disk, while also '
16586	                          'enabling malware to keep these payloads encrypted (or otherwise obfuscated) until '
16587	                          'execution.(Citation: Stuart ELF Memory)(Citation: 00sec Droppers)(Citation: Intezer '
16588	                          'ACBackdoor)(Citation: S1 Old Rat New Tricks)',
16589	           'name': 'Reflective Code Loading',
16590	           'platforms': ['macOS', 'Linux', 'Windows']},

16795	                              'behaviors. For example, malware operators may limit the distribution of a second stage '
16796	                              'payload to certain geographic regions.(Citation: Lookout eSurv)\n'
16797	                              '\n'
16798	                              '[Geofencing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1627/001)\u202fis accomplished by '
16799	                              'persuading the user to grant the application permission to access location services. '
16800	                              'The application can then collect, process, and exfiltrate the device’s location to '
16801	                              'perform location-based actions, such as ceasing malicious behavior or showing '
16802	                              'region-specific advertisements. \n'
16803	                              '\n'
16804	                              'One method to accomplish\u202f'
16805	                              '[Geofencing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1627/001)\u202fon Android is to use '
16806	                              'the built-in Geofencing API to automatically trigger certain behaviors when the device '
16807	                              'enters or exits a specified radius around a geographical location. Similar to  '
16808	                              'other\u202f[Geofencing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1627/001) methods, this '
16809	                              'requires that the user has granted the `ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION` and '
16810	                              '`ACCESS_BACKGROUND_LOCATION` permissions. The latter is only required if the '
16811	                              'application targets Android 10 (API level 29) or higher. However, Android 11 introduced '
16812	                              'additional permission controls that may restrict background location collection based '
16813	                              'on user permission choices at runtime. These additional controls include "Allow only '
16814	                              'while using the app", which will effectively prohibit background location '
16815	                              'collection.  \n'
16816	                              '\n'
16817	                              'Similarly, on iOS, developers can use built-in APIs to setup and execute geofencing. '
16818	                              'Depending on the use case, the app will either need to call\u202f'
16819	                              '`requestWhenInUseAuthorization()`\u202for\u202f`requestAlwaysAuthorization()`, '
16820	                              'depending on when access to the location services is required. Similar to Android, '
16821	                              'users also have the option to limit when the application can access the device’s '
16822	                              'location, including one-time use and only when the application is running in the '
16823	                              'foreground.  \n'

16827	                              'operated within. For example, location data could be used to limit malware spread '

17261	           'categories': ['collection'],
17262	           'description': 'Adversaries may attempt to position themselves between two or more networked devices to '
17263	                          'support follow-on behaviors such as [Transmitted Data '
17264	                          'Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002) or [Endpoint Denial of '
17265	                          'Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1642).  \n'
17266	                          '\n'
17267	                          ' \n'
17268	                          '\n'
17269	                          '[Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1638) can be achieved '
17270	                          'through several mechanisms. For example, a malicious application may register itself as a '
17271	                          'VPN client, effectively redirecting device traffic to adversary-owned resources. '
17272	                          'Registering as a VPN client requires user consent on both Android and iOS; additionally, a '
17273	                          'special entitlement granted by Apple is needed for iOS devices. Alternatively, a malicious '
17274	                          'application with escalation privileges may utilize those privileges to gain access to '
17275	                          'network traffic.   \n'
17276	                          '\n'
17277	                          '\n'
17278	                          ' Specific to Android devices, adversary-in-the-disk is a type of AiTM attack where '
17279	                          'adversaries monitor and manipulate data that is exchanged between applications and external '
17280	                          'storage.(Citation: mitd_kaspersky)(Citation: mitd_checkpoint)(Citation: '
17281	                          'mitd_checkpoint_research) To accomplish this, a malicious application firsts requests for '
17282	                          'access to multimedia files on the device (`READ_EXTERNAL STORAGE` and '
17283	                          '`WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE`), then the application reads data on the device and/or writes '
17284	                          'malware to the device. Though the request for access is common, when used maliciously, '
17285	                          'adversaries may access files and other sensitive data due to abusing the permission. '
17286	                          'Multiple applications were shown to be vulnerable against this attack; however, scrutiny of '
17287	                          'permissions and input validations may mitigate this attack.    \n'
17288	                          '\n'
17289	                          'Outside of a mobile device, adversaries may be able to capture traffic by employing a rogue '
17290	                          'base station or Wi-Fi access point. These devices will allow adversaries to capture network '
17291	                          'traffic after it has left the device, while it is flowing to its destination. On a local '
17292	                          'network, enterprise techniques could be used, such as [ARP Cache '
17293	                          'Poisoning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557/002) or [DHCP '
17294	                          'Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557/003).  \n'
17295	                          '\n'
17296	                          ' \n'
17297	                          '\n'
17298	                          'If applications properly encrypt their network traffic, sensitive data may not be '
17299	                          'accessible to adversaries, depending on the point of capture. For example, properly '
17300	                          'implementing Apple’s Application Transport Security (ATS) and Android’s Network Security '
17301	                          'Configuration (NSC) may prevent sensitive data leaks.(Citation: NSC_Android)',
17302	           'name': 'Adversary-in-the-Middle',

17358	                              'transmission mechanism as well as the goals and objectives of the adversary. For '
17359	                              'complex systems, an adversary would likely need special expertise and possibly access '
17360	                              'to specialized software related to the system, typically gained through a prolonged '
17361	                              'information gathering campaign, in order to have the desired impact.\n'

17364	                              'Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1641/001) is by modifying the '

17366	                              'through the `ClipboardManager.OnPrimaryClipChangedListener` interface on Android to '

17508	           'categories': ['credential-access'],
17509	           'description': 'Adversaries may steal or forge certificates used for authentication to access remote '
17510	                          'systems or resources. Digital certificates are often used to sign and encrypt messages '
17511	                          'and/or files. Certificates are also used as authentication material. For example, Azure AD '
17512	                          'device certificates and Active Directory Certificate Services (AD CS) certificates bind to '
17513	                          'an identity and can be used as credentials for domain accounts.(Citation: O365 Blog Azure '
17514	                          'AD Device IDs)(Citation: Microsoft AD CS Overview)\n'
17515	                          '\n'
17516	                          'Authentication certificates can be both stolen and forged. For example, AD CS certificates '
17517	                          'can be stolen from encrypted storage (in the Registry or files)(Citation: APT29 Deep Look '
17518	                          'at Credential Roaming), misplaced certificate files (i.e. [Unsecured '
17519	                          'Credentials](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1552)), or directly from the Windows '
17520	                          'certificate store via various crypto APIs.(Citation: SpecterOps Certified Pre '
17521	                          'Owned)(Citation: GitHub CertStealer)(Citation: GitHub GhostPack Certificates) With '
17522	                          'appropriate enrollment rights, users and/or machines within a domain can also request '
17523	                          'and/or manually renew certificates from enterprise certificate authorities (CA). This '
17524	                          'enrollment process defines various settings and permissions associated with the '
17525	                          'certificate. Of note, the certificate’s extended key usage (EKU) values define signing, '
17526	                          'encryption, and authentication use cases, while the certificate’s subject alternative name '
17527	                          '(SAN) values define the certificate owner’s alternate names.(Citation: Medium Certified Pre '
17528	                          'Owned)\n'
17529	                          '\n'
17530	                          'Abusing certificates for authentication credentials may enable other behaviors such as '
17531	                          '[Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008). Certificate-related '
17532	                          'misconfigurations may also enable opportunities for [Privilege '
17533	                          'Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0004), by way of allowing users to '
17534	                          'impersonate or assume privileged accounts or permissions via the identities (SANs) '
17535	                          'associated with a certificate. These abuses may also enable '
17536	                          '[Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003) via stealing or forging certificates '
17537	                          'that can be used as [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) for the '
17538	                          "duration of the certificate's validity, despite user password resets. Authentication "
17539	                          'certificates can also be stolen and forged for machine accounts.\n'
17540	                          '\n'
17541	                          'Adversaries who have access to root (or subordinate) CA certificate private keys (or '
17542	                          'mechanisms protecting/managing these keys) may also establish '
17543	                          '[Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003) by forging arbitrary authentication '
17544	                          'certificates for the victim domain (known as “golden” certificates).(Citation: Medium '
17545	                          'Certified Pre Owned) Adversaries may also target certificates and related services in order '
17546	                          'to access other forms of credentials, such as [Golden '
17547	                          'Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1558/001) ticket-granting tickets (TGT) or '
17548	                          'NTLM plaintext.(Citation: Medium Certified Pre Owned)',

17554	                          'network. A variety of online services and initial access broker networks are available to '

17556	                          'Service)(Citation: CrowdStrike Access Brokers)(Citation: Krebs Access Brokers Fortune 500) '
17557	                          'In some cases, adversary groups may form partnerships to share compromised systems with '

17562	                          'access via [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133). In some '
17563	                          'cases, access brokers will implant compromised systems with a “load” that can be used to '
17564	                          'install additional malware for paying customers.(Citation: Microsoft Ransomware as a '
17565	                          'Service)\n'
17566	                          '\n'
17567	                          'By leveraging existing access broker networks rather than developing or obtaining their own '
17568	                          'initial access capabilities, an adversary can potentially reduce the resources required to '
17569	                          'gain a foothold on a target network and focus their efforts on later stages of compromise. '
17570	                          'Adversaries may prioritize acquiring access to systems that have been determined to lack '
17571	                          'security monitoring or that have high privileges, or systems that belong to organizations '
